reviews.title: OK Headphones
reviews.text: I think these headphones are more like 3.5 stars but I rounded up.  I have kind of a small head for an adult female, and still these headphones were too tight.  Usually I can wear headphones made for kids but not these.  These are definitely for smaller heads and small ears since the ear cups get painful after a while since they aren't big enough to fully cover my ears.  The sound is o.k., nothing to write home about, but for the price (as of this review these head phones cost $19.44) I think they are worth it.  Great for kids, not so good for adults, even if you are a pinhead.

reviews.title: High quality headphones
reviews.text: These are perfect for my 4th grade child to use at school. It is hard to find headphones with plug-ins and that aren't wireless. For my son, the ones with a plug are best to use his school issued ipad. These are sturdy and I'm hoping they last the entire school year.

reviews.title: Not really for large heads.
reviews.text: All the talk about "classroom" and "child's" in the Amazon listing really means "this is a small headset." It's not big enough for me. I have a large (7 3/4) head and this thing actually hurts my ears (presses on them too hard). If you need headphones for a child then this would work just fine. Not for me.

reviews.title: Good headphones for kids
reviews.text: These are perfect for my 6 yr old. They fit her great and don’t get so loud that they can damage her ears.

reviews.title: Great for TV
reviews.text:
So far the KBEAR Larks are the best sounding dual driver in-ear I have used. I have used them for listing music, playing and singing live and even watching TV. In comparison, I have about 5 different pair of dual driver in ears. These are by far my favorite.

Live music:
I use more expensive 5-8 driver in ears for playing live. I will say these don’t stack up against the more expensive in-ears but if I had to choose from this price bracket then I would choose these.

Great for TV:
Recently I tried all my in-ears(12 pair) for listening to tv. My parents often do this as they are hard of hearing and they get a much better listening experience with headphones. Therefore, I thought I would find the most well rounded pair for doing just that. These won! I preferred them, even over headphones that cost twice as much.

Listening to music:
These got the job done. I wasn’t amazed but they didn’t leave a lot to be desired either.

EQ:
Slightly elevated lows and highs. To me they weren’t harsh. They lacked some clarity but nothing sounded intrusive to my ears which tends to happen with other brands.

Pros:
-Nice packaging
-Quality case
-Somewhat a jack of all trades. Do many things well.
-Look stylish
-Fit my ears well
-Comfortable especially with replacement memory foam tips

Cons:
-Silicone tips suck. Replace with memory foam.
-My other 2 pin cords didn’t fit these.

reviews.title: Good value and monitor sound is good for music and voices.
reviews.text: I use these IEMs while singing with my church's praise team. The sound quality is good and allows good distinction of sounds without distortion or static. Connecting the wire to each ear bud was easy in comparison the other brand I had. I've not had any issues with them disconnecting. I also like the copper cord since it is more inconspicuous with colored clothing. The length of the cord is long enough to run down the back of my shirt and into the pack on my waistband. I am satisfied with this product and would buy them again.

reviews.title: OK IEMs
reviews.text: Work OK but sound quality not as good as other in ear monitors that I own in the same price range.

reviews.title: Great sound for a cheap fun IEM! Fake sloppy bass lol
reviews.text: The KBEAR KS2 are actually pretty great sounding! I was really surprised for the price on these the sound is really Bassy and fun. The dynamic driver 10mm produces some intense bass and deep lows that sound stunning and the balanced armature mixes almost perfectly together. Vocals are pushed forward a bit and mids are also. Kind of hard to explain I haven’t listened that much yet but compared to my Jade Audio EA3 they aren’t as professional sounding it’s more of a enhanced sloppy bass and everything is pushed forward more. Still a fun IEM though I would definitely recommend them given you get some different ear tips and a cord if you have an extra (it’s not horrible).

reviews.title: These Don't last.
reviews.text:
I was pretty sad to discover that these literally lasted one road trip from Oregon to Southern California. Roughly 20hrs of drive time so I used them for music and audio books. The sound quality was okay but not great. If we had a lot of road noise I couldn't hear anything on full volume
When I tried to use them for the return trip they were even quieter and the microphone wouldn't do more then a whisper on the other end. We tried multiple phones and multiple carriers to see if that was the issue
Another issue on the 2nd round was the amount of feedback we had on the line when calling or even listening to music. I thought my phone was broken or something till I turned my Bluetooth off and just used my phone speaker. I was really excited for this but won't buy them again.

reviews.title: I do not recommend these earbuds.  They have a serious design flaw.
reviews.text:
I would have easily given these earbuds 4 or 5 stars, if it wasn't for the "low battery" warning. JLAB clearly put no thought into this. Here are my issues:

1) The first low battery warning occurs about 5 minutes before the battery dies . So if you just started your jog, or just got on the bus, you're screwed. With 6 hours of play time, the low battery notification should give you at least 20 minutes notice. Since you are almost always "out and about" when listening to headphones, it would be nice to have enough juice to finish your activity or get where you are going.

2) The low battery message (which is verbal) repeats FREQUENTLY for the brief remainder of your battery life, constantly interrupting your music. This is so annoying you wind up taking the earbuds off.

Since the earbuds are essentially useless once you get the first low battery warning, the warning serves no purpose. Giving the low battery warnings at the 30, 20 and 10 minute marks would be far less annoying and actually give you a chance to get to a charger.

reviews.title: Best for DVDs and Inserts - HIGHLY RECOMMENDED
reviews.text: I've tried a few of these DVD albums, and this is best of the rest. The insert section is roomy enough so you only have to fold along one line and it will slide in comfortably  thus you can see the front and title edge. With Bellagio, you have to double fold, and it creases your insert more than you might want, especially if you think someday you might resell them -- messes with the aesthetics. As far as room, I can slip in 2 inserts, moving one up and under the blank space above and keeping the other low, so able to utilize every slot without feeling like I'm cheating myself by not having both inserts. In addition, for those annoying 3 disc DVDs/BluRay sets, you can slide one of the discs in with the insert, and it will be safe there. It's a sturdy product. I've been using my 240 count for 3 years now, and just bought a 120 in June. The 240 has held up very nicely, and I expect the same of the 120. If you have a large collection you want to transfer, you might want to do some planning ahead of time on how you want group your DVDs, because once you have packed your album, it is difficult to move pages around to reorganize. I had to remove my DVD and inserts. As long as it's not packed, you can manage. The metal clip is very strong and it's a firm hold, but when the slots are full, the bulk of it slides all the pages out because the pages are slick. I didn't have help to hold them in place, and you're going to need it. Leave a few empty in your groupings for new DVDs. The pages themselves are a good quality plastic and soft backing to avoid scratching. It's nicely balanced. I would recommend the 120 more than the 240 because it's easier to carry and store when full but as I said, my 240 has held up very nicely in 3 years. It is currently about 16# full. I don't carry the 240 by the handle. Don't want to push my luck. I can find no damage or weakening in it and every single original page is double packed with CDs  & Inserts, plus, I swiped a few pages from the 120 to put into the 240.  The downside is, if the pages ever do start to rip or tear, you can't find refills -- I've looked.  I have no hesitation in recommending this to anyone wanting to get away from cases and consolidate your DVD collection.  I just haven't found anything else I'm happy with.

reviews.text:
This gadget is simply ahead of its time. For audio enthusiasts (like me) who dare to explore how the right DAC can elevate the experience of music listening to a delightful level, this DAC won't disappoint. It brings out the best in headphones (reasonably decent ones), which in my case were a Sennheiser HD 600 and a budget triple-driver IEM. Also, it breathed life into the premium speakers of my old car--simply unbelievable; I never heard them sound so good (the DAC's line-out was fed into the car's aux-in). My tracks came from Amazon HD Music.

As a gadget aficionado in general, I find this DAC well-designed, functionality- and aesthetics-wise, and with a solid build and classy finishing that clearly distinguish it from the other DACs in this price range. It's one of the best gadgets I bought during recent years.

reviews.title: Much better than expected...Updated!!! MQA use...
reviews.text:
02/16/21
I've been using the Q5s TC for some weeks now mainly with Apple Music and sometimes the SIRIUSXM app for iOS on my iPhone 12 Pro. Just a days ago I decided to check out MQA music on TIDAL. I have multiple headphones and settled on Shure SRH1540 and SRH1840. I have listed a number of headphones in other reviews so I won't go there. Anyway, WOW!!!, what a revelation. Listening to MQA's through TIDAL is very revealing and at one point on some recordings I had to say to myself, "there were anymore detail and layering I would be able to taste and smell it". I can also easily hear what I can assume is in some cases budgets, engineering and anything else that might affect the way a recording sounds.

Now from my understanding the Q5s does not unpack the MQA music file but it appears. it's definitely seeing and recognizing the file, if not totally able to unpack it. I say this because the indicator on the front glows a solid yellow which according to FiiO is AptX HD, don't know but it makes a difference. Talking about spacial clues? all over the place. But of course it depends on the recording. I can say this, listening to all my old new music, from Aretha to Soundgarden and more is so much fun and enjoyable.

I'm a ex-audiophile that actually love music more than the equipment (most of the time). The Apple AirPods Max reviews and rages made me revisit headphone collection. After selling 3 and decommissioning 1 I ended up with my mostly hated (not by me, I love the way sound) Sennheiser HD700. Measurements and other people's bias' aside I decided to put a dac/amp in my setup for my iPhone 12 Pro. The Q5s plugs right into my iPhone via the supplied connector with no issues at all. The bluetooth works great as well. I prefer direct connection over using BT mainly because I want to as close to the true signal as possible. AAC sounds great through this dac/amp combo. I can't hear a real difference the 2. The Q5s is a solid and professional quality dac/amp combo. It does get a little warm while running but nothing that concerns me. I'm also using the Shanling UP4 which is to my ears good too and serves another purpose in modest collection. The Shanling is not capable of plugging directly into the iPhone but does a really decent job with BT. I prefer the direct connection ability of the Q5s. Of course like I mention the build quality is in a different league as it should be due to the price difference between the 2.

reviews.title: Ain’t loud enough...
reviews.text: It sounded low volume, muffled & cluttered to me. Didn’t sound like an *amp* with dual chips. BT wasn’t strong enough either.

reviews.title: They fixed all of my complaints with the Q5
reviews.text:
1) One USB port
2) Volume knob is also the power-on, as found on the Q1
3) Nice input selector on the right with some labeled LEDs that also show battery charging level
4) Fewer buttons
5) Bluetooth 5.0 can do 24-bit/96khz, so need cable only for charging once Apple supports aptX HD (audiophile-only issue)

Before going any further, I upgraded the firmware from 0.04 to the latest (0.39). The frequency response with 0.39 seems a lot smoother.

The Q5s sounds different from Q5. It's a clearer, more detailed sound. I also like that the bass level is a little higher with the OFF setting. I use ATH-M50x headphones.

So, FiiO, if you are listening, here are my new suggestions:

a) Replace the microUSB port with USB-C. It's a much more reliable connection. microUSB gets loose over time.
b) Have a bass switch or knob that allows for more bass settings. Actually, the EQ feature on the FiiO app is probably a better way to go, assuming it is remembered when not using the app. I have not tried it yet. If that's the case, why not get rid of the base boost button altogether?
c) Have different sleep timeouts for charging vs. not charging. Add 1 hour, 2 hour, and Never as possibilities to each.

Non-FiiO problem: macOS and iOS do not support Bluetooth aptX HD or LDAC, so I will need to wait for 24-bit/96khz over BT 5.0. I submitted a bug to Apple. I hope others will do the same.

reviews.title: Works well for sleeping
reviews.text:
I wanted some headphones that were flat and wouldn't hurt my ears or fall out and get lost while I was trying to go to sleep. These work just fine. The speakers lie flatly against my head and don't poke or feel lumpy. I only use them for sleeping, though, not for exercising, so I can't say how easy or difficult it would be to remove the speakers and controller to wash the headband part.

Sound is fine. They don't go into your ear like regular earbuds, so you have to turn the volume up a little, but it does what it should. I haven't tried to control the volume using the buttons on the headband so I can't really rate that aspect. All in all, it does what I wanted it to.

reviews.title: Great quality device if you're on a budget
reviews.text: [[VIDEOID:e49e95641bb1dc426258e889516d11e0]] Over great product for the price. I can't complain. If you've got the money and would like to go for a more "high end" product there are plenty of options available. However, this one appeals greater to the general public. Most reviews say the same thing: It cuts out if too far away and it has a short battery life. Also if it is being used while charging you'll heard a little buzzing noise. You get what you pay for. It does its job and I can't complain  for the price.

reviews.title: For A/V wireless solution, it is workable but not perfect.
reviews.text:
First, my purpose is to stream audio to wired QC headphones from my AV receiver, as a replacement for my broken analog FM TV sound transmitter/phones. For THIS purpose... I bought a pair of these BT devices, and it works, but the sync between audio and video is - versus analog - perceptible. The streaming generation is less sensitive to this, but AV-philes find it annoying.

It is a problem in all BT, compressed audio, technologies - to some degree. Compressed audio requires buffering, buffering introduces some minimum delay, and the delay can be worse depending upon the nature of the audio.
For many programs (sports, etc) sync isn't a problem, but in close-up talky-talky scenes the audio lag is annoying vs. the FM phones, which have imperceptible lag. For NON-SYNCed applications - this is a non-issue.
I wish Roku had a AV sync setting (+/- ms). This is what BT 5.0 does - it delays the video based on the estimated audio lag. *But that doesn't help here because these devices do NOT control the video stream*.

Otherwise, audio quality of BT vs FM is equivalent. My FM phones were very good (AR, $150) and audio was excellent, so the BT pair has good sound in this application. I have not noted any static others reported, except for a slight hum when the RX is not connected. Generally, the BT audio is equivalent to any other BT audio connection (ie., streaming iPhone to car stereo, etc.).
8/18/2020 Revision: After a power outage, I noticed a VERY bad hum. Removed RX side's power, no change. Removed TX sides power (from USB outlet on cable box), NO HUM. I tried several other USB outlets, each had some hum though with different qualities. Finally, I got out a good high amp USB hub & used it to power the TX side - no hum at all. SO... the transmitting side is VERY sensitive to ripple in its USB power circuitry.

One VERY annoying thing - my devices both power off after 4hrs (6hrs?) regardless of input, even though both TX/RX devices are permanently wired to USB power. It ought to power down only if on battery or unconnected for some time (firmware update perhaps?). Other than this obvious design choice, I have had no connection issues - power on TX, then RX, connects reliably in ~10s. Once connected stays reliably connected UNTIL it powers down.

So the good: Cheap solution to use superior wired headphones. Small & USB powered, so hides away easily on both TX and RX sides. Cheaper & more versatile than quality FM TV transmitter/phone combos.

And the bad: Audio LAGS behind video noticeably, 50-150ms. Also, I haven't tried with multiple BT sources - but there is no UI, no way to select a specific source - I suspect this would be a problem for some.

Overall: For the price, I can't complain and wouldn't spend 5x for good FM TV audio phones.

reviews.title: Neckbands are fine, but earhooks are useless for me
reviews.text:
The neckbands worked fine, and all items gripped my gen 2 AirPods okay, but the earhooks were not even a little useful for me.

I’m used to wearing headphones with integral earhooks, and loved the fit of those, but these add-on earhooks for Airpods do not have the right amount of rigidity, nor is it easy enough to rotate and position them appropriately with respect to the AirPod stem so that the combined geometry of the two would ever align to my ear. Because of those two factors, they simultaneously made my AirPods look kind of stupid while at the same time actually making the fit/hold even worse; they seemed almost more likely to fall out with the hooks than without them.

reviews.text: I didn't know that silicone could actually tear like this stuff has when I removed them from my AirPods. I'm past the return window and these literally ripped after about a month and a half of use when I was trying to slide them off the AirPods. Look elsewhere!

reviews.title: These saved my ears! Literally.
reviews.text: My new Bose 700 headphones kept causing an allergic reaction to my ears and the skin all the way around my ears.  Like blisters, redness, swelling and SEVERE itching.  The first time, I wore them for an afternoon and it took 3 weeks for the allergy to be cleared up.  I then washed the cups of the headphones with a soapy wash rag and rinsed well.  The second time I wore them for just under 2 hours and again had a reaction that took 2 weeks to clear up.  I use another brand of headphones daily to watch TV (that I also purchased from amazon) and have never had a reaction before.  I found these covers and they have completely fixed the reaction issue.  I also ordered another brand of ear cup covers off amazon to try but prefer these.  I'll be ordering another so I'll have extras just in case 😉.

reviews.title: Amazing ear pad replacements for the Logitech G35 headset!
reviews.text:
- Makes my G35 headset look better than when I bought it new thanks to the red accent markings!
- The installation tool was extremely helpful, and thanks for including it.
- Just a bit of warning for others the kit that includes the head pad isn’t mean for the Logitech G35 headset, because it is a different size and it doesn’t have Velcro underneath the head pad. I just ordered the ear pads only, and ended up using the spare two fake leather head pads that came with my G35 headset.
- Other thoughts: Not sure what some people are complaining about, but my ear pads are comfortable and fit my headset well. I’m just going to assume some peoples ears are extremely sensitive than others to certain fabrics. I like the cloth mesh pads compared to the original leather pads for two reasons. The cloth won’t crack or peel off like the leather pads, and the cloth pads are more breathable for the ears (ears won’t get hot or humid).

reviews.title: Difficult to connect. Oddly LOW VOLUME and INTERFERES with apps like VIBER and DUO. Easy to loose.
reviews.text:
Where do I start:::
Connecting, if you want to use it with multiple devices, you can just forget it (if connected to one device, they will not allow you to connect to another device until you actually delete the connection from the current device even if it's off, did not have this issue with Apple Pods).
SOUND LEVEL is oddly LOW. Seriously, even at max setting does not even come close to even cheap plug-in buds, so can't use them in any loud place. Noise canceling does not help with that.
If used with call apps like Viber or Duo you'll be missing every other word. Don't know how or why, but connection signal goes to crap while these are on. As soon as I switch to plug-in buds, everything works just fine.
TOO DAMN SMALL. Sure it's convenient for the ear, but trying to handle them like putting in or taking out, better be sure to do it somewhere safe in case you drop them (not outside for sure). It would be better if they had over the year clips or something.
COLLECTS all your EAR-WAX. Yes, these things go in so deep that it just gets absolutely gross (never had this problem with other buds and I clean my ears every day)

title: Dekoni Audio Memory Foam Replacement Ear Pads Compatible with Sennheiser HD800 and HD800S Headphones (Elite Velour)
features: Designed and Tuned for the Sennheiser HD800 and HD800S

reviews.title: Comfortable fit
reviews.text:
They snap on easily. They are a little too thick for my taste though. You almost forget you're wearing the HD800's with the stock ear pads because of how light and thin they are. With the Dekoni's you've got memory foam cushions pushing on the sides of your head the entire time, reminding you of the giant cans on your head. They are even thicker than the pads on my HD820's. Price is a little steep but only $5 more than stock pads.

The materials feel like nice quality, similar to my HD820's. They're just not as comfortable though, in the sense that you don't forget you're wearing them like you do with the stock pads. If you have the patience, I think it's better to order genuine replacement pads from SoundSpares and just wait for them to ship from the UK. Considering the stock pads are about the same price, I think they're the better option.

reviews.title: Comfortable, not a fan of how the sound changes
reviews.text:
More comfortable than the OEM pads. Does changes the soundstage a bit while also changing the sound signature. I do notice the increase in sub-bass and increased midrange as stated in the description of these pads, but not sure if I like the trade-off of a reduced soundstage. For me, the reduced soundstage makes it sounds a bit muffled, and since I like the clear/clean sound of the basic earpads I'm not really a fan of the changes. But I guess if you want to change the sound of your hd800 then it could be good.

[EDIT] I chose to cut off the cover of the pads and used the base HD800 covers instead. I actually like it more. I wouldn't recommend others to cut their pads though as it's irreversible.

reviews.title: A no-brainer improvement for the HD800
reviews.text:
These replace the foam ear pads from your Sennheiser HD800 phones - and they're an obvious purchase for fans of these headphones. It comes delivered in a protective, flip-open box, and the pads themselves are soft and comfortable. It's every bit as nice-fitting as the original pads. But most users will probably need to do a few things to perfect the sound.

1. Adjust the EQ. If you use an HD800, you probably use either an amp or some kind of EQ setup. When you use these pads the first time, you may notice that certain music is too bassy, or has too much treble. You can easily change the sound signature by playing around with the EQ. You'll find that the bass has more presence with the Dekoni pads, but I didn't notice much change with the treble. If, however, you don't use an amp or adjust the EQ, the sound will sound better with the stock Sennheiser pads.

2. The "sticking point." Sennheiser's stock pads are soft and resilient, and designed especially for the HD800. The Dekoni pads sound equally good, but some might find the sheepskin a little "tacky" at first. (I got used to it pretty quickly.) Also, the Dekoni pads are notably more warm-feeling than the stock pads. If either of these are a problem for you, you can upgrade to the Dekoni "fenestrated" pads - or just use the Sennheiser pads.

3. Looks. No question, the leather pads are notably attractive - a real improvement over stock.

4. Installation. While Dekoni includes a plastic tool to help pry the pads, you would be well advised to watch a few videos beforehand. Dekoni didn't include an installation guide.

These pads are a no-brainer improvement over stock.

title: Monolith M1060C Closed Back Planar Magnetic Over-Ear Headphones, Low Distortion And Perfectly Balanced Sound
description: The Monolith M1060C planar headphones are the perfect way to experience your music collection. The M1060C features a completely redesigned and engineered planar driver, producing a detailed aural landscape in a closed back enclosure. Spectacular imaging, low distortion, and perfectly balanced sound make the Monolith M1060C a true audiophile listening experience.
features: Planar Drivers: Not your typical headphone driver! The planar driver in the M1060C has been completely redesigned and engineered versus the driver found in the M1060.
Several enhancements have been made, including a new symmetrical magnet structure that allows the planar driver to be much more efficient in a closed back enclosure.

Closed Back Design: Outside noise stays out and only the music stays in! The 1060C delivers excellent audio isolation, allowing the sonic landscape to not be disturbed by the outside world, and the outside to not be disturbed by your music.
This makes the M1060C the perfect audiophile choice for those that may need to listen in less than silent environments.

Comfort: The Monolith M1060C has been engineered to be comfortable for extended listening sessions. Large, comfy earpads made of faux leather and a padded headband are designed to keep you comfortable as you listen.

reviews.title: These sound pretty great, if you get lucky
reviews.text:
I got the m1060c.
I got lucky, my pair was good. I didn't have 5k ring.
Frequency response is kinda flat though, so if you're into that, go for it. I found other, supposedly lesser, headphones more fun.
The base is deep, but not overwhelming .. and goes on for miles.
Mids are pretty good, though I like them being more forward.
Highs are clear and nice.
Construction is kinda meh, but solid enough to last a few years, but not sure beyond that.
The headband is kinda silly and cheapo.
Pads .. I found them exceptionally comfortable, but your mileage will vary.
Cable is nice though!
Quite hefty as a headphone.
They aren't exactly closed, or at least not very good at isolation.
Respond well to EQ, seem to have plenty of tunability.

Recommended if you like it flatish and want to try a planar.

reviews.title: I liked them
reviews.text:
They were decent with an amp, without they sounded a little thin. Weight was around 580 grams without the cord.
I opened the box and it looked like lots of spots inside, I thought it was a return and maybe someone sprayed something inside of it. Amazon sent me another pair but that box also had spots but less. I shined a dark light on it and this is what I observed. Maybe mildew, I don't know. 3 1/2 - 4 stars, could be a 5 star, they do feel very good and this is comparing them to the Mr Speaker Aeon Flow closed backs.

Pros
Really nice Bass
Sounded good for gaming very good imaging
Very comfortable deep pads

Cons
Maybe weight
Too bright for me

reviews.title: Great sounding Cans, though build quality is less than spectacular
reviews.text:
Love the wonderful sound of these cans however, some things to note before purchase:

1) Very Heavy (Probably the heaviest I've ever worn.
2) Cups swivel 360 degrees. This can tangle the wires easily if you are not careful.
3) Mine came with a defective cable with an intermittent right side connection. I've requested a replacement. Discovered that the only ones making a replacement for this is Monoprice .. Though they do offer an upgrade cable for around $35.00 that looks far more substantial.
4) Wood ear cups are stained very dark (walnut color). So much so that you cant really tell there is a beautiful zebra wood pattern. Would suggest that manufacturer offer non-stained version.
5) Metal frame is a little unwieldy (read large ) and somewhat flimsy. A new frame design should be considered.

All that said, they sound wonderful , so the other faults must be taken into consideration along with their reasonable price.

reviews.title: Great sound
reviews.text: The headband is an abomination. It hurt my head within 15 minutes of wearing.  The reason  I'm keeping it is because of how good it sounds. It's been the best closed backs I've tried, compared to some of the best rated ones like the dt177x go. I order a zmf pilot pad to fix the headband issue. All in all this headphone delivers a well detailed performance,  and if you can get past the comfort issue, you're in for a treat.

reviews.title: Versatile
reviews.text:
Yes. Versatile. These come from the factory as closed headphones and sound good in their stock form but where they really shine is if you convert them to open back headphones. You can google "1060C open mod" and you'll find a couple different companies selling the plates to mod these to open. The driver was designed for an open back headphone, so that is why they sound better when you open them up. There are ways to leave the wood cups on and turn them into a semi-open headphone as well and that will give you the benefit of improved SQ with a little less sound leakage but I think it's best to just switch between closed and open. Anyway, I've really enjoyed having the ability to switch from open or closed depending on the environment I'm in. Super useful. That said, I probably won't be taking these to the coffee shop with me, they're a bit too heavy for that.

As far as the headband is concerned, the other reviewers griping about it are correct, it sucks. However, I don't think it's bad as some of them have made out. Maybe it just works with my head shape but I've worn them for several hours at a time without any issues. I plan on getting the ZMF Pilot Pad ($30) and I've read that that basically solves any comfort issues with these.

The cable looks and feels just fine but beware that it is a little microphonic. I ended up buying a replacement for $17 on Amazon and that solved the problem.

All in all, I think these are great headphones. There are a couple of issues but they're solvable and once you solve them (ZMF Pilot Pad + new cable), they are outstanding in both their sound and comfort.

reviews.title: Good value for the price
reviews.text:
First I like sound! I'm an audiophile at heart but in my life now I'm an audiophile on a BUDGET! These are my first bluetooth speakers. More on that in a minute.

I was looking for on ear bluetooth speakers with a budget of about $50 to $60 and was set on waiting for a sale on the JBL EB45T but then saw these recommended on the wirecutter website (a pretty good review site in my opinion)

There is nothing wrong with these, but nothing really right about them either. They have a nice neutral sound that you can listen to for a long time. For movies and youtube on my computer, they are great. But there is nothing in the sound that is going to wow you either. Trust me if there was something actually wrong with the sound, I'd be telling you. You can listen to these for a long time without ear fatigue. If you are looking for lots of rumble for movies, these probably aren't the right phones for you. But if your movie listening requirements are more modest then these work well for that. For casual background music, podcasts, audiobooks, they will work really well for that.

Isolation is not great. I think the plastic is thin so a certain amount of noise gets in. I wanted to be able to hear a little bit of background noise, things going on in the house, but these push my limit for how much I want to hear. Even though they were open-back my Sennheiser HD-229 did a better job with isolation because of the design of the pad.

Comfort isn't bad and for my ears, the ear cup size is just about right size. I wish the earpieces swiveled a bit more but for my head, they swivel just enough. . They have a left and right and the cups swivel so little that if you have them on the wrong way you will notice.

Bluetooth... These are a pain in the backside on Win 7. When I want to use them I have to go and delete the previous pairing, pair them again and then go to the control panel and set these to be used for output. For movies on the computer, they get out of sync. I even set my movie player (Pot Player which I highly recommend) to use the Bluetooth headphones and they still get out of sync with the audio. I don't know if it's the player, the USB Bluetooth adapter, Windows 7 or some combination of them together.

I like that they can be used with a wire as well as with bluetooth. The controls are a little small, as mentioned by others but I don't have trouble working them.

I also tried the JBL EB45T Bluetooth headphones, which cost almost twice as much, at Target and these sound better overall. The JBL might have had better highs, a little punchier bass but these are more cohesive across the frequency range with nothing tweaked to make them sound 'better'.

Summary: I don't have any other Bluetooth headphones to compare these to but I think most people would be very satisfied with these at this price point for general use. If however, you are looking for audiophile on a budget, it's not here.

reviews.title: Sound Profile is Very Good, ANC is Ok
reviews.text:
My experience with JVC up to this point has been with video equipment and televisions. My experiences have been positive so I hoped that this would be a good set of Active Noise Canceling (ANC) phones. I have worked with a lot of ANC phones – Bose, Sennheiser, Sony, Philips and more. Almost every set I have used has had some flaw, either in the ANC or in the sound profile. These JVC phones are interesting in that regard. The sound profile is nearly spot on, but the ANC is on the conservative side.

I’ll go over the ANC first. This is not a real competitor for the high end Sony or Bose sets and if the main thing you want from a set of ANC phones is noise elimination then these are far from the strongest or most aggressive. I have a fan that I use as the main test for ANC phones, and with the most aggressive phones the fan is almost completely wiped out. The JVC phones do cancel a good bit of noise, but it leaves a good bit of sound behind that Bose in particular eliminates. Now, that said, ANC headphones that can cancel more than these are almost universally much more expensive, often by double the price. These are what can probably be called “good enough for most”. For me, I like a more aggressive headphone, but these cancel enough ambient noise that when I am listening to music I don’t hear much else.

Many ANC phones fiddle with the sound profile to compensate for some of the lost frequency response, usually in the bass range and at the expense of the midrange. These phones are very unusual in that they don’t really seem to impact the sound profile much at all. And, the sound is very balanced. The bass is good, not overdriven (if you have ever used Dre Beats or Monster phones, you know exactly what I’m talking about). The midrange is warm and music sounds like it has the right depth as a result. The highs are clear and vocals sound very clean. The sound profile does not seem to be different between when the ANC function is on or off, though turning on the ANC does enhance the volume (which you can observe by having the headphones off when you activate the ANC in the middle of playback.

The ear cups are comfortable and I can wear these for a while before I need to take them off for comfort reasons. They don’t seem to get too warm when wearing for a while which is good. They’re not the most comfortable phones I have used, but they are better than many.

They connect via Bluetooth and I had no issues pairing and connecting them to my phone.

My favorite feature is that there is an independent volume control on the headphones themselves that does not change the volume setting on the source device. This is a feature that is a bit unusual; often, when the phones have a volume control on them it impacts the system volume when adjusted.

So, there is one thing about these phones that I think needs some improvement. Included with them is a cloth bag for protection, and that’s just not going to cut it, particularly in this price range. A bag prevents the contents from getting dirty but provides no damage protection. For the asking price (presently $149) these should have a hard case that at a minimum provides crush resistance.

I am very pleased with these headphones, more than I expected to be. They sound great, though the ANC is passable. My biggest issue isn’t with the phones themselves but with the lack of a suitable protective case. Hopefully JVC will resolve that issue in the near future. If you want a good set of ANC phones without spending north of $300, these are worth a look.

reviews.title: Comfortable, noise cancellation actually works well.
reviews.text:
I have a very good pair of Bluetooth Sony earphones with pretty good noise cancellation, but I wanted a second set that could be used with a regular 3mm plug with my phone. Traveling brings enough aggravation without worrying about battery life on one more gadget.

These are very comfortable on the ears for an hour or two while listening to an audio book and my ears don't get hot. These are light enough not to cause cauliflower ear either. I tested the noise cancellation feature both at home with the tv and in a semi truck idling. Those trucks are pretty quiet inside compared to standing next to one outside, but the noise is still there and it impedes sleep if you're not used to it. I'm pretty pleased with how well these block external noise - it's an absolute difference and a little better than my Sonys.

Music is a pleasure with these also. There are adjustments to increase bass etc if you're so inclined. My primary use though is audio books. The full production Audible Originals with a full cast and sound effects are especially nice with these headphones - you can hear the background noises and details clearly and not the dog barking next door. I find myself reaching for these almost every day lately.

reviews.title: Better than my beloved Bose QuietComfort 35 (Series I)
reviews.text:
Yes, my Bose is a a couple years old, but it cost twice as much as this JVC unit, and Bose has a nice hard shell case, but this JVC works great. It comes with a nylon mesh storage pouch with drawstring, 3.5 mm cord (great for in-seat entertainment on newer jets), and (short) charging USB cord. It arrived too late for a recent flight to LA, but sitting in the kitchen with a 20 year old refrigerator running, and a central air conditioner running that sounds similar to a 737, I put these JVC headhones on, turned on the Noise Cancelling, and ... virtual silence! Word of warning for those new to noise-cancelling headphones, they won't be miracle workers in "open office" or cubicle workplaces, but will help reduce that type of noise a bit. Huge bonus: if using just the noise cancelling (NC) features and not the music/BT feature, 35+ hour battery life is claimed. Even with NC and BT, 16 hours is claimed.

Next step: Add some music! Listened to some music and turned the NC on and off, and back, and could hardly notice ANY loss of music fidelity and tonal range. Some cheap NC headphone tend to just clip certain frequencies.

Nice and comfortable. Over the ear design is the only way to go.

Easy to pair; you can use the standard pairing, or if your phone have NFC, you can open your BT settings page, and tap your phone on the "N" NFC logo on the left earpiece, and a pop-up asks if you want to pair to the JVC. Yes, I did. No more scrolling through a long list of BT devices available (wretched Tile and air furnace filters, my Bose that shows up as a "Zebra Machine", etc.)

And yes, in BT mode, these have a microphone so you can take and make phone calls. Microphone quality is okay, not great. There are controls on the headset to increase volume, lower volume, switch to next track, previous track, accept phone calls, etc.

So if a mesh bag and so-so microphone quality are good with you, these are a great choice.

reviews.title: JVC suprised me
reviews.text:
This is my first pair of JVC, as I have been using Beats headphones for many years, and BOSE portable speakers. I have to admit that I've always passed up JVC thinking that it was my grandfather's brand and that Beats must be better because their more modern, boy was I mistaken.

If there is one thing I appreciate is really good LOUD and clear music. I want to hear the producer coughing in the background when I sit down to listen. These headphones provide me with that level of sound. What's more (and even better) is that other people can't tell how loud my phones are. With the Beats, I would sometimes get double-takes at the gym if someone can hear my music. Not because of the genre but because of how loud they are. With these, no one can hear my music. Mine all mine, and I'm not forced to share my playlist with the guy on the decline bench next to me.

The noise cancellation is better than Beats. If someone is next to me and talking directly to me, then I can hear muffled sounds but not actual syllables and words. But far away noises are just actions in silence, gosh that's perfection.

I have those miniature cloth shower-cap thingies to put on the phones to keep them from getting icky but I don't think these will be for the gym. I think these will be after-work, cognac and cigar phones to listen to the classics. Nice.

reviews.title: I'm not keen on the cover material
reviews.text:
While the Arae Electronic Organizer does what it says, its implementation isn't great.

The double layers of this product has one and a half flap of elastic bands to hold bundled up wires, that's 18 spots total. The rest are two large pockets and a small pocket. That's plenty of room to carry most charging accessories that you'd have with you if you were equipped with tablets and phones. For laptops and cameras, you'll need other solutions. Even action camera chargers may have a hard time fitting in this slim product.

It's not a problem that this thing is pretty much made out of nylon from the outside in but the material that makes up the exterior of this product makes it look cheap. It's a rough, synthetic material that just makes it a bit cheap looking. I think cloth or leather would have been a better choice.

In addition, the zipper sticks, making it hard to quickly open this up to retrieve your wires for charging.

reviews.title: Case closed
reviews.text:
It's pretty amazing how much this will hold and still close up properly. I am using it for many cables and some adapters, and I am also keeping those little instruction manuals that come with everything in one of the zipper pouches. reviews.title: Comfort!
reviews.text: So the sound quality is good, battery life is good but for me the most important point is they are comfortable. I've been through a LOT of ear buds in search of something that I can wear for several hours without my ears starting to hurt and these are them! Charging case doesn't feel very substantial, but since I don't need to charge them every couple of hours I can live with it.

reviews.title: Interesting app
reviews.text: I've been using these earbuds for several weeks now, and they're as good as any pair I have. And I have several. They connect without issue and have good, clear sound. If you're looking for the intricasies of fine tuning, how good is the base and all that, I'm not the gal for you. However, I think music sounds great, and they're perfect for listening to YouTube vids on my computer and audio books on my phone. The app is interesting. At first I thought I could talk directly to my buds. "Hey, Skullcandy!" (First earbuds I've had with voice control.) But you have to use the app for that feature. Not quite as convenient in my opinion, although perhaps I was expecting too much. The controls are not touch, but require clicking on the individual buds to control them. You can also control them through the app, though. Instructions are clear and easy to understand. I was up and running in minutes. All in all, I think they are excellent and definitely worth the price tag.

Product Description
Push your workout to the limit with headphones that are up to the task. Bose SIE2i sport headphones, customized for select Apple devices, are specifically engineered for exercise. They're sweat- and weather-resistant, stay comfortably yet securely in place and deliver robust Bose sound to keep you energized - a combination of benefits conventional sport ear buds can't match. Plus, the inline remote and microphone let you control music on your iPhone or iPod and take calls with one-touch ease.

Energizing sound. Bold style.
Exclusive TriPort headphone technology delivers wide-range sound, including the deep, convincing lows that give your music—and your workout—its pulse. And because it comes from an in-ear headphone, you'll feel driven without feeling closed off from your environment—a must when you're running outdoors. These headphones can add extra punch to your exercise routine.
Stability and durability
Our StayHear tips conform securely and comfortably to your ears' shape, even during vigorous workouts. The speaker elements are covered with hydrophobic cloth that keeps moisture out but lets sound pass through. Cables and connections are made extra sturdy. SIE2i sport headphones are made for motion. Even their bold colors (Green, Orange, Blue, Purple) have an energy all their own.
One-touch ease for music and calls
SIE2i sport headphones have an inline remote that offers convenient control over the music on your iPod or iPhone. Skip a tune with the press of a button. No need to touch your device—a great feature for running. There's also an inline microphone for taking calls and switching seamlessly between calls and music.
StayHear tips come in 3 sizes (S, M, L)
Reebok fitness armband
There's another great workout feature—the exclusive Reebok armband. It holds your music device in place when you're exercising, and stores the headphones when you're not. It even has a separate pocket for your keys. It's made of stretchy, breathable fabric that adjusts to fit most smartphones and MP3 players, and has a touch-sensitive window for easy usability. Available in colors to match your SIE2i sport headphones.

reviews.title: Best headphones I have ever had
reviews.text: With Bose, you never have to worry about the sound quality.  It is excellent as usual.  The 3 different sized of ear pieces provided allow for a personalized fit.  They stay in place during all sorts of activities (running, yard work, etc..) and the soft earpieces are very comfortable.  The cord is split into 2 pieces which can be very convenient at times.  Without the extension, it works perfectly for an arm/exercise band.  With the extension, you can stick the phone in your pocket, backpack, etc..  and have some cord to spare.  The connection between the extension and the main cord is large and will make the cord feel heavy at times.  My ONLY complaint is that the cord is made of a very "rubbery" material and it tends to catch on itself (if you wind it up when not in use, it is a little tough to untangle it).  Other than that, I love these headphones.  I liked mine so much, I bought a second pair for my wife, who uses them regularly as well.  HIGHLY recommended.

reviews.title: Five Stars
reviews.text: Very comfortably for running in.  Can hardly feel them.  I like how you can still hear things around you.

reviews.title: Bose sport headphones
reviews.text:
Fantastic Bose sound.
The assortment of earpieces fit with no problem and the additional stabilizers don't allow the earbuds to fall out! even when on the elliptical trainer.
A great deal. Highly recommended.

reviews.title: Favorite running headphone, worth the splurge.
reviews.text: I've had these headphones for over 2 years with no complaints. I used to go through headphones on a monthly basis, but Bose provided me with the quality and durability I was looking for with sport headphones. I one time accidentally put these headphones in the washer and dryer, because they were left in my pocket, and they still work with no defects. (Sweat-proof and maybe even waterproof) They are great for staying safe while running or biking outdoors, while still providing excellent Bose sound quality. I like the interchangeable earpieces for the perfect fit and comfort while running. There is no need to readjust or worry about the earpieces falling out or getting yanked out. The versatile cord length was a bonus for less cord hassle, but if this product were to be upgraded I might suggest a flat cord for less tangle during storage.

reviews.title: Great in ear head phones.
reviews.text: Use almost daily with iPhone. Good sound, good quality very water resistant. The extension cable is a nice touch. You won't be disappointed. NO heavy Bass, just crystal clear music.

reviews.title: [review for non ANC version] Pretty good deal for it's money
reviews.text:
I lost accurate track of time, but it was definitely more than 60hr of battery life. very impressive, a little scary to carry this much power on my head, but logically I understand that risks of catching fire or batteries exploding is negligible)

* sound quality - awesome (in terms of sound itself)
* build and material quality - impressive
* bluetooth connectivity - awesome. range, stability, reconnect speed, sound quality (in terms of losses via bluetooth while in varying range of "hotspot with music").
* battery quality - a little bit over a week of daily uses for 8hr+ a day. just perfect. That will be enough for a business trip out of town for a couple of days and back without need to recharge and sometimes even without prior notice to recharge before I go.
* distinct controls (bumps with space between them) - awesome. easy to use, easy to locate, no mistakes)
* folding capabilities - they do fold/unfold, but I tried it only once upon unpacking, but I rarely use this feature

The only minus that I can see in the last 20 days is how the headband is stretching when I'm wearing headphones. Looks dangerous (in terms of longevity). That's all I think. If this headphones will last more than a year I would call them perfect for a price and capabilities (tiny note about non ANC version and that's it)

So final score (while they last) 10/10

reviews.title: Very Good Portable CD Player With Plenty of Options
reviews.text:
With the onset of Pandora, satellite radio and many other such options, I found I wasn’t playing my CDs anymore. In fact, I couldn’t find my CD player! And the high-end system in my truck doesn’t even have a CD option. So when I saw this I figured I give it a try. I like that it’s portable and plays without skipping even when bumped, running with it, or the dog knocking it off of the table. It can be used with my several different sets of earphones. It also plugs into my truck stereo without a problem.

I also wanted it to play through its own speaker while in my crafts room. This is where the 5th star gets removed. When turning it up nearly all the way the speaker starts to buzz on certain notes. It isn’t loud at all on its own either so using it without auxiliary speakers is not good if more than about 8 feet from it. However, I am playing my CDs which I have not heard in years, and that makes me very happy.

reviews.title: The Moondrop Chu is dead. Long live the new king.
reviews.text:
Well the Moondrop Chu's reign didn't last long. These WILDLY outclass everything under $50. They wildly outclass a lot of stuff under $200.

For starters, detachable cable. I hate the fixed cable on the moondrop chu's with a passion - it's all silicone rubbery and tangles, doesn't stay in place, doesn't stay tied up in your pocket or backpack. The chu's come with a microphone, which is the only thing it has going for it, but if you REALLY need a cable, these are still a far better deal with another $10 spent on the cable. This cable is nice, comfortable, wraps up easily around 3-4 fingers and stays coiled properly.

Then, eartips. The Chu's "springtips" don't really fit quite a few people, myself included. They were so bad that the chu's sounded downright broken until I got some better tips on them. The Zero's come with about five different size of tips that were no problem to find a comfortable seal/fit.

Comfort and build wise, they're awesome. My ears can be quite picky, and they basically disappear in your head. They're light and smooth plastic, with a nice stainless steel plate on the outside. No complaints, they just work perfectly as IEM's and feel plenty durable to just live in your backpack.

Sound wise, these things really up the game. The Chu's have excellent technical performance (detail is great) but they're downright claustrophobic. It feels like every instrument in the band is licking the inside of your ear. And it's unpleasant. They're tuned quite neutral, but with no sense of space, instrument separation or imaging (that sense of more than left/right, but front/back and in between) they're just not a pleasant sound. The Zero's have IMPRESSIVE separation and imaging. Not impressive at $20. Impressive for IEM's, period. There's $300-500 stuff that doesn't do imaging and soundstage this well.

The bass could be cleaner and it doesn't quite hit the detail of the chu's (which are also punching well into the $500 range in that one specific area) but I'm nitpicking HARD. For $20, these have no right sounding so spacious, detailed (you can enjoy the detail a lot more when the instruments don't feel all laid on top of each other) and pleasant. They're not overly bassy, but they are thumpier than the chu's. No overly sparkly either. Just a very "grown up" tuning meant to make music sound nice, paired with truly outstanding soundstage.

If you play video games, there's nothing anywhere near these in the price range. You'll hear sounds ahead, behind, and how far away they are.

Songs with real detail and separation will dance around you (Bobby McFerrin, Polyphia) and show you things you didn't even know were in your music.

The only next step up I can think of from these is the $50 Truthear zero's (same model name, different brand) but they're only marginally better (with a slightly worse fit) and the $100 7hz diokos are a very noticeable step up in every way. But jeez. These things are $20. I don't understand how they're so good for that little money.

Anyone else entering the $20-$50 space better bring their A+ game. These are a tough act to follow. If you really need a microphone, these are still unbeatable with another $10-15 for a cable with one.

reviews.title: Fantastic First IEM w/ Insane Value
reviews.text:
These were my first entry into IEMs and I really enjoyed the experience. Coming from Google Pixel Buds Pros, these were a significant improvement in sound quality but given the abundance of excellent budget headphones in the chi-fi market, I can't comment as to whether they're better than any of the others you'd find for a similar price.

I also really like the USB-C 2-pin cable that it comes with. It has a subtler finish compared to twisted cables and it also has a built-in mic that works well enough for calls. I actually bought a higher end set of IEMS and ended up using the Salnotes' cable since similar cables cost 1-2x the price of the Salnotes themselves.

I first noticed it wouldn’t regularly connect to my monitor via the HDMI port, then it began failing to connect all together. reviews.title: I wanted to love this,
reviews.text: I got this for my new iPad. It’s supposed to let you use wired headphones, SIM cards, and even hdmi.  And it does.  It’s a bit cumbersome to use but it does sit on the corner of my iPad even with the iPad cover on.  The big issue i have with it is that it does get hot, VERY HOT, while you’re using it for a longer period of time.  I don’t use it often due to that but i got it at a good price so I’ll keep it.

reviews.title: So far it works as advertised!  Gets alarmingly HOT.. concerned about longevity..
reviews.text:
update::: I've been having issues with connecting this hub to a capture device. it will constantly disconnect and reconnect. I purchased an hdmi splitter that has it's own power source (micro usb) and I connect it with the ipad and the capture device. It's like a middle man... and now the this hub stops disconnecting and reconnecting. It's very odd. Also, connecting power via the USB C port, on the hub, does not help. It's also not a heat issue because I bought a mini fan to blow on it and it's never hot. However, it doesn't disconnect and reconnect when directly connected to a monitor/tv.. it works fine then.

in addition to that issue, I had to get a replacement and noticed that both hubs displayed different color profiles. Using the same monitor, cables, ipad, etc. One was sort of washed out and one was very saturated. Also one wouldn't display 4k (only 2k) and the other one would display 4k, 2k, 1080p, etc. Not really sure why there would be so much variance with the same product.. I guess QC issues?

-----------------------------------

This is the "UPGRADED" version.

So far it works as advertised! Gets alarmingly HOT.. concerned about longevity of the hub itself and concerned about potential damage this could do to my iPad...

This product advertises "Heat vents" but they're just cutouts for the ipad's speakers.. it doesn't actually vent the inside of the hub. This seems deceptive.

I've tried those $20-30 cheap usb c to hdmi + charging port options and they all didn't work properly... mostly they wouldn't actually charge the ipad while outputting the HDMI signal.
This device actually DOES charge while outputting the HDMI signal properly.. which is great.
The audio port works fine, but I have not used the USB ports as I don't really have any use for them at the moment. I mostly needed hdmi output and a charging port that actually charged while hdmi was being used.

I love how the company included 3 different sized spacers to accommodate for ipad's with cases.

The switch to disable the hub is a nice feature. BUT I wish you could disable the charging while still being able to use the HDMI out... so if this switch instead only disabled the charging capabilities but still retained the ability to output video/audio via the HDMI output, that would be, imo, better. Then when the ipad's own battery gets low.. I could flip the switch and allow the hub to start charging. Obviously I can just unplug the USB C charging cable from the hub, but it would be a QoL feature to not have to do that.

I like how it has a long-ish cable instead of just having the usb port extend out of the actual hub body.. this makes it much more versatile, imo.

My biggest concern is how long this product will last due to how HOT it gets while using the HDMI out and charging the ipad at the same time. This is the only time the hub gets alarmingly HOT.. when one is using the HDMI out AND charging at the same time. One could argue that because it's so hot to the touch, that means the passive cooling, inside the hub, is doing its job.. but I don't know if that's actually the case w/o seeing the internals and seeing what kind of heatsinks or w/e are being used. All I know is that this hub gets VERY VERY HOT and devices that overheat tend to stop working sooner than later.

Overall I think this is one of the better options available for 30-50$. The versatility of attaching to the ipad or have it hanging is a huge plus for me.

reviews.title: Convenient & Useful iPad adapter
reviews.text:
So far the only bummer is it’s not really screen protector friendly. I used the thinnest insert because without one it won’t stay in place.

It’s a bit too snug to put on an iPad 11 with a screen protector. The edge of the protector kinda bubbles up. I’ll have to try a few thin cases and not use the inserts to this adapter. That would be more beneficial anyways.

One thing I did notice about the charging port is it’s a bit loose. So you may need to get new cables or try different brands. I have several brands/styles and some do better than others. The Apple cables seem to fit fairly snug though.

Other than that it works as stated. I do like it and it’s more low profile compared to others. All of the ports work especially for charging multiple devices. I use 30w+ for my iPad because I tend to use adapters often. 30w brick & adapter loaded still charged iPad under use.

The adapter looks nice as well. A bit thick but not to the point it’s an issue using it. I have the model with the on/off switch. That’s convenient while otg, in case you need to cut power from the adapter to save the battery from draining.

The adapter doesn’t seem to take a ton of power but if you don’t need it on while away from a power source I’d say just flip it off.

Overall I like this adapter it’s nice & convenient. Like I said my biggest gripe was not really screen protector friendly (iPad w/out a case only screen protector) but it’s not a deal breaker. I’d recommend trying this out!

features: True Quiet in a Small Package: We put 1MORE’s proprietary QuietMax active noise cancellation technology into the compact body of the ComfoBuds Mini to provide true quiet. With up to 40dB noise cancellation depth, you can get a more immersive listening experience. And the earbuds allow you to switch between multiple listening modes to fit different scenarios.

reviews.title: Mini, but Mighty
reviews.text:
Look, we know you aren't here for premium sound quality if you're looking at the tiniest earbuds and in this price range. That being said, these do still sound quite nice! There's a lot of oomph for such a small package. Unless you're used to professional grade sound equipment, these will cover most anyone's sound needs.

SMALL EAR HAVERS! I have been on a quest to find comfy earbuds. So far, these have come the closest. I can wear them for like 2 hours with minimal discomfort. This is a huge upgrade from "most cause physical pain near immediately". When placed correctly, they're pretty solid. I couldn't shake them out. They did come loose a handful of times and needed to be readjusted, but in comparison to the others needing that every 5 minutes? I'll take it.

They say they have ANC, but honestly, I'm not so sure. In my personal experience, turning ANC on didn't actually cancel any noise. It just brought the bass out. Unless I just can't get the right fit, the ANC mode is effectively just a "make the music sound better" button.

The drawback here is that you can only use ANC if both buds are in. Not usually a problem, unless you want to pop one in to listen to music and leave the other ear open for communication. The make the music sound better button won't do anything with just one bud.

reviews.title: Basically perfect, fantastic wind ANC, perfect case
reviews.text:
I needed a replacement for my Galaxy buds pro's that have the fatal ANC "roar in one ear" that Samsung won't fix, and they don't stay in the ear. Bring an absolutely ENORMOUS fan of the 1more comfobuds z (the single best sleep focused earbuds at any price) I liked that these are also small, the case shape is wonderful (flip top, tiny, wireless charger) and they're relatively inexpensive.

The sound quality uses 1more's app to do a "sounds" hearing preference test. I would prefer a proper EQ option but it works well enough. I prefer real audiophile iem's and headphones, but enjoyed the Galaxy buds on bass boost, they almost hit like planar magnetics. These are about 80% there. They're totally serviceable, with the only standout being a pretty good technical performance, with genuinely solid imaging and separation. They absolutely do need the soundID set up though, I hate the stock tuning. For tiny little things they are, I am perfectly happy with the sound quality when I want music on my bike or public transit.

The ANC is stellar. They have a specific mode for wind reduction that downright curbstomps Samsung and apple. If you ride a bike, you need 1more ANC buds. The transparency mode is great too, very natural sounding. It doesn't have that "talk and it switches to transparency" gimmick, but I found it obnoxious on Samsung.

Touch controls are easily customized and no "single touch" feature means you don't accidentally press anything readjusting or putting them in. Auto pauses when you take one out, your can use just one or the other no problem

The app features depend on the product but these are meant to be usable for sleeping, do they come preloaded with a library of sleep/ambient sounds. I just use my own but it's a nice feature. I can easily fall asleep with them in and I'm a very picky side sleeper, but I do prefer the absolutely microscopic comfobuds z's.

The stock eartips did bother me a bit, they have a little ridge from the mold that irritated my ears after a few hours of use. They have a very odd mounting system that I was only able to find one option for, spinfit 1025 tips are shallow enough to fit and still let the case close (the wells for the eartips is a bit to shallow, id like it if they addressed this on a revision) so if you don't like the tips, spinfit 1025's.

The case magnets that hold the buds in are hilariously strong. Your have to SMACK it to dislodge them. Very nice detail. The case size is tiny and perfectly shaped to slide into pockets, with a flip top that you can open one handed

For being so small they also stay put well. Not perfect, but I can work out or mow the lawn, an impossible task of the Galaxy buds pro.

Overall though, these things rock. They're exactly what I need as a paramedic who also rides a bicycle. 1more is a serious brand with some seriously well thought out products at extremely competitive prices. I can sleep on my side with a podcast and still be able to wake up for a call, they crush wind nose when I'm riding my bike, they sound perfectly adequately tuned with impressive imaging (once you run the sound id feature once) and the case is (slightly too shallow recessions for the eartips aside) very nice in the hand and perfectly shaped.

Highly recommend.

I had higher expectations with them, knowing the brand. I thought they could be headphones I would like and trust to listen to music, and also being able to do exercises. I'm not 100% sure now, but I think I remember I couldn't keep them on while running and sweating.

reviews.title: Great Sound With Comfort And Stability
reviews.text:
This is an excellent set of Sports headphones that sounds great and stays put when you're getting your workout in. The headphones use a dual magnet, dynamic moving coil micro speaker to deliver a frequency response of 10HZ to 19kHz making them more than adequate for listening outside of the gym as well. While these headphones work with any device they are truly made for the Apple line of products (iPhone, iPad, iPod) as the control box gives you control over the volume, skip tracks and even take calls.

►► SOUND QUALITY ◄◄

The sound across the board is excellent from the low-end through the mid-range and high-end. They are not as open and airy as my Ultimate Ears TripleFi 10's, a set that listed for $399 retail, but they don't feel muted at all when listening to them.

Testing through a variety of music genres it would seem that these are tuned for the louder, upbeat music that you'd listen to while working out which makes sense since these are Sports headphones. With that said if I would have no problem listening to acoustic music through these as they product a nicely balanced, clean sound that is better than a lot of wired headsets I've tried. They are way better than the headphones included with my iPhone.

►► COMFORT ◄◄

For me comfort is just as important as sound quality because if your in-ear monitors aren't comfortable you won't want to wear them for extended periods of time. This set does a couple things right in the comfort arena with the design of the oval earbuds and the over the ear wire design that keeps the headphones in place and makes them feel as close to weightless as you can get.

I was a bit skeptical of the oval design of the earbuds as I am very used to the circular design and have been very happy with the Comply tips that I normally use. With that said the oval design here truly does seem to make a difference in the comfort of these tips as the included tips are more comfortable than most, if not all, of the standard tips I've had included in a set of headphones.

►► CONTROLS ◄◄

There is a small control box attached to the clip that you can use to keep the cord in place. The control box is very similar to those on other sets of headphones I have tested and it worked pretty much as expected except for the way you move up and down in the track list.

The top button on the control box is used to raise the volume on your device.

The bottom button on the control box is used to lower the volume on your device.

The center button is the most versatile as a quick click will play or pause your music or answer a call if the phone is ringing. A double tap of the center button will move to the next track in your track listing and a triple tap of the center button will move to the previous track. Pressing and holding the center button for a second will initiate Siri. While I am used to the volume buttons normally doubling up as the previous / next track control once I was used to this system it was a breeze to use.

►► PHONE CALLS ◄◄

The headset does a nice job with calls due to the fact that the microphone is nice and clear so there is no worries about taking a call while wearing these headphones.

►► CONCLUSION ◄◄

Overall this is an excellent set of Sports headphones that are both comfortable and sound great. They stay firmly in place and seem to be built to handle whatever wear and tear you will throw at them while working out. I love having full control over my iPhone with the included control. For me this is about as close to perfect as you can come with a Sports set of headphones. Highly recommended.

Sample provided for review.

reviews.title: Just right for me.
reviews.text: Diggin' these just fine. I can see how maybe people with tiny ears, or oddly shaped ears, might not have the right fit. Also, the portion in-ear is quite tiny, so there's not a huge amount of bass, but I still like the clarity, and there's enough adjustability to tailor the sound, even on my tiny Sandisc Mp3 player. What I like the most though, is the over the ear design, and I can have the wires feed out back out of my way. The portion in-ear, with the smallish oval tips, also makes me quite happy. So small, and un-noticeable, and comfortable, and they stay put till the end of my hike, or run, or skate, or whatever. The ones that came with the player sounded good too, but really annoying and would fall out when you get sweaty or turn your head. And I just didn't have a bunch of the new-style design to try out, with the horn on them that you rotate and lock into the ear. I read that those kind still fall out when sweaty and slippery anyway. (or you don't get the right fit). All problems solved with these sporty little guys. And Klipsch speakers and equipment have always impressed, so I'm glad I trusted my instincts...

reviews.title: A very minimal sleek case for the airPods Pro 2
reviews.text:
I have purchased this brand before for my apple watch series 6 titanium, Ive only had the shell for two days before it decided to walk away, or fell off and went byby. There was no adhesion to the watch and little effort will cause it to come off. Thank you guys for your concern about what we think about your product. Great customer service!

With that said, This case is no different with the top half, it will slip off with out you knowing.

They have no adhesive strips like others will include. I guess they have to high of confidence in their product. Nice as it is, I would expect more.

I have purchase thin strip double sided adhesive through amazon to have around when needed. This was no exception.

Now that I had to vent my concern with their product, I was prepared with handling this concern.

The bottom shell is no problem since the opening for the lanyard will secure the bottom shell, I have added a small strip of double sided adhesive to the sides of the top half shell.

These are the most minimal light weight hardshell cases you can buy, the look great and feel’s great and will take any reasonable
punishment you can give it and
protect what is important.

The packaging is nice, too nice, they could have spent less on the box and a little more on protecting the investment, like adhesive. They do have decals in a strip, if this was to prevent cases from slipping off, you could have fooled me. There was no instructions in the box on anything, 🤔.

Don’t let my concern detour you from making the investment.

reviews.title: Good sound quality
reviews.text:
These are good quality but my left ear is uncomfortable. My ear must be a different shape. I was hoping the battery life would be better, but its ok. I use it to listen to books while i work. Take calls when needed.
Most bluetooth headsets have a delay or echo. These do not. It makes phone calls very clear.
These are the best sound quality of all but my Dewalt headsets.
The battery lasts about 5 to 6 hours with my streaming usage. Probably last much longer with just calls.
My left ear hurts after a couple hours, but ny right ear is fine for all day.
They charge quickly about an hour maybe a little more.
DON'T MISPLACE THE CHARGING CASE they will become worthless. They can't be charged without it.
And it seems if they power off by themselves they have to be reset in the case.
All that being said i probably would buy them again.
