SWAPPABLE WRISTBANDS — If you have multiple bands, it's easy to change them in seconds to wear ScanWatch your way: leather, silicone or metal.

reviews.title: Absolutely stellar watch but battery life is meh for a hybrid
reviews.text:
Withings wearer for almost two years here. Have had the Scanwatch for a couple months and had the Steel HR before that.

First off, if you're reading the reviews you should definitely buy either this watch or the Steel HR. I absolutely love it. It's gorgeous, the app is great, it fits in well to daily life. Looks fantastic whether suited up or wearing grubbies to work on the car. My doctor even hooked up tri-leads to me to compare the ECG with actual medical equipment and they thought it was pretty darn close! Same with O2 sat monitor and heart rate. Quality wise, on par with its excellent forerunner, the Steel HR. The functional twisting crown with haptic feedback is a nicer touch than the push button on the old one.

I have to ding it on one star because of the battery life and charge time compared to the prior model. My Steel HR lasted for about a month with all features enabled and charged almost completely in the time it took to take a shower. This one lasts about five days with all features enabled (I know, there are more features). But the bigger problem is charge time. I take the watch off for showers and that's a logical time to charge (obviously you want to wear this in your sleep). About 30 minutes does not come anywhere near to fully charging the battery. Just now it only went from 30-40%. So you need to find time to charge it during the day or occasionally not wear it while sleeping. I think I'm going to disable some of the continuous monitoring features which puts me back at my Steel HR just with sleep disturbance monitoring and O2 sat on demand.

Ultimately, if you want activity tracking, heart rate monitoring, enhanced sleep monitoring, ECG and O2 sat WHILE still wearing an attractive watch, this is hard to beat. If you don't care about ECG, O2 and sleep disturbance tracking the Steel HR is the watch to get as it's more or less the same just without those features and is cheaper. As to whether the ScanWatch is with the extra money over the Steel HR, I think that depends on how much you prioritize those extra features and battery life. If this would last a week plus on a charge I'd say the extra hundred bucks is a no brainer. But battery life as it is... tougher call.

One other note. While this watch will give you notifications, they're a bit cumbersome on the small screen. I have it turned off.

reviews.title: Screen fogged up after only a few days
reviews.text: Was exited by this smart watch, look and capabilities. But within a few short days the screen had fogged up on the inside without having come near water in any way. Very disappointing.

reviews.title: Great watch! Battery myth...
reviews.text:
The best looking, excellent build quality, thoughtful app. Notification is done nicely.

Battery Myth:

My first green horizon watch battery is very bad the battery dropped 14% on day one. I tried Amazfit, and it only drops 5% a day. I tried to disable a lot of things and it became about 7-8% a day.

Second Blue horizon, more than 24 hours later, it still shows 100%. I could not believe it. Almost like I complained and they did something remotely and manipulated the battery meter... 😊

Sleep Track is nice and main reason I bought it.

reviews.title: great appearance, perfect for work
reviews.text: I love the product. The ease of use, it's intuitive nature. It looks like a regular watch-quite stylish in my opinion, but it functions like a smart watch but with just the essentials that I need. If you are regularly using the smart watch functions with blue tooth to your phone--the battery life is closer to two weeks than a month.

reviews.title: Update:  Watch cannot keep time!  Needs frequent adjustment Not trustworthy!
reviews.text:
Update: Watch now 10 months old and does not keep accurate time. Initially a couple months ago, I noticed the time difference and using instructions adjusted it, thinking it must have been an odd glitch. I am used to watches that rarely need to be adjusted and thought a Hybrid Smartwatch would be smart and never be off time. Boy was I wrong.

Since writing the original glowing review, last May 2022 which was two weeks after purchase. I have had to adjust the time several times. The first time it was off it was 12 minutes difference. Right now it is off 5 minutes. A couple weeks ago it was off 4 minutes. This is not an isolated incident. Interestingly, the hands do not match the digital time, but all the same, both are off. Right now the hands read exactly 4:30 while the digital is 4:31 even though the real time according to my computer and Samsung S21 phone is 4:36. This is really a shame given the watch cost $300. IMO, the watch is unusable if you cannot trust it for its most basic function.

I havent put it entirely through its paces. I noticed that it was registering nearly same heart rate as my fitbit sense. I havent it worn it long enough to determine blood oxygen. There is still a lot to learn. The learning curve feels a little clunky compared to my fitbit.

Has ability to connect to Alexa, take and make calls, music. Can make changes through app or scroll through the screen face.

The watch band fits my 7" wrist and feels comfortable enough. Typical silicone band. It is attached via pins, so I imagine it is possible to swap it out but not sure. I may try some old bands to see if it is doable. I'd also prefer for it to have a soft protective cover (bumper guard) to protect screen and edges.

I still prefer the ease of using a name brand, but this has a good looking interface. Main thing is to see how accurate it is. I think it has been fine for heart rate, steps, but will need more sleep time for seeing how well it tracks sleep and oxygen.

I dont rate on price, but I comment. This is pretty reasonable, but it looks like there are many similar products for less. So compared to a name brand of similar features this is a bargain. Compared to other no name generics, this is competitive. Some are easily $20 less. I noticed the price on this vacillates. I think I got it for $70, and have seen it as low as 35-40.

reviews.title: Best Wear OS for true Android users, but not perfect
reviews.text:
I will avoid the facts that this watch is outdated at launch by its hardware (processor). That, coupled with retail and even discounted price also are out of step with the competition. These two big gripes aside. The watch is good and likely the best choice going into 2023 for pure Android Wear OS users (not looking at Apple or Tizen overlay users.)

Its not perfect and Pixel users will benefit the most when paired to this watch. Its lost most of the lag recent watches from other Wear OS brands. Has all the sensors the majority of buyers could want based on watch tech right now. It swipes, it plays well with the apps made for it. It gives you the info you ask of it. There are even a few nice 3rd part accessories now to avoid Google Gouging for proprietary bands. And there are few quirks I hope they iron out soon. Mainly, when the phone is in Bedtime Mode. Make the watch do it too, or add that Zen Mode feature to the watch also. It sucks to have animals tripping the security cameras outside dinging on my wrist and killing my sleep score. The snooze/do not disturb button on watch fails too easily and you have turn it on/off manually everytime.

As many claim, the battery sucks. Sort of. I can go up to 36+ hours on a slow day, and many others can too. It will depend on too many factors to list. But basically your popularity with notifications and thinking you need the screen always on are the biggest battery hurdles. Most can get use to touch to wake. And maybe only having text, phone, front door doorbell and one email be allowed to bother your watch with notifications. Do you really need to know what cousin Billy had at Dairy Queen when he posts the same pic/vid on Facebook, Instagram, Tic Toc and YouTube, etc. Find a nice balance of wrist information along with what sensors you need checking if you are still alive. You can start the day and track everything till the next morning when you charge it again while you shower and get the next day started. It charges quickly. And most other Wear OS watches have the same daily charge requirements. Nobody on Wear OS is winning on battery. Or Turn every setting all the way up and have a spare charger puck ready for a mid day juice. If you go that route. I suggest a quick release band to ease the removal of the watch.

So, its not up to the level or price of the Ultra Apple Watch. And if you don't care for Samsung. Your love for stock Android will eventually lead you back to this watch. Unless you forgo ECG sensors. The price will drop soon. Cases are minimizing the fragility of an ALL glass jelly bean design. But when comes to keeping your phone pocketed and yet still have info relayed in a useful way. Pixel Watch is the best current albeit not perfect solution for now.

reviews.title: Look elsewhere unless you love charging
reviews.text:
I'll start with the pros because sadly there aren't many. It feels premium and I personally like the small footprint on my wrist as it's not heavy and is comfortable with the band it ships with. Everything else leaves me wondering why I've stuck with Google this long. Battery life is the main reason I returned this watch. If you don't ever touch it, leave the screen dark, disable every feature you can and leave battery saver on constantly, you'll get at most 20 hours of use per day because the thing can't make it a full 24 hours, even when you aren't wearing it at all! I have to charge 2-3 times per day (twice if I do no exercise at all) and it takes around 1.5-2 hours to charge, which seems excessive given my phone can charge from 0-100% in 28 minutes. When you aren't charging, you have to deal with no spo2 sensor (even though it has one), AFib tracking doesn't work constantly and the speakerphone is ENTIRELY UNUSABLE. It crackles when turned up loud enough to almost hear it and when it isn't crackling it's not loud enough to make out voice. You can't even hear the Assistant talk and the alarm wouldn't be noticeable if not for the vibrating. This watch makes me want to spend thousands to switch back and be an Apple customer after years of leaning towards Google for everything. This watch was a swing and a huge miss. This watch doesn't even compete with 5 year old watches out there. Not sure what Google was thinking, but it's making me reconsider being a Google Fanboy as no other Android watch checks all the boxes. My other complaint is the FitBit Premium membership needed to keep most of your data long-term unless you export it elsewhere (which isn't too difficult). Ultimately this experience pushed me to decide to not use a watch for now and I'm going to quit using Google Fit on my phone as I feel I should be getting paid for them to keep and sell my data to others. My other negative is the impact that this has to the environment. While the manufacturing process already did enough damage, this watch needs so much electricity to stay alive that it will cost me more than the watches value to keep it charged, creating more unnecessary environmental impact and costing me more in electricity daily. I can't even believe that I came to these conclusions because I'm a techie/nerd and usually need all the latest/greatest products.

Would not recommend this subpar watch, most likely will convert me from Googles [clearly] subpar Ecosystem. Even Fitbit Sense (which Google owns) gets at least 6x battery life and has more features, but Google made lots of promises for that watch that they still have yet to deliver - so I'm going without a watch now. Very sad this is what they released as their first watch. Maybe they should have waited yet another year if this is all they could do? Everyone I know that got a Pixel watch returned them and everyone I knew that wanted one no longer does. Pretty sad, but you sure aren't getting what you're paying for here. Google needs to remember who their customers are...

reviews.title: Nice design, but it ends there
reviews.text: I wanted this watch to be great since I have a Google phone and thought the watch would be comparable. After less than a day's use, the battery died. The only thing I used on it was the alarm option and media notifications since previous reviews mentioned that too much use would cause the battery to die quickly. I guess I didn't realize that it would be as bad as everyone else said. Returned after two days.

reviews.title: I love this watch- works amazing with pixel 7pro
reviews.text:
I bought my Pixel Watch LTE direct from the Google store. My husband got one too. We both have the Pixel 7 pro + pixel buds pro to use with it.
After about 3 days the battery stabilizes and becomes quite good! I get between 21-26 hrs depending on how much I'm using LTE+GPS. My husband got 30 hours because he works so doesn't use it as much during the work day as I do.
It pairs immediately with the pixel buds pro so answering the phone, using assistant, listening to streaming music, responding to text messages with voice, etc is awesome!! Sleep tracking works great tho I wish there was a way to have it automatically go into bedtime mode rather than have to remember to manually do that.
I have both Google Fit and Fitbit running on mine. They work great. The HR sensor actually matches my chest strap which is crazy. It does auto track workouts- you can't see it until you're done. I'm bummed Sp02 isn't turned on and fall detection isn't on. The bands are way expensive so we got the leather band in order to be able to pick out whatever bands we want. Really it's a great smart watch if you're into something that can be dressed up or down and works seamlessly with pixel. It's also great if you're not into the heavy giant watches and just want something comfortable on your wrist with good haptics. I could write more but I think that's enough. Can't wait for updates and also think gen2 will be just incredible

reviews.title: Best SmartWatch I have ever owned
reviews.text:
I have owned just about every smart watch from Apple, Samsung, Garmin, Fossil and Microsoft and all of them have had their issues. The Pixel Watch is not necessarily perfect out of the box either but, in my opinion, has already proven to be the most accurate wrist-based heart rate monitor I have ever used which is invaluable to me. I can finally ditch the chest strap for weight lifting workouts which is a game changer for me. I know it will only get better with time as Google works on future updates too.

Battery life has not been a problem for me but I am not using it as much as some and I don't typically track sleep so that is not a factor here. I mainly use it to get hourly reminders to move and for my main workouts, which I do at least 2 per day, and it works great for that. My workouts include a variety of HIIT/Cardio, Strength training, walking and yoga and this sucker tracks them all with extreme accuracy which I have tested against my trusty old chest strap. Great job Google. Keep it up!

reviews.title: Seems to work pretty well for the most part
reviews.text: Setup was easy with a quick app download and it paired with my iPhone 12 without any drama. Biometric tracking seems to work reasonably well with the exception of heart rate, which seems to always read 70 no matter what I'm doing. I'm not too crazy about the aesthetic of the watch, it just looks kind of cheap to me. I got this mainly to use as a health tracking tool and to tell time, not to make and receive calls/texts with, so I haven't setup any of those features yet and may never get around to doing so. So i can't comment on ease of use for any of those features. I did like that there are quite a lot of different watch face designs that can be applied and without any additional purchase. For the price of around $40, this is a pretty smokin' deal for a smart watch, I think.

reviews.title: Not bad for the price
reviews.text:
I’ve tried a few different affordable watches and my biggest issue has been the charging port. They have trouble staying connected with tiny pins and no magnetic pull. So going into this I’m more critical.
Upside is there is definitely a better charging system. It holds in place nicely even though it’s a pretty small pin area it is easier to charge.
The screen does have low sensitivity response. When pairing it it took 3 tries to get it recognize I had tapped the screen.
On a good note it’s reading well and has some great features like heart rate, oxygen, and sleep. Everything lined up well with my normal statistics so I feel it’s pretty accurate.
There’s a variety of images to choose from so you can customize the screen however you would like.
It’s very comfortable. The band holds like a premium watch band. It has a large face that is classy. Aesthetically it’s very nice.
Overall for an affordable smart watch it’s a decent option.

reviews.title: Okay tracker
reviews.text: For the price, it is an okay tracker.  The microphone on the watch is not of great quality as I was told sounded muffled on it.  It does have a lot of features and was quite easy to use but nothing about it made it stand out from the other hundreds of smart watches out on the market.

reviews.title: Cute watch is all I can say
reviews.text: Initially the watch was quick to charge and holds the charge for a couple of days.  The functions were easy to use, and a lot to choose from for the activities I do.  I mainly track my steps, distance, duration, heart rate.  It worked well for a few weeks, then I took it swimming for a few laps in the pool.  That was a mistake, battery stopped working (won't charge anymore).  Sad, I really liked the watch, it's cute but the battery died.

reviews.title: Great Smart watch for the essentials
reviews.text:
I was looking for a good smart watch for my mother. She was a Fitbit user but her Fitbit died after years of use and wanted something with a similar feel.
This watch really worked out for her.
It's got a great screen and a good amount of apps to provide essential uses.
It's able to work with iOS and Android.
It's able to get notifications from apps and make phone calls.
Not a bad product at all.

reviews.title: Watch is good, not great with mybphone
reviews.text:
The watch is great. Synched quickly with the app and I like the number of different face options offered. The battery life is also strong and it charges quickly.
Things I didn't like. If you touch the face it quickly unlocks and scrolls through the menus. So when I cross my arms I can mess up the watch, it needs a better lock. The app didn't synch all options to my watch/phone. So, I couldn't track sleep, heartrate and other things.
Maybe if I have a better phone?

Connects to any phone. #FoundItOnAmazon

reviews.title: Great Apple alternative!
reviews.text: Got this for my mom, here it is next to my Apple Watch, it has pretty much all the same features as the Apple at about a quarter of the price. The battery lasts all day and seems to be on par with the battery life of my watch. The app is easy to use and my mom loves it!

reviews.title: Awesome Smart Watch
reviews.text:
For the money, this is an awesome smart watch that has some of the same popular features as that “fruit” brand.
The watch was packaged securely in a box and included a User Manual and a “How to Connect with the smart watch” brochure.

My watch was received with 46% battery life and did not need to be charged immediately, but I noticed that the charge cord is magnetic and attaches easily to the back of the watch.

I read the instructions and powered on the watch. I downloaded the app and proceeded to pair, referred to as “bind” in the manual. The smart watch paired effortlessly with my iPhone 13. Other than pairing or unpairing, the user manual doesn’t cover much else, but I found the watch use to be intuitive. I do think a more detailed user manual would be helpful to explain navigating and swipe direction of the screens.

The watch has many functions and I was pleasantly surprised that the watch provided a “Siri connection” and performed flawlessly. I compared the blood pressure and oxygen sensors to my individual monitors to check accuracy. Surprisingly, the watch is pretty accurate.

As I mentioned earlier, I started using the watch with 46% battery life and wore the watch for approximately 25 hours before I received a low battery alert.

This is a great buy and so much so, that within hours of using my watch, I ordered another one for my husband.

reviews.title: Best watch yet!
reviews.text: I'm very impressed with this smart watch. It has so many features and works well. Definitely recommend it.

reviews.title: Easy to set up, very accurate, keeps me updated with many aspect of my health
reviews.text:
I really appreciate this watch and the features it has. First off, the smart watch was very easy to pair to my phone. I have an Android phone, and it only took a few minutes to pair the watch with my phone.
First enable Bluetooth and find the device listed as "C20"

Next, download the app that's shown in the QR code. Once you have the watch paired via Bluetooth to your smart phone and the app is downloaded, your watch ready to go, and should be syncing to your smart phone. The connection has been great thus far; it hasn't disconnected/lost connection to my phone.

As someone who has suffers from pulmonary lung disease, I was very excited when I found out this smart watch has the capability to track my oxygen saturation, heart rate, and blood pressure. In addition, you don't have to do anything, the watch will automatically to measurements periodically throughout the day.

It's helping me monitor and compare results over a few days. I suggest authorizing Google Fit so your hearth history is accessible when it. For me, it helps to have a history when I meet with my pulmonologist.

The watch has great standby battery life, and it's light weight. After m three days it's only dipped minimally in available battery percentage. I highly recommend this!

**Updated**

So it's been several days now since I first posted the review and I am amazed how little the battery has drained. Needless to say this smartwatch has fantastic standby battery life; especially considering it's constantly looking for/measuring heart rate. As you can see from the photos the readings are very accurate. I own a pulse oximeter and a blood pressure monitor to keep my pulmonary hypertension in check. My resting heart rate is 95 bpm, which may seem high, but the reading is accurate and normal which makes this product more the reassuring.

reviews.title: Great Watch!
reviews.text: Ok, I have had fitness watches from Samsung to Fitbit to Garmin and this one is the best....especially for the price.  First thing since turning 60 I need a watch I can read in the sunlight.  This has a brightness level I actually do not have to turn it all the way up and the workout data is big enough to read. I think all the health data is correct, but do not trust the Blood Pressure readings because of the science behind it. Actually do not trust any BP on a fitness watch.  There is a lot of customization you can do......I recommend a custom watch face along with setting up quick view on a schedule. I am now going to see if I can get a spare charging cord,

reviews.title: A good start but needs a lot of work.
reviews.text:
This is a tough review to write. If I could do half stars, this watch would be a 3.5 for me. It does so much right but it feels incomplete and overpriced to me.

First off, the screen and overall build quality is amazing. I have a Galaxy Active 2 as well and, candidly, this Zepp watch is better in pretty much every way in terms of build. The glass feels better and more scratch resistant. You get a stainless frame instead of aluminum. The shocker is the screen. I am not sure how but this watch looks brighter and crisper to me. The size is really nice as well. The Zepp E has a lower profile and almost no visible bezel. If hardware was the lone consideration, this would get a near perfect score.

The battery life is also really outstanding. I get 5 to 7 days with this. It has a proprietary magnetic charger that works well. Even playing with it often and tracking regular workouts doesn't seem to bother it.

I also like Zepp's approach to overall health measurement. The PAI (Personal Activity Intelligence) score tries to give you an overall measurement of how healthy your days are. Once you understand it, I think it is a good general snap shot. If everyone tracked their life like this, the world would be a much healthier place. Sleep tracking is good as well. In line with what I have gotten from Fitbit and Samsung though you need to make sure to set a daily screen timer as it doesn't automatically know to turn off the screen when you are sleeping like the others.

From here though things begin to slip. At $250, there is no onboard GPS. This is a big omission at this price. There also isn't auto tracking for workouts like most others have so you have to remember to physically start tracking workouts. There is no onboard music player though you can control your music from the watch. Interacting with your notifications and inbound calls are all but worthless. Zepp's app is also a mess. It is cumbersome and not well thought out. Everything you want is there but it often takes alot of effort to get from one thing to another. Samsung's app is vastly superior. Lastly, the watch comes with a leather strap. At the time of this writing, Zepp has silicone straps listed on their site but they don't appear to be available yet. A watch that is focused on health should come default with a silicone strap.

I guess I am just not sure what Zepp set out to accomplish with this watch. Is it a smart watch? Not really. Is it a fitness watch? Kind of. Its like they tried to split the baby and ended up accomplishing neither successfully. If you want a good looking everyday digital semi-smart watch with a great battery life, this is worth considering but, for most, at $250, there are better options out there. Perhaps Zepp will update this product and make it more well rounded. If not, I would suggest waiting for a price reduction before investing.

reviews.title: Only thing missing is the talk and messaging
reviews.text: Otherwise, it is similar to Apple watch. I easily set this up and downloaded the software from the app store. It installed easily with absolutely zero issues and you know it is always the software that has glitches. This watch is probably one of the better health smart watches on the market.. It looks nice, it performs nice and has lots of features. You will love the battery life, especially if you have a smartwatch that has to be charged almost daily or maybe ever day and a half. The watch monitors sleep stages, heart rate and 11 different exercises, including swimming. And, it is nice looking. Pretty sweet. I wanted to add that you can select so many faces for your watch without extra charges.

title: Apple Watch SE (GPS, 40mm) - Silver Aluminum Case with Abyss Blue Sport Band (Renewed)
description: Stay safe, active, and healthy with the Apple Watch SE. The SE sports the same bright LTPO OLED Retina display as the Series 6, giving you a bright screen you can view at a glance, even in bright sunlight. On it, you can view all of your fitness metrics, health stats, and mobile notifications. When it comes to health, the SE's optical heart rate monitor can give you indicators of a possible medical condition with notifications for high or low heart rates, as well as irregular rhythms. Even healthy habits are supported, such as hand-washing detection, which displays a 20-second animated countdown as you scrub. Fitness is a large part of staying healthy, and the Apple Watch SE has a variety of ways to assist you in reaching your goals. Activity Rings displays three rings that correspond to movement, exercise, and standing. Stay mobile throughout the day to hit new personal bests as you close the rings.You can also choose from a variety of workouts, such as running, swimming, yoga, cycling, and more; with the watch recording and tracking their specific metrics. Whether inside or outdoors, the SE can guide you via GPS and even provide continuous elevation updates on screen. As you move, choose from a variety of music, podcasts, and audiobooks to entertain and motivate you. For added fun, share your activity rings with friends and challenge them to 7-day activity competitions. Throughout the day, the Apple Watch SE keeps you connected with the world around you. When paired with your iPhone, you can make calls and send texts directly from your wrist, navigate your surroundings with Maps, buy items with Apple Pay, and use your voice to interact with Siri. Made to last in almost any kind of weather, the Apple Watch SE is water-resistant up to 164'. Use its 32GB of built-in storage for apps, watch faces, music, and more.
features: LEAVE YOUR PHONE IN YOUR POCKET: Apple Watch SE GPS Model lets you call, text, and get directions from your wrist, while leaving your phone in your pocket. It offers multiple connectivity options, including: Bluetooth, Wi-Fi, and NFC to suit your needs, whatever they might be.

LARGE RETINA OLED DISPLAY: The SE sports a bright LTPO OLED Retina display, giving you a bright screen you can view at a glance, even in bright sunlight. A variety of watch faces are available for the SE watch, including faces that provide essential information for specific activities.

LOADED WITH FEATURES: When paired with your iPhone, you can make calls and send texts from your wrist, navigate with Maps, buy items with Apple Pay, and use your voice to activate Siri. Made to last in almost any kind of weather, the Apple Watch SE is water-resistant up to 164'.

WORKOUTS THAT DON'T QUIT: Cycling, yoga, swimming, high-intensity interval training...the list goes on. You name it, Apple Watch measures it. Set workout-specific goals, see full summaries when you're done, and track how you're trending over time in the Activity app on your iPhone.

GET LOST IN YOUR MUSIC: With Apple Music on your wrist, you've got 60 million tracks of musical motivation to take you places. You can also catch up on the latest podcasts or listen to an audiobook if that's your thing. Stream everything you need right from your watch, even without your phone.

reviews.title: Pretty much a Fenix 6S with a better battery
reviews.text:
I figured I'd give my 6S to the wife and try the 7S Sapphire Solar. In general the watches are nearly identical, but the 7S does have a noticably better battery. When we go hiking, we get identical information, the 7S doesn't need L5 GPS but it works fine. I like the addition of the touch display. Lastly, Garmin is finally getting their act together on software, the 6S and 7S both work well with Garmin Golf and Connect, lots of good data and charts.

There are a few more data pages on the watch for me to look at than on the 6S. I suspect the 6S could have them too but Garmin wants you to upgrade.

Bottom line, if you have a 6, wait for the 8, maybe it will have ECG?

I was very surprised to see that after a full day out-and-about I had under 300 steps on the counter.  That's roughly what I would normally have when I got up to get my morning coffee. reviews.title: doesn't stay on securely
reviews.text: I've purchased one of these in the past and liked it, but the gold color faded so I l reordered another it in black. However, this time, one side kept disconnecting and the attachment site looked defective compared to the other side causing me to almost lose my Fitbit twice. Luckily, I was indoors and heard it drop. I will return it and try a different brand as I fear I will encounter this issue again if I simply replace it.  This style is nice because it's easy to put on and off even with a single hand as opposed to the type of bracelet that comes with the Fitbit.

reviews.title: Worried the magnet will damage device
reviews.text: I wanted a band that would have more variability in fit, and I liked the color, so I ordered this.  It is, indeed, compatible with the Fitbit Sense and I enjoyed it for several days until I had to charge my Sense.  I then discovered that the magnet was so strong that I had difficulty keeping it off the back of my device long enough to get the charger on.  I was worried that strong magnet might damage the circuits and contacted FitBit for their opinion.  They weren't sure, but pointed out that they do have a hook-and-loop wristband in-house that is available.  Since I was also having trouble with the edges of the VNCAS band getting caught on my wool shawl and anything else fuzzy I wore, I decided to ditch it for the FitBit brand option.  Sorry, but I can't recommend this one.

reviews.title: Not Well Made😳
reviews.text: Initially when I bought this watch band, I thought it was nice, solid and seemed to be well made. I've been wearing it just a little over 2 months now and there's some sharp little burrs that have now showed up on the watch band itself and the edges of the other parts are now seeming to be sharp as well and keep getting hung up on my clothing and have also scratched my boyfriend several times. The finish is wearing off on the backside of the magnet connector area so now it looks very tarnished. I do wear it everyday all day long, but I don't feel after such a short period of time it should look so bad and have these sharp edges now. Unfortunately it's past my return window so I'm going to have to just throw it away and get another one. Such a shame because I really like the magnetic band and the color. I'm a little bit leery about buying another similar style for fear that the same thing will happen again. 😳

reviews.title: I was worried that this cable damaged my watch.
reviews.text: I bought this item as extra charging cables for my Vivomove Style, which has physical watch hands in addition to the electronic display. Every time I use this charger instead of the OEM charger, the time shown by the physical hands is hours off and I have to realign.  It also seems to become much less sensitive to touch until I plug it back into the OEM charger to reset it.  The Vivomove Style will keep the time on the physical hands 2 weeks after the battery dies (and I've never seen it not keep accurate time), so it wasn't a dead battery issue.  I was hoping to have more than one cable to charge my watch but based on the issues I'm having,  I'm going back to the OEM cable.

Q&A:
1. Why the watch doesn’t have the network(The watch shows "Search ... " for a long time)
(1) The SIM card is not overdue. (2) Check the upper left corner of the watch interface for stable signal icons or up and down arrows. If no, please restart the watch. (3) There may be no set the correct APN.
2. Why the watch cannot recognize the SIM card
(1) Confirm that the SIM card is not overdue. (2) Confirm that the SIM card is installed in the right direction. (3) Power off before card insertion. (4) Change the region and try again.
3. Why can't I make a video call
(1) Confirm that the SIM card has data and the network signal is stable. (2) Check whether the APP side is disabled for video calls. (3) Other family members who want video calls need to have a Leefine account and bind the watch. (4) Whether all permissions of APP needed are granted. (5) The APP needs to be opened, run and work in the background. Only the video call is initiated on the watch end, the APP end can receive the push message. (6) The video call has just ended. It will take 5 minutes for the watch end to call again.

reviews.title: Would be the perfect watch if the battery was replaceable
reviews.text:
I normally don't like smart watches because I hate the idea of spending hundreds of dollars on something with a non-replaceable battery that will wear out in a few years rendering the watch useless. Even though I do love my new Instinct 2 watch, I'm still not crazy about the wasteful business model of smart watches, and am not sure I will buy another after this one. That said, the Instinct 2 is a near perfect watch in almost every way... it is feature packed, fully customizable (without being over the top), has a long battery life, and is very comfortable as a daily driver watch.

I use mine for the usual day-to-day watch stuff, and hiking primarily. I don't use any of the smart phone or health features (heart rate, pulse ox, etc.) as I don't care about them. I use the compass, altimeter, and gps tracking features frequently, and they all work great.

Overall, this is a fantastic watch for what it is. However, I really, REALLY hate that it has a non-replaceable battery that will inevitably wear out after only a few years. I know that this is the case as I had a Fenix 5 before this one that lasted about 4 years before the battery began dying quickly. It essentially became a $500 door stop after that...

reviews.title: It's soft
reviews.text:
Like another reviewer had mentioned, they are soft. I used a rubber squeegee that I've used on countless other screen savers, and it actually damaged the skin. It has permanent "bubbles" (more like dents) in it that will not go away. Other than that, the fit is perfect. And the skin comes very nicely packaged with everything you could ever need, including a bottle of soapy water for the application.

The attention to detail by Skinomi is second to none. The company gets five stars, but I've got to deduct one for the soft material. Skinomi did include a squeegee, but it's too big for use with this skin. Had I cut it down to size and used it, I may not have "dents" now.

reviews.title: Everything and more from what i expected from a smart watch
reviews.text: i spent a great deal of time researching smart watches, Garmin came up the winner.  I have dealt with their customer service on two occasions with another product and found them to be excellent which i a big reason for buying another Garmin product.

reviews.title: Poor battery life, feature rich
reviews.text:
If only the battery life was better... I have the GPS turned off and I only measure my blood oxygen level when I'm asleep yet it is nearly impossible for the watch to last a little more than 24 hours.

My next Garmin will be the one with a solar powered assist.

That being said for the negatives this watch has the features I wanted at a good price:

- Sleep quality/quantity
- Blood oxygen level
- Steps counter
- Flight of stairs counting
- Water intake recording ) manual input)
- Multiple activities recording (it can detect when I'm running, bike riding, etc.)

It has been durable and the screen is still scratch free.

If poor battery life isn't a deal breaker buy it.

reviews.title: After a year and a half...can't wait to switch, Spotify is the worst part of this watch by far
reviews.text:
I have owned this watch for a year and a half now. I use it almost daily for my walks/runs, weight workouts, and indoor bike workouts. The main reason I chose this watch in the first place was because it was one of the smaller ones available. I am 5'9 but have small wrists, and really disliked the 'utilitarian' look of larger watches. After a year and a half, I am so tired of the issues with it and ready to jump ship. If I used this watch more regularly (I only wear it for workouts - not all day), I would have switched a LONG time ago. The amount of people who have complained about the same issues for YEARS without Garmin doing anything makes me hesitant to purchase another Garmin product, especially with the Apple Watch, Samsung, and now Google buying out Fitbit and coming up with a watch.
- Spotify on this watch seriously sucks. If you check Spotify forums, you will find COUNTLESS threads of suggestions for the Spotify app on this watch that should truly be basic features at this price. Do they implement them or listen? No. Also, there is no way to contact Spotify customer service - you just get pointed towards their 'community forum' where you have people complaining of the same exact things with no fix. You can't skip forward on any track, at all. I listen to a lot of podcasts when I walk. Some are 2 hours in length while my walk is only 1 hour. This watch constantly either reverts to the very beginning of my podcast so I have to start all over (because again, you can't skip forward - so have fun listening to ads as well!) in anything, only updates 1 song out of 15 on my playlist or get the error 'sync failed', or some other random issue. Also, if you have a playlist on Spotify, you cannot choose the track you want to listen to. You have to hit the >> button to get to where you want. Really? I hope Garmin drops Spotify because they have been a truly horrible app on this watch the entire time with no effort to make updates. Take a look at the reviews of Spotify on the Garmin store if you don't believe me.
- Battery life is a couple of days. However, there are points in time where my watch will be at say 80% the night before, I get ready to leave and go my walk the next morning, pick up my watch, and it's at 8%. WTF? This happens enough to be super annoying and apparently is not an 'only me' problem. It appears to be tied to when the watch updates.
- I tried to wear this to track my sleep in the beginning and gave up after two nights due to the extreme disco effect of the 'gesture' motions. I tried turning on the 'do not disturb' function advertised on the watch which is supposed to disable this stupidly bright light that WILL wake you and whoever is next to you up. Didn't work. Do a search for 'Garmin watch lights up in middle of the night' and you will find all sorts of people complaining of the same thing, and not just on this version of the watch.
- GPS has issues connecting and can take several minutes which is pretty annoying when you try to start tracking an activity only to see a red bar when trying to connect. I 'sync' my watch to my phone constantly so that is not the issue. I have switched between the GPS options Garmin offers on the watch to no avail. Search for this issue as well and you will see lots of people with the same complaint.

reviews.title: GET THIS WATCH!!!
reviews.text: I LOVE this watch!!! It is so easy to use, tracks all of the metrics I am interested in (steps, sleep, stress, activities, hydration, menstrual cycle) and then some!! It is very accurate and the app is very user- friendly. The watch itself has worked perfectly and I have found it to be comfortable and intuitive to use.  It holds a charge for several days on end and when it does need to be charged, it reaches full battery very quickly! I looked at a lot of different watches and considered a lot of different options. I am so happy that I went with the vivoactive 4! Garmin, you all did a great job with this watch!! I honestly could not be happier with my choice!!

reviews.title: This is just a 22mm silicone watch strap, ignore the smartwatch stuff if you're using a real watch.
reviews.text:
Recently Amazon had a sale on a watch I like, a Seiko Solar 42mm faced 22mm lug analog watch. A real watch, that tells time, day, date and that's all, what we in the watch enthusiast world like to call a "tool watch". Because it's a tool for telling time. Period. I"m a semi-retired IT engineer and have more than enough screens in my life, I don't need nor want one in place of a real watch too. This watch runs for 10 months on a full charge from a light source and never needs a battery replacement, eat your heart out 3 day smartwatches.

I decided being as the watch is black with a sort of stencil font on the face indices that I'd take a chance on this band and accessorize it with a military-looking Army Green silicone band -- Because I do not wear permeable (leather, nylon, canvas, cloth, etc.) watch straps I decided an Army Green silicone band was the way to go with the new watch and put the canvas band that came on it in a drawer. I don't wear NATO straps either, first because they're permeable nylon (permeable is a no-no for me) and secondly because to me they look like someone tried to tie their watch on their wrist with a chunk of old seat belt.

This band fits on a 22mm lug's spring-bar perfectly. It's very easy and fast to remove or replace too. I've tried to get it to let go of the spring-bar "by accident" and it's on there very solidly, at least as solid as any other system. I have a rather large 8" wrist and there's room to spare on the band. It's also very quick and easy to remove or replace, I wish more bands would use this kind of system. I wish more bands came in this length too, it's hard fro me to find one that fits without strangling my hand.

The "keepers", the little loops that hold the tongue of the strap in place where it emerges from the buckle, have lugs on them that fit in the sizing slots on the band. That's a GREAT extra feature because those keepers tend to wander up and down the watchband without those lugs to hold them in place. This can cause either the tongue of the band or the keeper to snag on something which can break the band or the keeper loop. No problem with this band, the lugs on the keepers stabilize them exactly where you put them. This is something that is not shown nor addressed in the product description and very much should be. It's a deciding factor for me and I might have returned the watchstrap if it didn't have those lugs on the keepers.

The band is about the thickness you'd expect and has no discernible taper from lug to buckle. Being silicone it weighs very little and does not appreciably add to the weight of the watch and strap combo. It's just a good, plain, non-reactive, non-absorbent, military looking watchstrap. That will fit on any watch, smart or otherwise, with a 22mm lug. I don't know if I'd use this strap on an Omega or a Rolex, mostly because those are much heavier watches than the one I use the strap on. It's a little plain for a multi-thousand dollar plus watch too, I think there are better choices. But for a watch I got at less than half price and intend to wear every day to save my nicer watches the wear, tear and scratches that come with that kind of use ... This band works perfectly.

The only complaint I have with it is that I could do without the little "smart watch" triangles, of which there are three. One on the buckle and one near each lug attachment. But that's a very, very minor issue and not worth taking a star off my review over. I knew they were there when I ordered it and this is a style thing not a failure in design and materials thing. This particular watch that I'm using this band on has a very similar little triangle on the bezel above the 12 o'clock indices so it looks like the strap was made for the watch ... sort of. Actually now that I look at it some more, it looks quite natural.

We'll see how long it lasts, I just got it. If it has an unreasonably short service life I'll come back here and add an edit to this review. If you don't see that addition, what I say here stands current.

reviews.title: Some Good Aspects, But Several Annoying Issues
reviews.text:
This CNPGD Smart Watch Fitness Tracker had the potential to be really great. In terms of appearance, the body of the watch combined with the band are sleek and attractive. The watch is available in 4 different color schemes (Black, Pink, Red, and Blue/Silver) and each looks aesthetically pleasing. I received the Black one and really liked the clean lines and modern design. The band fits around the wrist comfortably as well.

Before trying to turn the watch on, I decided to charge it fully overnight. I followed the instructions and photos on the instruction sheet and tried to remove the band from the watch's charging port end. Unfortunately, it was so difficult to remove that I thought I was going to damage the watch or the band at some point as I worked up a sweat trying to pry/pull it apart. I finally managed to insert the lip of a plastic spoon into a sliver of space I had gotten between the band and the watch. I kept working at it until I was finally able to get the band off. I really do not look forward to repeating this process.

Once the watch was charged, I downloaded the WearFit 2.0 App and after a couple of tries, was able to pair my phone with the watch. There are some annoying aspects about the App. In one area, I was able to specify customary units such as pounds and feet versus the default kilograms and centimeters, but in another area, I was unable to make the change. When using the watch, as I started to toggle through the functions, I realized that there was no way to toggle backwards. So if I swiped past my desired function such as the stopwatch feature, I needed to swipe past all the other functions again until I got back to the stopwatch feature. Swiping right or left or pressing the Home button does the same thing and only moves the choice of functions in one direction, forward.

I went out for a long walk and compared the watch's step and distance counter against my phone's fitness app with GPS and a very accurate pocket pedometer. After the walk, my phone fitness app, pedometer, and this watch all gave roughly the same measurement for the mileage. Unfortunately, the step count of the watch was about 2,000 steps off from the other two devices. it's unfortunate that this watch has so many annoying issues as the features such as the BP, O2, and other health trackers are quite handy. I would give this fitness tracker watch more stars if they just made some upgrades/updates to the app and maybe the watch's firmware.

reviews.title: Great activity tracker with AMAZING Battery Life.
reviews.text:
[[VIDEOID:e0fda475d57018948d4bdf5116c091bf]] I had a different version activity watch that was way more expensive to match my phone. For the cost this watch does just about everything I need it to for way less money.

A few things I love about the watch...the Battery Life. OMG the battery life! It lasted me a full week with wearing it to bed most nights, through multiple exercise walks and a few work outs, and hundreds of notifications from my messaging apps and phone calls. It's easy to clear the notifications I receive on the watch. I love that it tracks my sleep, heart rate, and stress levels easily. I also tested out in my pool for swimming and it was waterproof without having to shake the watch or turn on any special modes to keep it watertight.

I haven't figured out of it auto detects a work out but that could be because I obviously don't work out that much.

I tested it against my health app on my phone and they were pretty accurate against each other info steps and mileage. I can't figure out how to get the watch and the app to register my GPS coordinates to see the map of my walks but I could be missing the settings.

The app that gives the data is easy to navigate and update any settings. Seems very similar to other track laps I've used.
A few things I'm not liking about this watch...
I feel like the band and the watch itself that comes with the watch is a little too big for my wrist. And I have a bigger wrist for a female at my size. The watch face is bigger than some of my friends apple watches and taller than my old Samsung gear fit watch. I can SEE notifications on the watch but I can't respond or give a quick response to any messages. For Whatsapp or Facebook Messenger I wouldn't expect that but for SMS messages I would like to be able to give a quick text back either by speaking a response or by selecting from some quick options.

Those are really my only 2 complaints. I like this watch and will continue to use!

reviews.title: A sluggish, inaccurate, subpar sports/health smart watch.
reviews.text:
I needed a backup sports smart watch for my Apple Watch. Let's check out this Veryfit watch.

What works:
Charged up in about 2-3 hours from 60% battery level.
Easy to install the Veryfit app and pair with my old iPhone 12 Pro.
Has many of the basic sports watch functions: stopwatch, alarm, timer, along with biometrics: Heart rate, Blood oxygen monitoring, Stress level, Breath training, Sleep, etc.
Big, easy to read watch face, only a bit narrower than my 44mm Apple Watch.
A variety of watch faces to download.
Nice, soft, comfortable watch straps.

What don't work:
Once linked up to my iPhone, app takes some effort to set up.
Can only receive notifications and phone call alerts, no relay of calls.
Heart rate monitor is erratic with a wide range of random readings. My resting heart rate is 56bpm yet this watch measures a range of 62 to 125bpm at various times.
Requires about 25s to get each biometric reading.
What's up with the 3-2-1 countdown to start each exercise? Start/Stop is what most users prefer.
Perhaps the Android version works better?
Don't expect too much from this $34.99 smart watch (after -30% off coupon on Feb. 19, 2023) but there are other smart watches in this price range that function better.

reviews.title: Awesome watch for the price!  On 2nd thought, maybe not so awesome
reviews.text:
I received this watch, opened it up and set it to charge for a couple of hours. I then followed the instructions to download the app onto my phone. I went to settings and pretty much turned the settings on for everything so that I could see if it would work. It does. I can check the weather, my temperature, blood pressure, oxygen, pulse and steps. I can set it to a sport activity and there are multiple ones. I was able to go to settings on the phone app and select 1 out of 152 different picture settings (and I can change it as much as I want to). It came with the 2 bands- pink and light brown or tan. I have only worn the pink band so far and it is soft. The charge on the battery lasted a week, which is nice because if you just remember to charge it for 2 hours once a week on the same day, that would be easy to remember. I have not really used the camera function but did somehow try it out as I twisted my wrist, and the phone camera took a picture. I have not used the music part of the watch either, but that is because I do not have a music option on my phone right now. The only issue that I had was connecting it to Google Fit so that I could attach that to the Walker Tracker App (which I use for competitions for # of steps). That is okay though because I can manually put the daily steps in. Overall, I would definitely recommend this watch. I have never had an Apple or Samsung Watch, but with this one, if it breaks, I won't be crying like I would with one of the expensive watches... and it works for what I want it for!

6/3/22- Update- this watch has been acting nuts the last 2 weeks. I was hoping it would work itself out, but it has not. The watch randomly buzzes and/or blinks. Sometimes it zeroes itself out. reviews.title: Warning: Do not trust medical readings!
reviews.text:
When I first opened this and changed the pink silicone strap to the rose gold steel strap, I thought it was pretty, albeit quite large for my tiny wrist. But I got this specifically for the health monitoring and wanted something that looked a little classy. Well, the only thing that reads correctly on my watch is the time.

I downloaded the app and it wants you to create an account and to allow access to everything personal on your phone. No thanks. I was not interested in receiving texts, calls, and alerts anyway. I just wanted to monitor my pulse, blood pressure, and steps. Everything else was supposed to be a bonus for me.

I had two separate doctor appointments yesterday and was alarmed when I compared the findings.
* Steps: When we discussed my new "smart"watch, the one doctor told me he's a runner and tries to get 10,000 steps daily even when he works. Apparently I walked about a third of that despite driving most of the day. GO ME!
* Temp: In the prior two days I wore this, my temperature has always read in the 95-96 degree range. Temp at both offices was NORMAL.
* O2 stats are probably ok, but that wasn't checked, at least that I paid attention to.
* BP: Here's a HUGE problem. It has consistently been reading at 128/76 +/- only 4 points on systolic or diastolic. But in both offices, my systolic was wrong by more than 30-35 points! I just came off BP medicine and needed to monitor it, so this was shocking, to say the least.
* Pulse: The other consistently incorrect reading. The watch has been reading between 90-110 at rest. This is alarmingly conceivable considering my health concern, which is why I went for one appointment to have it checked. However, after an EKG, my heart is fine and my pulse was actually around 70-80 at both offices after a little walking.
*Sleep: Since I have several issues with sleep, I looked forward to this info. Apparently I sleep while at my computer drinking coffee in the morning, as well as on part of my long drive home yesterday.

So not that it even matters at this point, but the location and weather would never "set" on the app or watch either, even though I specifically turned on my location just for your app. It just stayed blank with lines. I guess that's better than telling me it's snowing when it's really 70 degrees, considering your other reliable results.

Honestly, if you're going to market this as an activity tracker with health monitoring, then it should be able to give at least SOMEWHAT reliable readings. Mine weren't even close. I checked my temp, pulse, and BP manually the moment after it was taken in both offices to verify accuracy and it was so far off I thought I may be in jeopardy. So a big thank you for causing additional anxiety thinking my BP was only slightly high when it was way too high, and giving me tachycardia when it was only a bit elevated. Add my freezing temp and I should probably be close to death.

This is one of the most disturbing, nerve-wracking items I've ever gotten on Amazon. Or probably anywhere.

reviews.title: Nice resolution
reviews.text:
I bought this watch because of the high-resolution display. And that's what I got, no more, no less.

Upon first impression, I can tell the display has crisp graphics. The touch screen is responsive. The processor is fast. Overall, the phone itself is nice.

The app, on the other hand, is awful. It is intuitive, but it loses Bluetooth connectivity without reason. This is the only app that I've seen that will move forward and backward during a dial sync. When I switch to certain dials, the progress bar will reach 61%, then count back down to 60%, then 59%, then start going back up. It's nice to see honesty in an app, but it's just strange.

I didn't test notifications from other apps, but no SMS text messages came through. The setup is simple and easy with SMS notifications settings on its own section. But once set up, no messages came through.

Battery life? What battery life? After a fully charge, this watch drained to 90% in the 15 minutes I used to overlook the features and set up the app. This from a 330mAh battery. At this rate, the battery will be depleted in less than two hours.

reviews.title: Junk
reviews.text: What a piece of junk. The instructions don't match the watch or the Amazon description and is written in awful broken English. And the app--- AWFUL. Navigation is bad, the English on the app is even worse than the instructions. I'm seriously concerned that downloading the app has somehow compromised anything on my phone. While I understand Amazon is a gigantic company that can't police every single item for sale, this is just BLATANTLY bad. In case my review isn't already clear, DO NOT BUY.

reviews.title: Great replacement bands for the Fitbit Charge 5
reviews.text: These bands fit well on the Fitbit Charge 5, as a replacement for a damaged band or just to change up the look now and then.  They are easy to install and remove and they do give an entirely different look to the Charge 5. I have the Large size and they are the same length as the original band that came with the Fitbit.  The colors as presented in listing are accurate and, in fact, I liked the teal and purple even more when I saw them in person.  There's only one noticeable difference between these bands and the original band.  The original band is quite smooth while these bands have some friction to them when you run you fingers over them.  Neither texture is better than the other. They're just different. My original band is black and absent the difference in feel, there's no real distinction vs. the black band that I received in this six pack.

reviews.title: works to add security to fitbit watch band
reviews.text:
Good. I have been using these bands as extra security on my fitbit bands since I first got a fitbit dating back to 2015. I have had several styles since then, and I always make sure to have a pack of these security bands on hand. First it was because the fitbit band was just a pressure close band that easily popped off, then it was a matter of keeping a regular watch band style extra secure. These work on the regular width bands.

When I was ready to buy more of these security bands, I was about to buy some that are made for fitbit, but then I realized that those have a protrusion for locking into the band. I really just wanted something to slip on with no need to make use of the band holes to secure it. These are exactly what I wanted. Nice variety of colors.

title: Apple Watch Series 6 (GPS + Cellular, 40mm) - Graphite Stainless Steel Case with Black Sport Band (Renewed)
description: Monitor even more of your health with the Apple Watch Series 6. The Series 6 adds pulse oximetry to measure your blood's oxygen levels (SpO2) in just 15 seconds, as well as showing you your VO2 Max (maximum oxygen consumption) score. These indicators can provide early warnings to possible respiratory conditions. They are joined by an optical heart rate monitor and the ability to record your own ECG (electrocardiogram). The Series 6 can even detect and help you with healthy habits, such as hand-washing detection, which displays a 20-second animated countdown as you scrub. Fitness is a large part of staying healthy, and the Apple Watch has a variety of ways to assist you in reaching your goals. Activity Rings displays three rings that correspond to movement, exercise, and standing. Stay mobile throughout the day to hit new persol bests as you close the rings. You can also choose from a variety of workouts, such as running, swimming, yoga, cycling, and more; with the watch recording and tracking their specific metrics.Fitness and health metrics can be viewed, customized, and tracked on the Apple Watch's curved watch face that houses an always-on LTPO OLED Reti display. Even in direct sunlight you can view the screen with just a glance. As you move, choose from a variety of music, podcasts, and audiobooks to entertain and motivate you. For added fun, share your activity rings with friends and challenge them to 7-day activity competitions. Throughout the day, the Apple Watch Series 6 keeps you connected with the world around you. When paired with your iPhone, you can make calls and send texts directly from your wrist, vigate your surroundings with Maps, buy items with Apple Pay, and use your voice to interact with Siri. Made to last in almost any kind of weather, the Apple Watch Series 6 is water-resistant up to 164'. Use its 32GB of built-in storage for apps, watch faces, music, and more.
features: GPS + Cellular model lets you call, text, and get directions without your phone
Measure your blood oxygen with an all-new sensor and app
Check your heart rhythm with the ECG app
The Always-On Retina display is 2.5x brighter outdoors when your wrist is down
S6 SiP is up to 20% faster than Series 5
5GHz Wi-Fi and U1 Ultra Wideband chip
Track your daily activity on Apple Watch and see your trends in the Fitness app on iPhone
Measure workouts like running, walking, cycling, yoga, swimming, and dance
Swimproof design
Sync your favorite music, podcasts, and audiobooks

title: SAMSUNG GEAR S3 FRONTIER Smartwatch 46MM (Bluetooth Only) - Dark Grey (Renewed)
description:
Stay in touch, without reaching for your phone, with the smartwatch that’s engineered for adventure. Convenience being the key feature, the watch offers fitness tracking, app access and watch face customization. With the Gear S3, you can pay right from your wrist and track your location as well. The Gear S3 is compatible with both Android and iOS smartphones.
Never Miss a Moment
The Gear S3 is Bluetooth connected so you can receive texts, emails, and alerts without reaching for your phone. With a built-in speaker and microphone, you can also make and answer calls hands-free. Just rotate the distinctive steel bezel to easily access apps and notifications so you can instantly check texts, updates, and more.
Pay with Your Watch
With Samsung Pay on your Gear S3, you can easily make payments with your watch almost anywhere you can swipe or tap a credit card - even without your phone or wallet.
Get Out There
Whether you’re off-roading or exploring a new city, the built-in GPS tracks your activity and makes it easy to share your location.
Designed for The Elements
The military-grade Gear S3 is tough enough to handle the elements. It resists water, dust, extreme temperatures, and the occasional drop so you can venture out with confidence.
Go for Days
Go nonstop for days on a single charge.4 When it’s time to recharge, the wireless charger lets you power up without slowing down.
Tailored to You
Make the Gear S3 your own. Customize your watch face, choosing from thousands of striking colors and designs. Plus easily swap out the standard 22mm band.

I love this strap it is so pretty and such a value for the money. It looks like it cost way more. The little kit it came with to attach it to the Fitbit and to remove extra links was so handy and easy to use. It attached with no trouble at all.

The only issue I had with it was that the rose gold color is slightly off from the Fitbit, but when wearing it, it’s not next to it directly so you can’t really tell. It’s not enough to bother me or take a star off but it could be for some.

reviews.title: Surprised at the comfort and beauty of the band.
reviews.text:
I've only had it on for a few hours, but I love it. The colors, black, pink on the resin look so rich and shiny. And it's a comfortable fit. I did have to take out 2 tabs to get a snug fit. Taking out the tabs wasn't difficult after figuring out the way the tool that came with it. Can't say the instructions were the best, but I figured it out.
I always got the magnetic mesh band in rose gold, but it always discolored and no matter what i tried I couldn't get it cleaned.
This is why I tried a new band. A review prompt gave suggestions of different things to comment on. One of the suggestions was a mobile app. I have no idea what that had to do with the band. Maybe someone knows and can let me know.
UPDATE:
I've been wearing it 24 hours a day, except when showering or recharging the watch. NO discloration, no running of colors (bracelet) and it doesn't get dirty looking like the metalic bands. I'm going to buy another one, just in case something happens to this. So worth the money.

reviews.title: Super impressed with this watch. Truly remarkable
reviews.text:
[[VIDEOID:ae47b9651b52b2c1b0485219f33680bf]] Wow. I am not impressed by much, but this watch is truly impressive for this price point.

Build: Very good build quality. The waterproof case feels solid, with responsive buttons and full color high res screen. Bracelet is soft rubber and is very comfortable. It's a very large band, so large or small wrists will fit in here.

Features: Though not perfect, the features on this watch are impressive. Measures steps, activities, heart rate, laps, sleep quality. Very very nice featuers. Plus it's waterproof!!!

Cons: Some of the interfaces are a bit clunky, and the app could use work, but it's fairly intuitive, and easy to use. I connected to my Galaxy S7 with no problems.

I recommend this watch!

reviews.title: My favorite budget smart watch
reviews.text:
I've tried a variety of budget smart watches, and this one by Dr.Viva has become my favorite. It's very comfortable, great flexible band, no issues with feeling like it's pressing into my wrist bones. The screen display is a good size without being too large, perfect for smaller wrists.

The Zeroner app has been fantastic, no problems. It accurately tracks my steps, sleep & oxygen. I like how it has a variety of exercises for me to document. The battery life is a big winner. I recharge the smart watch once a week, compared to twice a week with the other watches I've tried before. I was disappointed that I don't have the option to have my own picture as the screen display, but the app still has plenty of screens to choose from.

If you're like me and don't want to spend an exorbitant price on a smart watch, but would still like to enjoy the features of a smart watch this one would be a great option.

I have another watch that is comparable and this watch costs 25% less. This is definitely good value. A watch like this is a game changer for people monitoring heart issues. Highly recommend.

reviews.title: Pretty good
reviews.text:
Pretty good smartwatch. I needed something to replace my Galaxy Active, but didn't want to spend $100+ on something with a horrible battery life. I bought this one and for a while I was disappointed. I had to charge the watch each night and the steps weren't as accurate. I changed the setting so that the screen doesn't turn on when you move your wrist and that has saved the battery big time. I'm on day 4 and only down to 50% which means I'm now able to track sleep as well. I still think the steps aren't as accurate because it almost matches the steps in my phone's health app, but I'm notorious for leaving my phone places. I also miss being able to limit the options for exercise types in the watch face. I have to scroll through a long list each time. Overall, pretty good product for a cheaper price.

Update: I originally gave this 5 stars, but I have to take 2 away. A few days ago, the watch all of a sudden stopped counting steps. For the price, it was perfect until it stopped working. Back to the drawing board.

reviews.title: does what it's supposed to
reviews.text:
*edit: I've found a con and it bugged me enough to update my review. If your phone is on "Do not disturb" and you leave your phone on at night for emergency calls, the watch still vibrates with every text, regardless of whether they're on your emergency list. This is annoying when you're a light sleeper and you get a text for go cart racing or Dairy Queen at 4 am. I'm assuming it would still go off with a call as well.

I have a Garmin Vivofit that for some reason the notification vibrations will work for a couple months, then stop working for a while, then randomly start working again. I was sick of this, and went looking for something not too expensive and found this. I'm still getting used to it, but it vibrates when I get a call or text, so I'm happy so far. The band is very flexible and comfortable, which is nice, since my Vivofit band was a little stiff.

reviews.title: Great watch for the price.
reviews.text: After buying the earlier brands of Fitbit which I loved. I bought myself a Luxe on sale for $100 last December 2021. It didn’t record anything accurately and just didn’t function the way it should. CS was if no help. I switched to Amazfit!  This is a great watch, the battery has lasted over a week. It accurately tells time, my heart rate, steps and I love this watch. It’s great and is so light on my wrist!!

reviews.title: Terrible smart watch, inaccurate and waste of time/money
reviews.text: After 5 months of use I’m done with this. It seems to be getting less accurate every workout. It can’t even get step counts correct. The accuracy of the heart beat monitoring varies too. The sleep monitor is often wrong about awake times so I don’t believe the other sleep data either. The only thing I can believe with this watch is the time of day.

reviews.title: Did not like this nearly as much as my original amazfit bip watch
reviews.text:
I bought an Amazfit Bip watch a year or more ago and have really been enjoying it The app tracks all my cycling trips and the sleep monitoring is useful. Iam really a big fan of the long battery life of the older model.

This watch has a 9 day battery life which is not nearly as long as the 30 days of the original watch.

This watch meausres blood oxygen levels but taking the measurement requires holding your wrist it the right position and takes much longer that the finger tip device Ihave.

I did not exhaustively evaluate the new app that came with this phone but it did not look nearly as good as the original app.

reviews.title: Poor Measurements - Support Cannot Help
reviews.text:
After charging for 30 minutes as instructed, I paired the smart watch with the app. This was easy, and the one reason I gave it 2 stars instead of 1. The other reason for 2 stars, the interface was easier to use than I expected.

But if the measurements are not accurate, ease of use doesn't matter.

I bought this smart watch to track my heart rate while exercising—mainly walking. After recent heart procedures, my doctor wants me to keep my pulse below a certain rate. Each time I measure, the pulse differs substantially from the pulse oximeter that always agrees with my doctor's office pulse oximeter, and heart monitor. It goes as high as 90 when the PO says 52. I took multiple measurements, including taking my own pulse. The closest measurements were 60 when the actual rate was 51 or 52.

Support is through a chat on the app. I did not wait long for support, however they did not try to help me. They insisted that the heart rate changes. That I had to let it sync with the app. Not once did they address the possibility that the smart watch might be reading the rate wrong. Told me to try again after I had already tried multiple times.

Focusing on anything but the issue I am reporting does not help me. Even suggesting I exercise and measure my heart rate. Telling me the human heart rate is constantly changing. Literally, answers like they were talking to a small child.

I had high hopes for this device. It disappointed on two levels - Heart Rate, Support. I cannot recommend. Look for a different smart watch if you need accurate heart rate measurements.

reviews.title: NOT AS DESCRIBED AT ALL
reviews.text: I carefully read all reviews before purchasing this smart watch but was so disappointed. It would not hold preferences & kept defaulting to kg & cm. Would not toggle from one thing to another on app. Had to go all the way out of app & go back in before it would toggle from steps to profile to anything else. Sometimes I'd get my cell to ring on my watch, never could answer it or text back from the watch. I'd rather pay the extra & get an apple watch that actually works. I can't tell you how many times I set the preferences & saved them only to find it defaulted right back the next day.  One of the sorriest watches I've ever owned & I kept it 2 weeks before returning it really trying to make it work.

reviews.title: Sleep function is worthless
reviews.text: I really like this watch, has everything I wanted and everything works with one exception:  the sleep analysis feature is worthless. reviews.title: Works well for step counting and can measure heartrate upon request. Otherwise less than stellar
reviews.text:
This generally works well enough for exercise purposes. I didn't get the "dangerous app warning" on my iPhone, though I did get a warning that if I use the watch to display messages, then the app has access to all my contacts and the text of all my messages. I doubt I'm a target for Chinese spying so I chose to ignore that, but it's still worth noting.

I love that it's waterproof, other watch faces are available (though I couldn't figure out how to restore the original, more-helpful one without doing a full factory reset), it tracks steps and sleep, plus it's able to measure heartrate and blood pressure. Mine sometimes tells me the weather, but only immediately after connecting to my Google account on my phone; otherwise it just says "unknown" (and honestly, if I have to click extra buttons on my phone, I can just check the weather there). It has a music playback control, but I couldn't get that to work. It also theoretically connects to my phone and lets me enter a phone number, but I couldn't click "dial" so that bit felt more like a child's toy, where you pretend to call a phone but don't actually do it. But since I use this for exercise more than connectivity, I'm OK with that.

Some things are less than stellar, like their heart rate screen always shows a default chart (I don't think it ever lets you create your own heart rate chart)... and it shows a heartrate from 120-150 ALWAYS, which catches me off guard when I've been sitting at my desk for 2 hours. But I learned it's just a concept; there is no real *graph of my heartrate that I can find, just current / min / max that I can see from my phone. Or I can click "measure" to get my instant heartrate on my phone (good while exercising). Blood pressure can sometimes be measured from your phone (though it takes 1-4 minutes for some reason), and sometimes that screen disappears completely; I haven't yet figured out the pattern

It doesn't seem to measure many things other than steps automatically; you have to select each one when you're wanting to see it. Soooooooo all told it's solidly mediocre. It's good for counting steps, manually checking heartrate, and manually checking blood pressure (very slowly) on occasion; otherwise it's a lot weaker than most smart phones
