But
Be warned, it takes a little bit to set it up and understand how to understand how to download and update activity widgets. Updating of watch faces isn't too bad. Be patient and read the user guide, there is a lot of functionality you should be aware of whether you use them or not.

reviews.title: Great purchase
reviews.text:
Great, does all of the stuff running nerds love. Spotify is a hassle to sync when i want to adjust my playlists. This is especially annoying for podcast listeners such as myself. For this reason, I could have gone without the music upgrade and just used my phone but I still use the music feature a good amount for my shorter speed runs where I need the running jams!

But obviously I didn’t take a star because Garmin is the GOAT

reviews.title: Great watch
reviews.text: I bought this for my husband, an avid runner, for our anniversary. He is super into tracking, numbers, stats, etc. And he loves this watch! He previously had the Forerunner 235 Garmin but it was probably close to five years old. He had done alot of research on this one verses the newer models and this one still came out ahead and did not disappoint!

reviews.title: great fitness watch!
reviews.text: if you are looking for a smart watch, then this is not for you. however, if you want a fitness watch, then get this one! the gps tracking is great and accurate! it takes a little bit to get used to the buttons and where all the settings are, but i love that i can customize it to do just what i want in terms of display, audio outputs, etc. the band is comfortable and the watch face is a good size to see my stats while working out without being overly cumbersome (i'm a small 5'0" female). i love that it can play my spotify playlists! the only thing of note is that it will not be able to get any data such as weather, sms notifications, calendar updates, emails, phone calls, or send emergency assistance notices unless you have your phone with you and connected via bluetooth. the point of this watch for me was to keep my phone at home so those features don't work during my run, but it does do the fitness tracking and play previously setup spotify playlists, so it's exactly what i want and need. i don't use it for sleep tracking since i only wear it during workouts. love the heart rate monitoring too!

reviews.title: Sleep Tracking and Incoming Call Notification (on android) are EPIC failures
reviews.text:
Overwhelming 5 start reviews really make me skeptical that the reviews themselves are genuine....
Overall the watch is not bad but really needs functional work. The Android Dev/QA team should have some re-training/structuring after releasing this to the general public...
Sleep tracking shows me as sleeping if I am in bed relaxed watching tv during sleep hours, making it useless. I only receive an incoming call notification on the watch if my phone screen is unlocked...
missed calls come in every time..

no problems with GPS, Battery Life, Music , Bluetooth, feeds to 3rd party athletic tracking apps. all those work fine.

Not sure I would buy this again.

reviews.title: Outstanding value
reviews.text: I got this for my spouse who has an android phone.  He absolutely loves it!  He was so thrilled with it and how easy it was to set up and use that he gave me a list of the pros and cons. Pros: comfortable; stylish (never heard him use that word before lol); there's a watchface for all tastes and occasions; the features are intuitive and the charge lasts for 24+ hours.  The only cons he mentioned was that it did not give an approximate charge time and that he can't figure out how to add contacts. I've never seen him so enthusiastic about a fitness watch before and he previously disdained them. Based on his experience, I would highly recommend this one.

reviews.title: It works as a watch but most other functions are suspect
reviews.text:
This smart watch looks nice enough - someone could easily confuse it for an older Apple Watch - and its easy to make custom watch faces (I put a pic I took at an Iron Maiden show on mine). And it is jam packed with features - way more than some other watches in this price range.

Unfortunately, I have trouble trusting its more advanced features.

A number of times when taking my temperature the watch says I have hypothermia, measuring me between 87-95f. I am a 200lb man living in in Southern California and my wife won’t turn the thermostat down below 74 degrees. I don’t have hypothermia. If it can’t properly read my body temperature, there’s no way I can trust its accuracy with many of the other health features - blood oxygen, blood pressure, heart rate, etc

That step count seems pretty accurate but ONLY once I paired the watch with the Da Fit app. Before I paired the watch, it measure me taking like 350 steps while just sitting on my couch. Not sure why it would measure differently paired or unpaired but it did - significantly. I would not recommend this as a fitness tracker for someone without a smart phone (yes, there are still a few people without smart phones).

And the sleep tracker seems to at least get my sleep times accurate, though I am unsure how well it reads light/deep sleep as I don’t really trust the readings from it’s health sensors. I want to believe its doing a good job. I like the way the app presents the sleep timeline and information. But I just don’t know if its accurate because the watch thinks I have hypothermia.

As for the non-health related functions, they are pretty spotty too. I stopped receiving text notifications after a couple days and could not get them to start back up again without completely disconnecting the phone from the app and starting over again.

Pros:
- Looks like an old gen Apple Watch.
- Customizable face
- Lots of features
- Doesn’t technically *need* a smart phone for many features
- Step counter seems accurate when paired
- Great battery life for a smart watch. I wore it for 5 days without charging.
- Nice app

Cons:
- Highly inaccurate step counter when it is not paired
- Health features are unreliable
- Notifications are unreliable
- The speaker in the watch sounds terrible
- Vibration function is weak and easily missable in active situations
- Sometimes the watch doesn’t ‘wake’ from sleep as easily/instantly as it should. I find myself having to give it an extra shake to wake it almost every time.

reviews.title: Great affordable smartwatch
reviews.text: [[VIDEOID:52a9c3b58a7816ac48b831c65b3aa6ca]] This is a great smartwatch at a reasonable price. It works really well, making and receiving calls, and all of the other features. It is lightweight and charges really fast. The battery life is really good too. You cannot beat the price. Great value and highly recommended.

Down to what and how you reply via messages.

reviews.title: Love this watch
reviews.text: Nice looking watch with accurate steps. I love the gps feature where it shows your walk on a true map on the app. Nice visual. Heart rate is very accurate as well. Haven't used music feature as much as I thought I would. Garmin makes a nice watch. Highly recommend.

reviews.title: Heart rate way off
reviews.text:
The main thing I bought this for is to monitor heart rate while hiking. Its reading is way off for me - as confirmed by a pulse ox and manually counting. The watch kept telling me my heart rate was over 100 just around the house. I have nsvt but my heart rate generally runs low. So I'm very sensitive when I have palpitations - when this watch kept saying my heart rate was over 95 I wasnt buying it. That brings into question any other readings or parameters.

I find the watch annoying and frustrating to use. The watch face does not interact very well for me. I'm constantly trying to tap it and it wont register so then the screen shuts off. Another annoying thing is it tells you to start moving around when I'm doing housework. I guess you can shut that off but I've really lost interest. Hopefully Garmin can offer some fix for the reading since its past the return date.

The positives - watch is comfortable and I don't wear jewelry. I forget its on. Its a large size so its readable if you have vision issues. I've had no problem with that.

reviews.title: Best gift ever
reviews.text: Bought this for a 9 year old. It’s amazing. It has so many things on it and is easy to use. She shows it to everyone who will look at it and she feels like it’s just like her big brothers and sisters watches. Very happy.

reviews.title: 2G is Dead
reviews.text: This watch says that it utilizes a sim card with 2g service. This service is nearly dead everywhere. The sim card area in the watch is a little tricky to figure out. You have to open the back and then lift up the battery slightly. The sim card slot is located under the battery. You have to slide(left/right) and lift up the metal sim card cover like a door. Insert the sim card and lay the metal cover down over it and slide it into place to lock it. This watch is not waterproof. The watch works as specified except for the 2g calling. 2g service is not available in my area, so make sure you check if your area still has it. You have to buy your own sim card and they recommend Speedtalk service. Check their coverage map for 2g service.

reviews.title: Huge disappointment
reviews.text:
I am a big supporter of Polar products, my M400 was an absolute beast. I've since moved on to the Vantage V and it's by far the best training watch I've ever owned. This watch was a mess from the start...

I can't in good faith give this anything but 1 star, which it earned because of the HR monitor built in and I didn't seem to have any issues with tracking or accuracy, but that is pretty common faire these days and warrant just 1 star. I was just so damn tired of the HR strap that this was great at the time.

The power use or battery life (could never figure it out) was complete garbage. I understand that the target demo for this watch was never the ultra-marathon crowd, but this thing could barely make it through a day let alone a workout within that day. I disabled the "smart watch" features, enabled the smart watch features, ran the battery dead between wears, tried to always keep it charged, etc., And nothing seemed to matter. The battery would go from full to "not enough charge for workout" so erratically that it felt like keeping this thing working was the real workout. Mid-run, EVEN AFTER DISCONNECTING FROM THE PHONE, it would drain so quickly that it was always a gamble if it would make it through a 3 hr run (tops). Also, when this thing starts dying, you lose your tracking data first, then the HR, then it's a brick on your wrist. All within about 14-15% to zero, which was also pretty erratic. The sleep monitoring features are a wash because you have to charge this thing constantly so it only makes sense to do it at night.

The 2 button layout was a failure... Swiping is great (in theory) but the screen is pretty small, the gestures awkward, "swipe to nothing" screens and such made navigation miserable. (Possibly an Android Wear issue but no one needs to change their watchface swiping in 2-3 directions.) Secondly, this is a workout watch, you get sweaty (or drenched here in FL). This renders the watch's screen completely useless and I can't tell you how many corners I stood at pressing the screen trying to resume a run, change the metrics on my screen, etc. The standard workout screen also requires you swipe down for some stats so you just give up after a while. For normal daily use, I kept changing watch faces (which were very clunky to modify) or ending up at the settings menu. An Android Wear update resolved some of this but very iffy at best.

Once said run was done, syncing became an issue. I finally figured out that if you completely disconnected the watch, turned off any Bluetooth on the phone, did the workout, then slowly added the connections back, you had the best chance of the watch properly syncing with Flow and Strava. 60-70% of the time... If you forgot, all bets were off. I don't generally run with the phone and watch, but the few times I did it destroyed the battery life because it kept pinging the watch (also may be Android Wear), even when the link was severed/watch disconnected.

Onto the smart watch features. I won't beat a dead horse with the things noted above, but other than vibrating for calls or text messages, this was mostly useless. The slow response and connection time between the watch and my Pixel 2 had me constantly talking and repeating myself to my wrist like a lunatic. Then there are the 2-3 confirmations and need for a notary to send anything from the watch.... The mic idea is a good one and I suppose having the OK Google feature might be handy, but it mostly steers you back to your phone for anything useful, so I just ended up picking up the phone and bypassing the watch 90% of the time. This of course is not to mention the drain on the battery... I was really hopeful about the wrist nav and Google maps since I travel a bit but it just didn't pan out and I continued to rely on just the phone. They also sell that as a running feature (navigation) but you've got to pair with the phone so we're back to battery concerns.

The watch itself sits in a rubberized strap for removal/cleaning, which makes it large/bulky. Was difficult wearing under a dress shirt as a daily activity monitor. The Vantage V isn't small either, but it has a more classic watch look rather than time-traveler band so it blends better and I can wear under a cuff. If this watch isn't separated and rinsed after each use, it gets funky fast. Lotta nooks and crannies in there, be sure to clean it well or smell like a locker room. The band also doesn't breath at all so I would have to take days off wearing it because a rash would form. Wearing it loosely to help with this was uncomfortable due to its size so there wasn't really a win to be found there.

Polar really missed the mark on this one and I was really bummed that this was the direction they were taking their product line. Thankfully, right at the apex of frustrations, the Vantage V came out and they redeemed themselves. It's not a small price jump and I don't know too much about the Vantage M, but literally anything would be better than this watch and the V is by far the most impressive item they've delivered on.

reviews.title: Not Rating Watch
reviews.text: I’ve spent thousands of dollars on Polar watches, speedometers, etc, for my bikes and gym. I’ve had trouble off and on with charging cables. Although they have been great to replace charging cables, they outmode their products, so they become useless even tho they still work. I had a bad accident so was rehabbing for two years and had just started training in my gym and on bikes to compete again. I just got a notice in the mail, that the online training program will no longer be available I would have to buy a Polar Beat. I still need to know V2o, heart rate zones, training zones, so many other things that helped me train to my full potential. Even my Polar gym watches don’t work. I guess I can throw them out, although they still work. That being said, they make a good product, but so many become outmoded so you have to keep buying them.

reviews.title: So much potential but not worth the headache
reviews.text: I have had this for almost one year.  Very soon after I got it, it crashed.  I called customer service and reset it.  It took awhile and I was annoyed but the problem resolved.  Then again, similar issue.  This time the bluetooth and GPS stopped working.  I have used it for months with very limited capability - to track steps and heart rate - but decided to try to do another factory reset.  Lo and behold, that did not work so I guess I will be returning it to Polar.  I bought this because the heart rate monitor was supposed to be the best, and it is very accurate.  But it seems that Polar is not able to consistently deliver a quality product.

reviews.title: Glitchy smartwatch has a mind of its own
reviews.text:
I've been using this smartwatch for about five weeks. There are tons of watch faces to choose from, but I couldn't find any with just the info I wanted at a glance: time, date, steps, and weather. I found one watch face with everything but weather and loaded that, but the watch face spontaneously changes several times a day to designs I've never selected. I don't like having to reset it with my phone every few hours to get back to my preferred watch face.

It vibrates at random times and shows me (what I believe is) some sort of prompt to reset it. Sometimes it prompts me for voice commands or makes phone calls for no apparent reason. I erased my contacts, so I hope it won't accidentally wrist-dial anyone else.

It needs to be recharged every 2-3 days — not every ten days as claimed for "Bluetooth daily usage mode" — and I'm NOT using the majority of its supposed features.

I've reached out to customer support a few times, but they say I'm doing something wrong. I'm just wearing it; the glitches happen whether I'm moving or still. Support has been no help at all. I haven't been able to find information on how to make it work as advertised online either, but at least Google doesn't blame me for the faulty product.

reviews.title: Un-binds Constantly...
reviews.text: It wont update, most of the watch faces don't download correctly. It decides on it's own when to un-bind from blu tooth. The only reason i'm not returning is because it's comfortable and it tracks my steps and tells time. Literally the only things I use. However, you do not receive messages, you miss calls, and it struggles to bind to your phone. I have had to re-install the app numerous times. When i complained to the online chat. they suggested re-installing the app. That was their only answer to any questions. Doesn't seem like anyone knows really what's going on. either way, if you want to "phone/messages" part of the watch, i highly suggest shopping for a different one.

reviews.title: Face size is great for reading it without glasses
reviews.text: I like being able to see the face and read it without my glasses. I didn't turn on any of the special features like phone, pictures, messaging, etc; mainly because it's made in China, but I'm sure I'm giving away info anyway. Unlike the Fitbit, this doesn't have a way to list and track your food intake and glucose readings. I bought it inorder to read the time, steps, etc, without glasses.

reviews.title: Great watch
reviews.text: This watch did everything I needed it to do.  It keeps very accurate time and has many excellent features.  The ones I was most interested in were the sleep tracker, heart and blood pressure monitor and step counter as these  are medically necessary.  The accuracy was top of the line.  My only issue is this watch caused the area on my skin that contacted the watch to get a bad rash.  While the rash was essentially harmless, it is caused by a chemical reaction in my body.  Not the watches fault, and I've experienced this side effect with other watches in the past.  Now I use it only occasionally and for only a couple of days at a time to still track the previously mentioned condition.  It's a great watch that I would recommend.

reviews.title: Pricey but worth it for multi day backpacking
reviews.text: I tried the Fénix 5X and returned it because it was very tedious to use the maps with buttons only.  The Fénix 7X Sapphire Solar not only solves this problem but has a massive increase in battery life and better sensors all around.  Most well-traveled trails don’t need fancy GPS watches, but I’ve been going off the trails more and more, and having an accurate GPS and not just a breadcrumb app is convenient. It beats relying only on Compass and maps only.

reviews.title: More watch than I need
reviews.text: I've had the 3 and 6x prior to this. I upgraded for the flash and the touchscreen as well as the significantly improved battery life. This thing is bullet proof. All the previous functionality through the Garmin app is maintained if not improved. I use it as an everyday watch and for my biking and hiking needs. I've also used it for swimming and SUP and have been impressed. As with previous versions, more faces will be developed so I'm not holding the slim options against it for now. Not cheap but it's hands down the winner in this space for me.

reviews.title: Comprehensive and accurate. Excellent fitness tracking device.
reviews.text: I use the Fenix 7 to track all  of my fitness activity, my sleep numbers, weather, text messages, and security around the house, music, etc..  It was too expensive for me but I'm glad I purchased it as it has paid for itself and has become indispensable in many ways.  I cannot imagine a better more functional fitness watch.  You will appreciate the battery life and all the other available functions.

reviews.title: A worthwhile upgrade from the 6X
reviews.text:
I just upgraded from the 6X sapphire to a 7X solar sapphire watch during Garmin's anniversary sale. It wasn't that I was unhappy with the old one, it's been invaluable, but there were just enough new features I decided it'd be worth a try. All-in-all I'm very glad that I did. I weighed the extra battery life from the larger solar array along with the ability to reuse my existing QuickFit 26 bands into my decision to keep the same size rather than go with something a bit smaller and, perhaps, sportier-looking. Fortunately I have big hands and wrists so it doesn't look overlarge.

Others have spoken about the smartwatch in more detail, so I'll both be brief and focus on the upgrade process instead of on the watch itself here. Given Garmin's otherwise clunky software, I was amazed at how easy it was to configure the new device, download a watch face, and port over my data from the old one. Even with the firmware and map upgrades it only took about 20 minutes, most of which was downloading stuff and reconnecting the new device to my wi-fi and phone app. All I needed was Garmin Express (on my laptop) and Garmin Connect (on my smartphone).

The bottom line is that the 7X looks great, works perfectly, has massively improved battery life, is easy to set up, and comes with a few extra cool features like the flashlight (which is far more useful than expected).

reviews.title: good but expenisive
reviews.text:
My old tracking watch was a suunto abit 2. I does the basic recording of your running, cycling, walking and show you the distance on the map when downloaded.

I was looking at a garmin bike gp map, like the 830 series. I just wanted to see streets and location as I bike and not use my cellphone. There aren't that many models that show real-time map, even the one from other brand that shows map, it lacks a lot of details or cross street. Garmon fenix 7 was the most rebus in the lineup in term of map.

Goods (mostly compared to my older suunto ambit 2:
+faster gps acquiring
+has heartbeat detector, so don't have to wear a chest monitor.
+fit nicely, I have skinny wrist and it is almost the same sixe as the height
+More detail on map than the regular fenix 7.
+battery is like around 2 weeks if I don't realy use the recording.
+convenient to have a map on your wrist, grant it is a tad small.
+tell me I have low Vo2.
+can monitor your sleep pattern, rem, deep sleep, etc.
+I was on the east coast and now back on the west coast and I didn't even have to adjust the time. Not sure If I had to adjust the daylight either.
+like google smartwatch it can send you alert on your screen.
+battery is great, since it has solar and doesn't have the bright and vivid oled screen of garmin epic. ( I bought mine instore and was able to compare both) I prefer the longer battery life. My smartphone can be fore more detail items.
+alot of good info, temp, alt, sun set heart rate you can see on the fly.
+touch screen works very well.

neutrals:
*has a flashlight led, I don't use it much. Actually I hard every use it.
*good little vibrate when you get alert.
*this is music and wallet stuff I also don't use.

Negatives:
-cost
-while the map is good, I might want a bigger cycling map later.
-compared to the garmin epic which has a brighter screen, this one isn't as bright, Seem reflect light so you can see even at night but not very bright.
-it is quit dim at times

I want to get the base model but looking at this at the store, i wanted the bigger screen, the solar power and sapphire. I scratched my watch from just bumping into things so anything less than sapphire is a no go. Is still might end up buying a cycling gps map, but this is good enough for now. price is just way too high when they add one feature over the next model for 100 more.

reviews.title: Waste of money
reviews.text: Don’t waste your money

reviews.title: I like this one better than my other smart watch
reviews.text: I have a big deal designer's name brand smart watch which has a battery life of like 12 hours max and that's with disabling just about everything!  The problem with charging that (and this) smart watch is the fact that you can't just plug them in anywhere with a regular micro usb.  They have their proprietary charging "cradle" that gloms onto the back of the watch.  This one seem so far to have a higher battery life without having to shut down every app to extend the battery life.  The only thing I would wish is that if they market these to both men and women, MAKE THE WATCH FACE A BIT SMALLER!!!  I understand about seeing/reading everything on the watch, but JEEZ it is HUGE!!!  I had to fasten it further down on my wrist/arm so the watch face fit my arm.  I'm not a tiny woman nor am I a big one, so if that's a problem for an average woman, please take note and scale it back by about 3%.  Otherwise, this is a great smart watch.  Runs on Google OS which my other watch runs on and seems to do pretty much the same things.

reviews.title: My husband LOVES this watch!
reviews.text:
I got this watch for my husband who is 6'3. This watch fits his wrist really well. He has used this for over a month before the review.

CONS (very minor):
1. If you move your hand the right way it can hit the buttons on the side and start apps by accident
2. It can be sensitive when moving your hand around and turn on the clock display/run down the battery faster
3. I don't like that the charger is so specific. It would be nice to be able to have more than 1 option to charge

PROS:
1. Battery Life: Easily lasts 1.5 days before charging and it was fine. If it runs down really low it will automatically go into battery saving mode and only functions as a normal watch. It charges very quickly
2. Style: It looks nice. The face size is a good size and easy to read. The band is silicone, comfortable and holds up well to a lot of use. My husband has received many compliments on it. You can change the clock face to a few different options and customize it to you.
3. Alerts: When you get notifications of a message or call the watch vibrates. The watch has a microphone but no speakers so you cannot have a phone call through it or play music. You can type a message or even do a voice to text using the watch.
4. Calendar: The calendar function is nice and gives notifications for upcoming events. It makes it nice when he is in a meeting especially
5. Exercise: It took a while to figure out, but the exercise tracking is nice. My husband doesn't run but does like to lift weights and do other exercise. He was even able to calibrate the watch and it will count his reps for him. It also tracks heart rate, which you can set to track throughout the day. It also tracks steps.
6. GPS: The watch has a GPS and map function. You can see where you are and toggle the maps around to see routes around you. You can also set up multiple route paths ahead if you run/bike etc.
7. Durability: My husband swam with it in a saltwater pool and had no issues, it is definitely water safe. He has hit it accidentally on a few corners/desks and the glass has held up really well, no scratches. The touch sensitivity is great, easy to control but not OVERLY sensitive.

Overall it is a great watch!

reviews.title: Luxury, time and tracking for the seasoned athlete or outdoorsman!
reviews.text:
First things first: you have to be a true athlete or outdoorsman to really want to spend this kind of money on a smartwatch when there are others, but the features on this one make it exceptional. My son has truly been able to maintain his sanity after having to leave school and fly solo during this crisis. He has thrown himself into a variety of workouts to keep himself busy since he can't socialize and thinks this watch is one of the best items he owns.

The GPS features allow him to explore routes, trails, and areas he wasn't previously acquainted with (offline too!) and the health data points are accurate. There are dozens of sports modes for whatever activity he chooses for the day and the display itself is beautiful, bright and very responsive.

I wouldn't pay this much for a watch because I prefer a sedentary lifestyle (LOL) but for the athlete in your family with a long and hot summer ahead, this is the perfect graduation gift too!

reviews.title: Great watch
reviews.text:
Absolutely amazing watch. I have and iPhone and works flawlessly. Only inconvenience is the battery, it barely make it thru the day even don't using gps or other sporty functions. It would be perfect if only
Suunto fix that, otherwise is better than the Ultra for me.

reviews.title: lastima el software del celular
reviews.text:
Este reloj tiene varias cosas interesantes, pero lastimosamente el software del celular que lo controla tiene muchas fallas, por ejemplo cuando uno agrega una lista de contactos favoritos al reloj, esporadicamente desaparece y hay que volver a crearla. Tambien es frecuente que se desconecta el programa y el reloj, por lo que se dejan de recibir notificaciones en el reloj.

Tambien hay problemas con la personalizacion del skin, donde uno selecciona una foto de fondo, la descarga al reloj y aveces despues de unos minutos u horas desaparece y toca volver a hacer el proceso.

Tambien la aplicacion del celular esta mal diseñada, algunos botones no se ven bien y es dificil encontrar como seguir cuando se quiere configurar el reloj.

Lo bueno del reloj:
- permite recibir y hacer llamadas desde el reloj ya que trae microfono y un pequeño parlante, pero hay que aclarar que necesita al celular cerca y conectado por bluetooth.
- Reporta bien la mayoria de notificaciones que recive el celular, como llegada de SMS, emails, mensajes de whatsapp, aunque no muestra emojins.

-La bateria carga en 90minutos completamente y puede durar 3 dias sin tener que recargar.

En resumen hasta que el fabricante no mejore los problemas de software no es una buena compra este reloj.

reviews.title: There are TWO ways of rating this... Garbage or almost garbage.
reviews.text:
There are two ways of rating purchases... either an overall evaluation IRREGARDLESS of the price OR... CONSIDERING THE PRICE. Considering I paid $20 for it... not horrible. BUT here are the SERIOUS flaws so far:

-The Blood Pressure monitor is a COMPLETE JOKE. "Inaccurate" is NOT the word. I tried it on several friends and coworkers. Garbage!
-You are supposed to be able to make a gesture of bringing your wrist up to view the watch and then it is supposed to turn the screen on so that you can read it. ALMOST NEVER! No matter HOW I make the gesture the only thing that works is a PAINFUL twist/shake of my wrist and then it's not guaranteed. I just use the button instead which kind of defeats the purpose.
-BUT THEN, when sleeping.... EVERY DAMNED MOVEMENT I MAKE it turns on... and waking up my wife, because it is like having a flashlight shone in your face!!!!!!!!!!!

So... EVEN THOUGH this was only $20... SAVE YOUR MONEY FOR SOMETHING THAT ACTUALLY WORKS AND WORKS WELL.

reviews.title: Great looking watch, battery life isn't what I expected
reviews.text: The major feature that seems missing from this watch is sleep tracking.  Reviews of the watch point to the limited battery life of the watch, and not being enough to track though an average night's sleep.

reviews.title: Measure your wrist before you buy.
reviews.text:
The blue silicone band was too small to go around my wrist. I called Skagen and they offered to sell me a bigger band. I told them I shouldn't have to pay extra for the watch to go on my wrist. They said since I bought it from Amazon there was nothing they could do. So sadly, this is getting returned.
I've worn plenty of watches before, and I don't have a fatty wrist. My wrist is 8 inches in circumference, which is average for a male.
The interesting thing about the size as I inspected and measured the watch, is that if you measure the watch laid out flat, 8 inches goes to the second to last notch, and it should fit fine. BUT -- the watch body itself obviously does not bend, which means in actual wear when the watch goes AROUND your wrist, you need an additional 3/4 to 1 inch for it to work.
It's basically like that one gallon jug I bought at Walmart, I got it home to make a drink mix in it just to realize that yes, it held one gallon, if you filled it to the absolute brim, at which point putting in the drink mix made it spill.
If your wrist is greater than 7 inches in circumference, I would not buy this watch.

reviews.title: Great watch, much better than my old "smart" watch
reviews.text:
I got Moto 360 several years ago when smart watches first came out and it was nice, but annoying. It was tied into everything and kept giving me alerts and so eventually I got tired of it. My wife also had a first generation Samsung Gear watch and that was about the same as the Moto.
Well, fast forward a few years and now my wife, daughter, son and daughter-in-law all have newer smart watches (Apple Watches and Fitbit) and they all love them. It was time to get a new phone, so I got a Samsung S20 FE and then decided to get the Samsung watch. I saw on the reviews that it really works well with Samsung phones and so I decided to get the Watch 3. I was looking at the Watch 2, which had a few less features and then I found the Watch 3 in the 41mm size and then found a refurbished one so I ended up paying about the same for the Watch 3 as I would have for the Watch 2.
I'm very impressed with the watch and really love it. I didn't get the one with a cell phone, it just connects to my phone with bluetooth and/or wifi, but it's really amazing. I get my messages, and can turn off the ones that I don't want and then I also get all the health apps. So, now it tells me to get off my chair and walk around and does EKG and stress tesing and Oxygen levels..
I was concerned that the 41 mm might be too small, but it is a great size for me as you can see from the pic. I have had a Citizen Echo Drive for more than 10 years and it is a little larger, but I like the size of the Watch 3 better.
If you are thinking about getting a watch, this one is a good deal right now and I believe it does work best if you use it with a Samsung phone.

reviews.text: I don't use the sleep tracking because the watch is bulky and annoying while trying to sleep. The mobile app is ok, constantly running in background.  The battery life sucks, only good for a day and sometimes a day and a half which is to bad because I do love all the things it does. I think I can answer my phone on my watch (still figuring out how) can definitely hang up on unwanted calls and can read messages.  Good pedometer and workout tool. Overall nice watch with crappy battery life.

reviews.title: I wanted to like this product...
reviews.text:
I wanted a simple activity tracker and this looked like it was perfect. There are a number of things that worked well, battery life, simplicity, matched my needs... However, the accuracy is non existent. I was at the gym working out vigorously and my heart rate was 50 and dropping. I checked it with another app on my phone and I was approaching 140. When I am at rest it creeps into the 90's. by the way, I have entered all profile info. The steps are also way off as I tested against an app on my phone.

I tried but its not worth the effort.

reviews.title: Nice looking but---
reviews.text:
Just received yesterday so can't comment on accuracy yet. Got watch set up through app with no problems. Then the maddening part-One of reasons I ordered this watch was watch face on Amazon pictures. Well, I scrolled down through all the faces on the app 4 times and the shown watch face was not even there for download-What the hell!!!!! I've ordered 6 or 7 smart watches and this is the first one without magnetic charging cable. Has this plastic thingy at end of cord you have to push watch down into in order to charge. Don't like this at all. Haven't decided whether to keep or not but not off to a good start.
After a few days another problem. Battery charge on watch shows 100% all the time even after 2 days of wearing. Impossible for battery level not to go down somewhat if not a lot. Returning.

reviews.title: Cheap watch with premium features!
reviews.text:
I own several smart watches only because I like different styles. I have to say this one is very stylish and elegant. Works very well and has tons of features. The watch band feels strong and durable.

Some of the reading features such as the blood pressure monitor is not 100 percent accurate but pretty close compared to a cuff system.

Battery last a few days before needing a charge again. It’s also IP68, has music control once paired to your phone, heart rate monitor, blood oxygen readings, call & text notifications, and so much more!

If you are looking for a smart watch that would not break the bank, then this is it! Go and get yourself one of these today! It’s highly recommended!

With morning report, you can get an overview of your sleep, recovery, training and more — as well as a picture of your overall health with heart rate variability (HRV) status (This device is intended to give an estimate of your activity and metrics). On the run, new multi-band GPS and full-color, built-in maps help you navigate confidently. And with traditional buttons and a touch display, it has never been easier to tap into your training status and know whether you’re training productively, peaking or strained. If you’re pushing toward the podium — or to the very limits — Forerunner 955 Solar is by your side with up to 20 days of battery life with solar charging in smartwatch mode (assuming all-day wear with 3 hours per day outside in 50,000 lux conditions).

Multi-band GPS is nice - which honestly is the only reason we all haven't moved back to the 945/735 - which are AMAZING watches.

The 955 is a fantastic update over the previous 9XX, 7XX, and 6XX models. This update I'd much more communicative and provides loads more encouraging updates and workout suggestions. The interface is also more fluid than previous models. The return of touch to the user interface is nice but, optional.

Definitely worth going with

reviews.text:
First of all, you must keep in consideration that this is a $50 watch. That being said I will state what I consider are the pros and cons:

Pros
Price, battery life (more than the typical 1-day of apple watches), capable of answering and dialing within the watch (Bluetooth required) and blood oxygen and heart rate sensors.

Cons
Strap does not hold to watch and you must keep correcting it (solved with another strap?), blood pressure monitor? How???, you only have five watch faces at any given time but you can only replace one of the five - the others are permanently set, you get to edit the fourth one by adding a photo

Overall, there are cheaper and better watches like the WYZE (which I own and has better quality) but lack the phone answering and dialing features.

I will be replacing the strap with another type to see if it holds.

reviews.title: Excellent Dive Computer and Smart Watch
reviews.text:
I have been wearing this for a solid 4 months, using it to track dives, swimming, running, walking, treadmill workouts, etc. In watch mode the battery lasts a long time, but for activities you will find yourself charging it after about 5-8 hours of activity use.

I was a bit worried my skin would react as I cannot usually wear anything metal unless high quality gold or sterling silver. No problems with this watch - the band is comfortable and the watch, while a bit larger than I was used to, fits well and without any reaction.

Functions while diving were flawless. You have a lot of parameter's you can set - this thing is designed for divers. It tracks entry and exit locations accurately. I wish I could tell it when my dive is starting and when done, the automatic feature is a bit annoying in this regard. However, it is one less thing to remember when you are in the water and doing a buddy check to get going. It is pretty neat to how nicely it updates the app on your phone and makes sharing easy.

Pool swimming is not entirely accurate - the watch cannot record kickboard laps, for example, so if you like to vary your workout you won't have accurate times or distances. Basically, any time you are not completing actual strokes you won't get a record.

Treadmill work - you can adjust the settings to match your treadmill readings. I found it was not very accurate and finally quit bothering to adjust it. The watch was either lower in distance or higher every time, but close enough to just let it be. At least once you leave it alone you get consistent numbers, and you can also record numbers from the treadmill if you want.

Walking and trail running features are great - I love seeing where I was with the GPS integration. I work out regularly on a measured trail and the distances are spot-on with the MK2S. There are workouts it will suggest, but I tend to stick to my own and ignore those. I was really frustrated to find my VO2 was consistently "Poor" all fall, but have seen some improvement recently with regular workouts. Kind of cool getting readings like that.

I plan to use this watch for backpacking as well - I have not had an opportunity to test it since the purchase, but my last trip my sister had a different model and it worked well other than eating power. You absolutely have to carry one or two good battery packs to charge it. I really wish this had a solar option, which I understand is in future plans, so I will more than likely upgrade when that is offered. Even so, hiking puts your wrist in the shade a lot of the time unless you are hiking alpine locations, so not sure how well solar would actually work.

All said, I love my "toy". It helps keep me motivated when I see I have been in the office too long or my scores are a lot lower. I am competitive and happy to compete against myself, so it works well. I don't use the connections, although I have considered seeing if anyone I know has a Garmin, but so far its all me :D While pricy, for someone who loves a wide variety of athletic activity, you can't beat the Garmin Mk2 in any of its versions. My husband is still trying to decide if he wants the Mk2S or the Mk2i but he will be getting one or the other. Fantastic product.

reviews.title: It could have been so much better.
reviews.text: I have so many feelings about this watch. First off, set up was a breeze. You just open your app store and get the Google app directed. Pairing and synching up your info is very easy. The watch is very beautiful! I was scared the crystals would rub right off like glitter, but I have not had any issues so far. Now for all the bad stuff.. first and foremost the battery life is terrible. I would give it 9-10 hours max. I'm not much of an app person either, so if you are then that means your battery life will be even lower. It has its own charger, so that means you'll have to carry it around with you, especially big your planning to go out after work or school which is very inconvenient. I with it was a standard C USB charger so I can just use my phone charger, but sadly that's not the case. I did an experiment to see how long the battery would last. I charged it to 100%, and left it in my desk right before bed. In the morning at 8 am, I am at 15%. Whoa. Yeah, the battery is just really really terrible. So I thought I'd just change the battery settings..well there is only one other option and that is to go into battery saving mode where all it will display is the time. That in my opinion defeats the purpose of a smart watch. Other than that, I love how I can customize watch faces by using my social media, or pick from a pre made list by Michael Kors. You can also get email notifications, download apps like Google keep to take notes by speaking into your watch, as well as use Google pay, activity tracker, weather, and pause and play music without taking out your phone. So yeah, if your okay with a short battery life, then everything else about this watch is awesome. Just giving you the real tea. Hope you found this review helpful.

reviews.title: Great feminine watch for dress up or down
reviews.text: This watch works with android and iPhone which makes this a winner in my book. It does pretty much everything my iwatch series 4 does and it looks beautiful on my wrist. Charger is magnetic and easy to use.

reviews.title: Easy set up - does what a smartphone can do
reviews.text:
My wife really likes this watch. This is the one with the glittery watchband... It comes with a magnetic charger that just attaches to the back - no fidgeting. And I was surprised at how quickly it charged.

The screen colors are great! Vibrant colors and clear graphics. The touchscreen itself can lag just a little, but overall responds very well. Neither one of us have ever had a smartwatch before and I was a little apprehensive about setting it up, but I downloaded the wear OS app to her phone and from there, it just walked us through the process. It paired on the first try and seems to be working just as it should.

She's now got it set up to check emails and can generally do anything on the internet that she would do with her phone. Then theres the added advantage of the fitness stuff... heart rate monitor, etc.

All in all, she loves it!

reviews.title: Still Searching
reviews.text:
The MKGO has the best battery life of any WearOS watches I've tried. On a fairly busy day with the app running in the background on my iPhone the whole time, I was able to wear the watch from 6 a.m. until I went to bed around 10. The other three android watches I've tried didn't make it to dinner.

But this doesn't have a speaker.

Why doesn't this have a speaker?

One of the indispensable features of my Apple watch is being able to answer a call quickly when I have stepped out of the room my phone is in. I have lupus. I can't run. People somehow seem to know to call about something important when I've gone to the bathroom or stepped out to the mailbox. I'm close enough to be connected to my phone, but not close enough to answer it.

This never happens with spam calls. Just the ones from the people I won't be able to get back to through their nightmare phone menus.

The lack of this feature makes the watch unsuitable for me, and that makes me sad, because the iPhone is a begware spamming disappointment machine these days, and I really want to move to android.

reviews.title: Nice watch
reviews.text: Shipping was very slow but the watch is nice.  Took minutes to install.  easier than my apple watch.  does everything i need that my series 4 does but is discrete and fashionable.  Love the pink color..... my favorite.  Touchscreen works fine and easy to navigate.  A great buy for those who dont necessarily want an apple watch.  I am able to sync my contacts and apps to the watch.  Tracks my heart-rate on command.  I love this watch.

reviews.text:
This VALYV K22 Military Sport Watch is packed with an amazing number of smart features and provided seamless integration with my Samsung smart phone. The display is crystal-clear, and the audio capability and volume are very impressive. In general, it’s a very handsome watch and has a very intuitive user interface. The price is unbelievably low in comparison to some of the other smart watches on the market.
I especially enjoy the built-in fitness, activity, and sports tracking features which have already proven to be invaluable while training at the gym as well as general health monitoring during my activity throughout the day.
This watch charges quickly using the included USB magnetically connected cable and the battery is long lasting once charged. The user interface is customizable through the app – I preferred the default one that it shipped with… but there are MANY other options to choose from.
I summary, after spending many years not even wearing a watch… I am very happy with this purchase and can definitely recommend the purchase of this useful product to others.

reviews.title: Quite decent for the price - better quality than I expected
reviews.text:
I was skeptical about purchasing this combo because of the cheap price and the sketchy reviews, but I'll admit I'm impressed. I only spent $22.50 for the entire combo (used/refurbished). I expected the mouse to be dirt cheap from what the reviews were saying, but it feels quite solid to me. I played some Boarderlands and some League of Legends on the combo last night and it was comfortable and they both held up well. The mouse has a dpi changer that works great. For me personally I think it may have too many modes (somewhere around 4 or 5). I personally just like having 2 or 3 because when you're in game it gets complicated to remember which dpi setting you are on and cycle through to the correct one all within a few seconds.

They keyboard isn't overly bright. It is kind of is hard to read the keys at an angle, but other than that, it seems to be a great keyboard so far.

This is a good buy, for the low price of $20-30, for a basic gamin setup.

Typing is also decently comfortable, just takes some getting used to since I am used to flat keys.

reviews.title: Amazing gaming & multitasking keyboard – improved my gaming and my everyday typing.
reviews.text:
I purchased this keyboard to go with my first custom-built gaming rig that I built around 2 months ago. I had been getting so frustrated with my old standard Logitech keyboard and I wanted an upgrade. I am not new to gaming, but this was my first ‘serious’ build, so I went with the advice of many of my more experienced friends and purchased a mechanical keyboard.

I needed a keyboard that could multitask as well. I work as a web developer, and I am in grad school for marketing – I do a lot of typing. So I wanted something that was going to last and perform in all of these uses – and still improve my gaming experience. After doing a TINY bit of keyboard research, I chose the blue switches since I do a lot more “regular typing” than gaming.

I’ve had the keyboard for about 2 days, and in that time I’ve used it to play the DOOM Multiplayer Beta, and several hours of Fallout 4. So far this morning I’ve written 2 blog posts, one paper, and now this review :D.

My first impression of this product was it was HEAVY. Not in a bad way, just in a very sturdy was that was a sharp contrast to what I had had before in my standard keyboard. Since this is a desktop keyboard, there’s no need for this keyboard to be light. The other thing I noticed was the high quality braided USB cable. I must’ve missed that feature when I ordered because I was pleasantly surprised – the USB connector is also gold plated. I did not expect that for such a low price point of around $100. (Note: I did receive a discount on the product in exchange for my honest review.)

I also received this keyboard exceptionally fast. I ordered on a Thursday afternoon and got it Saturday morning – no Saturday delivery fee!

**Important** So the package comes with a guide that is very concise – pay attention! I got confused when I didn’t get a ‘new hardware found’ notification like the manual said. However, the rest of the instructions worked fine, so it must not have mattered. I’m on Windows 10.

I was surprised to find that the shortcut keys (like for volume and track control) worked without any software at all. To access the different light settings, you just press FN and select the pattern from the keyboard itself. I settled on FN+0 – It’s a responsive setting that lights up the keys you type and then lets them fade – very cool since I don’t want to have the keyboard lit all the time. I’ll admit though – this thing is pretty, when I leave my desk I’ve been quickly pressing FN+Ins to get it to do the wave effect if I’m gonna be away for a while.

So that’s just the extra stuff – let’s talk about the performance. I can without a doubt say this keyboard has made a difference in my playing. The game mode is essential – make sure you enable that when you launch a game. The DOOM multiplayer beta was probably a bad gauge since that game is ridiculously hard anyway – but I noticed a marked difference in my performance on Fallout 4. I’m not going to pretend to be a keyboard expert, all I can say is that the response time was way better.

And I am SO glad I went with blue switches. Writing papers, I feel like an old world typist – the mechanical and audible feedback I get from typing is so satisfying. I have noticed reduced typos from ‘accidental’ slips. The audible click sound doesn’t really sound like the bulky old keyboards, it’s more of a quick, clean clicking. It isn’t loud, but it’s NOT whisper quiet, which I prefer.

Pros:
- The rubber feet keep it in place on my desk (I am one of those crazy people who don’t use a slide-out keyboard tray).
- The keyboard is study, and well made. A great value for the money.
- No special software needed to change effects and settings, everything is controlled on the keyboard, and the instructions are only 1 page.
- The game features are useful! Locking the windows key, consecutive attack mode.
- Custom patterns – this is essential when gaming. I used it to highlight the keys used when playing.
- Excellent physical and audible feedback when typing – extremely satisfying.
- The confidence that comes with the 50 million actuation lifecycle (I type a LOT)

Cons:
- There weren’t any instructions on what to do if you never got the ‘new hardware found’ message when plugging in the keyboard. This confused me ' but I figured it out. If this happens to you – just proceed with the manual, as far as I can tell, it makes no difference.
- As far as I can tell, you can’t make ALL the keys light up one color. I might be overlooking something though. This might be a con for some.

I would say this keyboard is perfect for someone like me who wants a serious gaming keyboard, but is ultimately a multitasker. You will definitely notice a difference if switching from a non-mechanical keyboard.
The quality of this keyboard has me anxious to try other GAMDIAS products, and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for an upgrade!

reviews.title: Sounds great with no mods
reviews.text:
[[VIDEOID:58cc2520e806ff1428542a1df7456920]] Assembly was pretty easy for this DIY kit. It even sounds great without any modifications. I decided to put poron switch pads on the pcb since the foam it came with did not line up properly. The feet that comes with this kit is too aggressive for my liking. I decided to remove it and put clear rubber bumpons

Did not come with stabilizers. I was hoping it does at this price point. Speaking of which, this kit can be had for cheaper on other retailers. But ordering from Amazon gave me more confidence.

My copy came with cracked and scuffed case. I messaged the seller directly and they were able to help and send me a new case promptly. They also helped with VIA setup on this keyboard.

Pros:
- easy assembly
- VIA support PCB
- great sound with little to no modifications
- south facing, per key RGB
- under glow lighting
- A+ great customer support from seller

Cons:
- price seems higher compared to other websites
- inconsistent craftsmanship
- no stabilizers included
- front of the keyboard can be wobbly with the aggressive feet riser installed

reviews.title: Excellent quality cable and connectors, but color is more purple than blue
reviews.text:
Update: Oddly enough, this did not work with a Drop Alt keyboard. It worked with a few other keyboards just fine though. Just a word of warning for anyone pairing this cable with a Drop Alt (or maybe any other Drop keyboard).

This is the third coiled cable I have ordered, and it's definitely the best quality overall. The cable itself is thick and good quality. The coil is a bit firm, but nothing too unusual. The intermediate connector is all metal and heavy. Both sides of the intermediate connector can be unthreaded: The side going to the USB-C connector, and the side going to the USB connector.

One interesting thing I noticed was that the end connectors have a color matched almost shrink wrap thickness strain protection around them. The USB side is the most noticeable, and the USB-C side is a bit thicker. As long as there is enough strain protection, I actually prefer the less bulky end connections.

The only nit is the color. Even though it looked dark purplish in the product listing, I was hoping that it would be more blue in real life. It's not, it's an attractive dark purple. I would assume the color represented in the product listing is accurate, in case you're wondering if there is any color variation from the listing photos to real life.

reviews.title: Light, snappy, like a punchier Gat brown
reviews.text:
I previously got a tactile switch sampler set and honestly loved the AJAZZ Banana more than U4 Boba and its other iterations. I liked these more than Glorious Panda and Holy Panda. I type a lot as a student, so I didn't want anything too heavy--it gets tiring. I've been using AJAZZ Banana for two days so far now and I LOVE it!

I was using lubed Gateron browns before. I wanted something punchier but not too heavy. Banana is the perfect answer to that. Actuation force is about the same to Gat browns. I have a north-facing RGB board and the lights come through Banana switches beautifully.

In answer to the other reviewer, I believe that the Banana switches ARE lubed (with what, I don't know). I have a stock/un-lubed AJAZZ Banana switch from my switch sampler pack, these pre-lubed ones feel slightly lighter in comparison. Out of the box, these feel great without additional lubing. Results will vary depending on your mech keeb setup.

Note that the switch pack comes with 46 switches, so it won't be enough to do a full board. I have a 60% board and had enough to do the alphanumeric keys and other frequently pressed keys like Shift, Enter, Ctrl, Backspace, Alt, Tab, and punctuation keys. I left my Gat browns on the less frequent keys. I have two "extra" Banana switches as backups.

Highly recommend. If you want tactile but not heavy, this is a very affordable option.

reviews.title: Bananas are excellent tactile switch alternatives to browns and blues.
reviews.text:
[[VIDEOID:dff950435419a7006b0295e50b846c44]] This review is for the Ajazz Diced Fruit Banana Switch.
I wanted to try these switches compared to a brown switch because of its similar characteristics.
These Banana switches are definitely tactile and smooth. They do have a tactile click sound and require a bit more force to actuate (not really noticeable for me because I'm heavy handed and I bottom out the key when I type). I'm not going to mention specs such as actuation force and distance because you can find that info in the product description or manufacturer's site.
I will talk about the "feeling" of these switches though because in everyday use, gaming and office work, I'm not thinking about the actuation force/distance, etc. For me it is how it feels and sounds.

So first off, these are excellent switches, no doubt. It is then just a matter of personal preference whether or not you like the characteristics of the Banana switch. For me, it is a bit too noisy. The tactile bump feels good but after using the Banana's for a while, I would hate typing while on mic because the mic picks up the keystrokes loud and clear and can be annoying for others to hear. I don't have blue switches to compare these Bananas to but I would imagine the blue switches would be worse in sound. I do have red switches to compare and the reds are noticeably quieter, I think mainly due to being linear (no tactile bump). For me and personal preference and usage, I would stick with the reds.

If you like tactile switches and are currently using a different tactile switch, I'd urge you give these Banana switches a try. See my video review where I installed these switches into a keyboard and compare to red switches, so you can get an idea of the sound when the switches are installed into a keyboard frame with keycaps on. In the video I have mistakenly called the red switches Gaterons, but I'm pretty sure they are Kailh reds with box stem.

reviews.title: Nice looking strong tactile
reviews.text:
I love tactile switches, so when this was offered for review I figured I'd give it a shot as I'd heard good things about Ajazz switches. It arrived and I swapped out the switches in my NK65 (DROP Holy Pandas) and threw these into the alphas.

In terms of feel they're a pretty strong tactile. I felt it important to mention that I was using HP's above because these feel very similar to those, just with a lighter spring. The bump is close to identical which is nice, and I prefer the lighter spring as I've been mainlining my Niz lately with 35g switches, so light is my thing right now. In terms of sound, the housing does make these quite a bit higher pitch than HP's, and I'd honestly put it in line with some Akko tactiles. Not too high to not enjoy, but higher than I'm initially used to.

Because these come pre-lubed they can be used stock, which is nice because while once I start I find lubing switches to be relaxing, but it's an activity I dread until I'm actually going. Just something about it seems beyond tedious, and to be fair, it is. Thankfully the lube job on these is pretty good and there's no ping to be heard or scratchiness to be felt. I did lube one just to see the difference that one done by hand can make, and the job on these is good enough that it makes no difference. The switch is fine as-is.

Other than being plate mount only I can't find a problem with these. The spring weight is nice and they sound and feel great to type on. I'm thinking about grabbing another set to build out a board with them in the future.

reviews.title: Kiwi switches
reviews.text:
This is a review for the Kiwi Switch from DAIDAI AJAZZ. The Kiwi switch is tactile, 50gf, and housed in glittery translucent green. If you have clear keycaps, you can see the yellow stem and a little of the upper housing.

For the Kiwi switches, you get 46 switches. For most keyboards, 46 switches is not enough and you will need 2-3 cans.

The switches come in a clear plastic can, with a screw lid and a pull tab. The packaging is cute! More importantly, the can takes up less space than the usual plastic tray, and it’s reusable.

I use Akko Vintage Whites (linear), but I wanted to try tactile switches for the thumb clusters on my ergo keyboard, so I had feedback when I pressed those keys. The tactile bump is smooth and pronounced, I definitely know I pressed that key.

I didn’t notice any difference between these pre-lubed Kiwi switches and non-lubed switches.

reviews.title: Pretty good tactile switches
reviews.text: I've tried linears and even clicky switches, but I really prefer tacticles. These are right in the sweet spot for me in terms of spring weight and tactile bump. Nice colors, if that matters to you. I got these to try out before buying a full set, and I like them quite a bit.

title: SNAP 75% Mechanical Keyboard Kit (White)
description: A stylish, 75% split The SNAP is a 75% split mechanical keyboard kit with support for 2 rotary encoders, 2 OLED displays, speaker, and RGB underglow. We took all the best parts of the NIBBLE and added some of the most popular requests: true split shift/space/backspace. The SNAP is configurable, programmable, and easily assembled. 100% through hole design The SNAP uses a Pro Micro MCU instead of a discrete micro-controller chip. It offers the fun and aesthetic of a kit without having to worry about soldering the difficult bits like USB connectors. All required parts diodes, caps, and ICs) are through-hole, meaning they're easy and forgiving to solder. underglow LEDs are surface-mount Multiple Layout Options Use the SNAP in split mode, or snap it whoa, get it?) together for a more traditional layout. Strong internal magnets hold the two sides together and magical spring-loaded pogo pin contacts mean there's no need for a TRRS cable when the two sides are attached. The SNAP supports many configurations and layouts: Split space/backspace, split shift, ISO enter, and more. Since it runs QMK firmware and uses VIA, it's easy to change keymaps, program macros, and customize functionality. RGB underglow ready 10x optional bottom-mounted SMT LEDs shine nicely through the acrylic support material. Included Top & bottom PCB Acrylic supports M2 standoffs & screws Diodes, ICs, decoupling caps, reset switch RGB underglow, speaker, magnets, and pogo pins Rotary encoder & color-matched knob TRRS cable and mini bumpons Not included 2x Bit-Cs or Pro Micro Compatible MCU MX-compatible switches & keycaps PCB-mount stabilizers NOTE: This is a kit which requires assembly and soldering! Bit-Cs, switches, keycaps, and other accessories are sold separately
features: The SNAP is a high-quality split 75% keyboard kit with tons of room for customization
Use the SNAP together, or separate! It snaps together for a traditional 75% layout or pulls apart for use as a split board
Built around a Pro Micro, rather than a discrete microcontroller. This saves assembly time, and also reduces the build difficulty
All required parts (diodes, caps, and ICs) are through-hole, meaning they're easy and forgiving to solder

RGB underglow ready: 10x optional bottom-mounted SMT LEDs shine nicely through the acrylic support material. RGB underglow is supported natively in QMK, allowing for easy programming and configuration

reviews.title: Not for the faint of heart
reviews.text:
This kit does take a lot of work so I would not recommend it as a first build, or for someone looking for a quick build.

It is also a fairly unique one of a kind kit. I don't know of other split 75% keyboards with pro micro support that also have great documentation, support and community. If you are willing to put in the time you will be rewarded with a unique keyboard, and the kit really is fun to put together for experienced builders.

I would knock down half star as I encountered some issues with the fitting of the acrylic plate, specifically in these areas:
1. acrylic plate fitting at the keyboard split edge, had to use an exacto knife
2. acrylic plate fitting with bottom screws of the PCB mount stabilizers, had to make the holes wider
3. snap magnets did not fit, gave up trying to fit these
4. components pin through the solder joints interfered with acrylic, this is expected and is easily fixable by trimming them down.

Apart from that everything worked as expected. Firmware worked on first try and I was easily able to get it working with VIA.

reviews.title: Great
reviews.text:
It meets all my needs. I got it to replace a wireless Velocifire keyboard whose internal battery was dying. I had to plug my old one in everyday as I couldn’t see the key labels without the backlight, and it’s built in battery life decreased from 5 to 1 days over a couple years. So it was essentially wired, while I prefer the wireless aesthetic.

This one avoids the backlight killing the battery life as well as internal battery degradation. I can see the key labels fine without a backlight, and it takes replaceable batteries. Battery life should be months without the backlight, and it even has a low battery warning light. No cord to deal with.

Seems well built, heavy, and doesn’t slide on the desk. Nice price point. Easy to set up. It even has multiple tilt angle (height) options, although I like it flat. TKL is great to minimize the distance to reach the mouse, improving ergonomics.

I went from brown to red switches as that’s all that was in stock, and it was an easy change, although I could tell a slight difference initially.

reviews.title: Quite Loud
reviews.text:
If you can't stand the sound of a clacking keyboard, this isn't for you. It can get quite loud, especially when you're typing fairly quickly. This is probably better for techies who like the intense sound and the tactile key interface. The lighting is also nice. I can recommend this keyboard for those who either live or work alone.

Thanks so much for taking the time to read this review. I hope the information that I've provided helps make your decision a little easier.

reviews.title: A No-Cable Classic For Writers
reviews.text:
I am not lying: This is hands down the best keyboard for writing I have used in the last twenty years. I liked the older acrylic Apple keyboard and I own a mechanical keyboard with click-switches (blue), but this one makes touch typing so much more comfortable.
I wasn’t sure if I would like the tactile keys without click, because I actually like the click. They are just very loud. Logitech’s K845 (with Cherry MX red) is a great keyboard as well, but louder and has a cable.
I wish this keyboard would be backlit though. Black keyboards in front of big screens need some sort of illumination. I got one of these USB LED lights that I plugged behind my monitor, that half-solves the problem by providing some backlight.
Still it’s awesome to write on it. It’s focus is to be a mechanical keyboard. So much that it seems that it skipped the product design. It looks like an OEM-Keyboard from 1995. That’s in a way uncompromisingly functional, but next to a modern flat butterfly keyboard it looks like someone parked an old Volvo next to a Miata.
The quality is good. The keycaps are heavy and lettering sharp. It might be confusing for some that the ‘upper’ characters are printed next to the main set in the same size.
Battery life seems not to be a problem. I am pretty much writing all day, and I’m still on the first set of batteries that came in the package.
PROS AND CONS
+ Precise keyboard for touch-typing
+ Quiet enough for shared work areas
+ Height adjustable
+ Great quality
+ Long Battery life
+ Connects via dongle, not Bluetooth (yes, for me that’s a pro. Bluetooth sucks)
+ Compact with no number pad

- Chunky design
- No backlight
- Very heavy
- Vague keycap lettering
- No number pad (*conflict*)
I can recommend this keyboard to anyone who is typing over a long amount of times. It takes a while to get used to, but once adjusted it’s less tiring than modern butterfly or rubber cap keyboards, because the keys don’t bottom out that easily, and feel better to the fingertips. I took a few photos. I hope it helps to make a decision.

reviews.title: Silent Cherry Red Switches Work Well With Family Room Computer
reviews.text:
While the cherry MX red keys are often used for gaming, I am reviewing this as a typing keyboard in a family room, where the loud clackity clack of a keyboard is unwelcome. And I find this keyboard to be a great solution for such an environment.

This keyboard paired so effortlessly with my Mac that I wasn’t even aware it happened. I checked the keys for their mapping, and found them to be as one would expect for a Windows keyboard—just the usual issue with the non-Apple standard keys near the Shift key.

It is not “full-size,” but 80% size, so it is somewhat smaller, but not so much so that you fee cramped.

They keys are as silent as advertised. And while an old-school touch typist might miss the “click” feedback of a mechanical keyboard, these keys have decent travel, so if you are typing, you will have little doubt that you have actually engaged the key. (I can’t talk to gaming with these.)

I have had no trouble with the bluetooth connection, nor the responsiveness while typing.

If I have any reliability issues, I will be sure to revisit this review as necessary.

reviews.title: These keycaps feel and look awesome (for the price)
reviews.text:
I bought these keycaps for a cheap mechanical keyboard I had lying around. I had put some cheap keycaps of a similar price but a different brand on them earlier this year. Didn't like those keycaps at all.

These keycaps have a more pleasant texture, not smooth but not quite as grainy. I love love love the greyscale color scheme, and the blank keycaps are really aesthetically pleasing. Obviously, if you can't type without looking at your keyboard you should purchase the keycaps that come with all the lettering, it probably won't take away much from your experience.

One small note, I would suggest caution when using the included keycap puller. It scratched the side of my spacebar and left a little black line. Unfortunately, it is on the side of the keyboard that faces me, so now every time I sit down to type I will see the little black scratch. So be careful when pulling these off. Otherwise, I love these colors and will definitely consider buying other products from this brand based on this level of quality for price.

I forgot to mention. I loved the packaging on these keycaps!! The other brand I bought from had the keycaps all together in a ziplock bag. This brand had the keycaps arranged in order in sleeves and it was so much better for putting the keycaps on! ok that's all.

reviews.title: You Like Red, White & Blue So Make Your Keyboard Reflect That!
reviews.text: We started doing this with our “high-end” computer buyers. We take a premium – Cherry or similar – keyboard and remove all or most of the key tops replacing them with the various colors available making a color complementary computer input device. It makes for a more interesting keyboard, which obviously is the main interface with your computer, and it gives our customers something so unique as to be one-of-a-kind. All the keyboards start with premium red, blue, brown, or black key actuators which, without exception, are the best available. That together with our customer’s keytops “artwork” gives a person something exclusive as well as offering superior functionality. The keytops come right off use the small plastic tool most of the keytop provides include with their kits and doing a whole keyboard only takes about 20 minutes. One thing you do have to watch for is the keytop height. Many times, they will make certain keys a little higher. This poses no issue unless you stick a high key in the middle of the number/letters, then this may impede faster typists. Remember each key actuator that is attached to the base of the keyboard is programmed to send a certain signal to the computer thus causing your monitor to display that letter/number or take that action. For example, if you put the “M” keytop where the “T” was that will still send a “T” to your computer and monitor. I would recommend removing and replacing 2 or 3 at a time or having a like keyboard to refer to, so the possibility for confusion is limited. All keyboards don’t have the exact layout especially in the extended section and number pad. Also, some of the higher end gaming style keyboards have extra programmable keys that are specified through the keyboard manufacturer’s software. Some of the keytop set will provide blank keys to use in these instances. Buy a couple sets and have fun making your own custom keyboard.

reviews.title: Constant spring buzzing
reviews.text:
The keyboard is very visually appealing. I do not know if my lack of keyboard knowledge is why I give this 4/5 stars, but there are a few features I do not like. Starting with the positives, the backlight (light blue not changeable) is very appealing and not hard on the eyes, the swappable red switches are nice because I like red, and the linear red switches mean it has a nice click noise when typing. Moving into the cons, there is a bit that is annoying. The most notable, and would probably lower the rating more if I wasn't nice, is the spring noises from the keys. There is a buzzing noise that is left if a key is tapped too hard. This can be fixed by buying lube, but annoying nonetheless. Another feature is the lack of hotkey commands. I write a bit of papers and I usually have multiple tabs open. Trying to hotkey a tab to the left or right side of my screen doesn't work because to use arrow keys, the fn key needs to be held and that doesn't work for the windows hotkey: win+arrow_key. Another annoying hotkey feature is the 'del' key which is fn+n. The n key is in a bit of a bad spot to use the 'delete'' function. Of course, these can all be changed by editing the layers of the keyboard, but it is a long and annoying process that I have not taken the time to do yet. The last issue is the key colors. At night, seeing the gray keys, with the backlight on, is a bit difficult. The second photo attached also has extra keys added, not all of them can be attached to the keyboard because there isn't a spot for it (a bit weird but ok).

Pros:
nice backlight (not changeable color)
clacking linear red switches
extra switch colors

Cons:
Spring noise
keyboard's default button layer
hard to see switches at night

reviews.title: Check Your Computer First
reviews.text:
I sure hated to send this beauty back to Amazon, but I gave it a fair trial and I'm just not satisfied, and here's why.
It's a beautiful piece of machinery/artwork and weighs in at about 10 lbs. The keyboard glows in such a way that it will illuminate your work area in a dark room, and you can adjust the brightness up or down or off.
No, my complaint is with the speed at which it reacts. This keyboard has to keep up with you, possibly in order to mimic an old fashioned Royal or Underwood. I'm used to a $30 Logitech wireless that I can wag to the kitchen with my laptop. I don't like to use the laptop keyboard and scroll pad, I like a separate keyboard, it's faster for me. I find myself correcting errors constantly, and it slows me down, but I'm no stenographer either.
This Azio is Bluetooth, but not all computers support it. My 6 year old Toshiba doesn't, so I have to use the USB connection cord and block a precious port full time.
What a shame, it sure is elegant, and a lot of folks won't care about the perceived lag time.
The star rating posed a problem for me because I'm trying to be honest about my needs and I realize another might be perfectly satisfied.
This brute is expensive, and I'm not inclined to spend north of $700 for a new computer when I don't need one, just to support it.

reviews.title: Great Keyboard - Bad Reliability Plus Non-Existent Support
reviews.text: Ordered this roughly a year ago. Started having problems with the mouse within a few months, with the mouse not holding a charge. Got the product replaced under warranty. Replacement mouse never would connect via the USB dongle consistently. 10 months in or so, my keyboard started acting up and, despite being plugged in via USB-C on my desk, continually shows out of power / red light. When I move it to Bluetooth it strangely works, so it can't be out of power. Reached out to Azio support and got crickets. Now have a nearly $200 set of pretty chrome and leather and plastic paperweight. Looks great, fabulous when it work. Sadly that's not very consistently or long. I've got cheap keyboards that lasted multiple years easily.
