reviews.title: Nice manual keyboard with a lighter touch.
reviews.text:
This review is for the Pwnage Ultra Custom Mechanical Keyboard: Gateron Optical Switches.

The Package was delivered quickly in perfect condition. In the box was the full-size white keyboard, detachable USB cord, keycap remover, and manual.

Setup was plug and play, no additional drivers needed for Windows 11. The keyboard replaced my 105 key Cherry Blue switch manual black keyboard... which has worked very well with just basic cleaning for 5 years. Compared to my old keyboard this keyboard adds multi color, and some very intense graphics, should you choose to use them... I see videos already posted for this product cycling thru the graphics available so I will just show pictures of the static color I have chosen.

The Red Optical/Manual switches on this keyboard are a little quieter than the blue cherry switches I am used to – but they are by no means quiet…it definitely has the tap, tap, tap sound inherent in all manual keyboards The press seems very easy... much lighter and easier than the blue manual switches I am used to. And so far, I think I prefer the red optical/manual switches on this keyboard. Of course, typing is very subjective to taste and your mileage may vary.

Overall, I can honestly say that I approve of this keyboard, and will keep this one as my everyday keyboard, unless, of course my wife steals it for her home office workstation… she has after all been eyeballing it.

reviews.title: Overall an excellent full size keyboard
reviews.text:
Unboxing was fun. Nicely packaged. Keyboard is nice and large, a little too large for my tastes coming from someone who uses a 65%. But good for every day use and office use with a little side of gaming in the evening. Switches are nice and the RGb effects are plentiful. I think being able to switch the plates easily for those who want a quick easy solution to being able to completely change their keyboard without having to spend the time and money to build a completely custom one one.

Definitely a great full size.

reviews.title: Gaming all the way, I could not use this for extended typing... loudness lol
reviews.text:
This keyboard is very well made, has good heft and stability to it. The keyboard includes a braded USB-C and a key cap remover tool. The keys feel really good when gaming, the input is instantaneous and the feel and travel is really smooth. The only downside for me it is that it is very loud. I use this when my wife is around and she is immediately annoyed, lol, so I only use it when I game on my own. That being said, this is my favorite keyboard. I love all the RGB patterns, (check video). I love the feel of the keys, when I game I feel that is just the right travel distance and feel for my taste. The rear pop out legs help me put this bad boy at the right angle. The finish is really even and dark, the keys are not your typical white on black, it is more of a clear or light grey, this makes the contrast a little harder to see what key is what, so if you don't type well and need to reference the keyboard visually it might be a harder to see. All in all this is a very good entry level keyboard and it is very budget friendly.

+ RGB Great patterns
+ Hefty and stable
+ Silky smooth keys
+ USB-C braded cable
+ Mac / Win compatible
+ Black finish is matte and clean
- Loud Keys

Hope this was helpful!

As to the keyboard, it is beautifully white and has top-of-the-line red key actuators. With these you get a definite "click" when you hit the keys informing you the character has been chosen. The keytops supplied are also all white and they supply a keytop pulling tool, obviously expecting you to switch out some of the keytops to suit your taste, making this superior quality unit fully customized to your taste.

I think the stems could fit stabilizers a little better seeing as if I push a bit too hard on one side the other lifts up at times. Overall I'd say they're worth the money, but don't go expecting super high quality or anything.

reviews.text:

I put these keys on my Glorious Pro keyboard and am in love. Now my experience is limited to the Kinetic Labs Whale keycap set and a cheap knock off from the China Amazon that are in OEM height, so not a direct comparison. These keys have the same build quality and sound as the Kinetic Labs set at almost 1/3 of the price.

I'm not an expert but I did take a picture of the spacebars and it does appear that the blue version may be warped slightly or disfigured, I don't know. I took the picture incase it helped. Outside of that, to my untrained eye everything else looked perfect. Gorgeous set.

I liked the options this seller had in other keycap sets, so I used this set as a trial run and was not disappointed. I will be looking to order other colors in the future.

reviews.title: Only the 3 switches above the arrow keys are hotswapable
reviews.text:
Ganss ALT 71 Wireless/Wired 2.4G + USB Mechanical Keyboard with Cherry MX Brown Switch for Mac and Windows, PBT Keycaps for Desktop and Laptop Computer, 71 Keys (Can Be Customize to 68 Keys Layout)

This Keyboard is weird. I don't know why they made only the 3 switches above the arrow key hotswapable and not the others. I like the customization of the layout, but c'mon. The keyboard sounds terrible and with the limited tuning I was able to do, it sounds and feels a bit better. The wireless works fine and doesn't lose connection. The included keycaps are not great either. I replaced those straight away. If you are looking for a keyboard to mod this is not it.

reviews.title: Compact and functional at a premium price
reviews.text:
The Ganss ALT 71 keyboard is good, but not good enough to justify the price tag. I do really like that it's wireless--the dongle works well and I didn't experience any lag while typing for work or gaming. The keyboard even came with batteries, which was great! The wired option works well, too.

I didn't love the keycaps and replaced them right away with some that I already had, which are more smooth and have a broader key surface. That's a personal preference thing, though.

I've never used clear switches and was excited to give them a try. I usually use red switches, and found the clear switches to be very comfortable. They offer more resistance and shorter travel than red switches. Once I switched to lower profile key caps, I found the noise level to be slightly quieter as well. There is a bit of spring squeak when typing, though. There are also no feet on the keyboard to adjust the height/angle of your typing surface.

Only three of the switches can be removed, though I cannot figure out why you would... It removes functionality (why would you want a page up key, but not page down?). The only reason to do this that I could think of was to more distinctly isolate the arrow keys for gaming.

The keyboard came with a keycap puller and I was able to replace all of the caps without too much trouble. The keyboard is nice and compact and I do like that it's wireless. But for the price, it's very strange that there's no backlighting or truly hot-swappable switches.

reviews.title: Cherry Switches, dual USB/wireless, but missing other features
reviews.text:
I read the specifications several times for the Ganss keyboard, thinking I had missed something. Some things, in fact. The basic product -- the experience of typing on it -- is solid, and it's good to have both wireless and wired alternatives in the same keyboard.

But . . .

At this price point, you are going to do without several features that you might want. See CON.

But what you do get is a compact (no numeric pad, no function key row) keyboard whose touch I would judge to be halfway between gamer ("clacky") and laptop membrane-like (near-silent, minimal key feedback, short throw). The keys are durable, rollover-tolerant, likely top of the line at the key level.

PRO
- Compact
- Durable, with keytop replacement tool supplied
- Well-considered "middle feel" tactile design
- Status lights are below the keyboard, which makes them more visible when accidentally set (e.g., caps lock)
- Molded plastic cover will probably last awhile

CON
- Better keep the supplied manual (an annotated 2-pp diagram), as you may not be able to figure out key combinations after not using this for awhile. Function key access, for instance, is anything but intuitive
- Limited programmability
- No USB hub/auxiliary port (for mouse)
- Not backlit (requires different model from this maker)
- Tilt feature I usually use didn't work well for me YMMV
- I miss having an alternate ENTER key on the right edge somewhere
- The DEL key is oddly placed

Despite these limitations, you might like this model for the feel.

reviews.title: There are Much Better Options for the Price
reviews.text: This board was okay but at $100 it's hard to justify it's price. The build quality is similar to your run of the mill gk61 or sk61, so it's a plastic tray mount case with an some kind of metal plate not sure if it's steel or aluminum. The board isn't hotswap aside from 3 keys in the nav cluster on the right side of the board that can be covered with a plastic plate. I personally think Ganss was really brave to offer Cherry MX Clears as an option as those bottom out at nearly 100g but I'm here for it. The acoustics of the board are pretty bad this thing is loud and I would not recommend it for an office environment unless you really hate your coworkers. The stabilizers were sufficiently lubed and fit well in the plate so they didn't rattle. The keycaps seem like a cheap dye sub set and weren't terrible. The board lacks any kind of backlighting which I find strange as it has north facing switches which is usually the reason to have them that way otherwise they can interference with row 3 of cherry profile keycaps. The board has Bluetooth but doesn't have a rechargeable battery included, just 2 AAA Duracell batteries which I will give them credit for as Duracell is a good brand. Overall the board doesn't really do anything to justify it's steep price point there are much better boards in it's price range that include better switches, backlighting, and way better acoustics.

reviews.title: Compact, Well-Made
reviews.text:
This super-compact mechanical keyboard has a solid feel for a plastic keyboard at this price point. The travel and build quality of the keys feel great, and as expected for MX Clears (which are softer than other Cherry MX switches I have used). Having a detachable USB-C cable plus wireless is the best of all worlds for connectivity and long-term usability, and should be the standard for all keyboards moving forward.

I prefer a larger footprint for my daily driver, but this is a great keyboard if you need portability or work in a small space, and still want the benefits of Cherry MX switches.

n.b. The keyboard is not backlit, which increased battery life, but definitely reduces its "gamer chic" vibe.

reviews.title: Nice keys, font size a little horsey
reviews.text:
Note: I chose the Grey/Beige set. This set (YMDK 96 84 ANSI ISO Key) went on just fine, and are a great frugal find.

I bought these for an relatively inexpensive TKL mechanical wireless keyboard (RK87G) because the OEM keycaps were set in a truly fugly and illegible typeface.

These YMDKs feel good, and have a slightly deeper "thunk" when they bottom out. The two-character keys are typeset vertically, as Underwood and Remington intended. Although the font size on most of the keys is a big, they are fine and give the keyboard a bit of a homemade retro look.

NOTE Specific to the RK87G: This YMDK set does not have a ScrlLk key. The right Shift and right CTRL on this set are a little too small, so I just left the old ones on. I also left the OEM ScrlLk, Page Up, and arrow keys on because they have symbols for controlling the RGB LEDs. If you use the RKs function keys for app and control shortcuts, you may want to leave those on as well.

May 30, 2021
I've had these for a little over six months now. Still a great value set the money. I installed them on a keyboard I use for hours on end nearly every day. The printing on the beige keys hasn't faded, but I've noticed that the grey keys with white printing are beginning to fade. I'm not taking any stars off because before I purchased these I had already read other reviewers who had the same experience.

reviews.title: More updates than microsoft!
reviews.text:
First of all, its a DUMB keyboard, meaning, you cant save the profile TO THE KEYBOARD... For this price, you think they could have bout a 64k ram chip in it...

So this means, that every time I hit my KVM, it goes to default, then I have to open the software to get my color profile back and EVERY SINGLE TIME I OPEN IT... It has to update the software... EVERY FLIPPIN DAY!

I hate this keyboard! 3 stars are too many!

Seriously, ASUS, I love your gaming laptop, but your software is garbage... Hire better programmers or even better, let me move the color profile to the KEYBOARD, so I never have to load your crappy software ever again!

Then after this loading screen loads for 5 minutes, I end up having to restart my computer to get it work again...

Seriously, this keyboard needs more updates than M$ and you have to restart your machine to use it after... if you want a keyboard that sux less, see 2nd image...

Final Update: I just updated the software and now it wont even connect to the keyboard anymore... Im DONE! Just ordered a DROP ALT, it has build in memory, so I can program the color profile and its WRITTEN TO THE KEYBOARD, no more daily updates, and constant frustration to get the stupid software to work, just so I can keep the color profile I want to be ALL THE TIME...

Good hardware, keyboard is solid, software ruined the product!

reviews.title: The RGB lights will sleep and won't wake up... annoying
reviews.text:
I bought this keyboard both for work and play. I use it for work during the day, and play games during the night. It's been a couple of months since I got this keyboard, and I love it. I love the form factor, I love the feel typing with it. Excellent for gaming. But with all that said, there is one annoying thing that warrants it to get 3 stars... the RGB lighting.

I got this plugged in to my 43 inch Aorus gaming monitor's KVM. When I work, this keyboard controls my work laptop, and when I game it controls my gaming PC via KVM. The RGB works fine on both computers, but when the computers goes to sleep and/or the screen turns off, the RGB also turns off. It's fine when it turns on when I wake up the computers, but majority of the time the RGB lights won't come back on from sleep, and that is annoying. When I manually lock the desktop, the RGB lights on the keyboard turns off, but when I unlock the desktop, the RGB lights won't turn on also. I thought something may be wrong with the KVM, but I tested the KVM using my Keychron keyboards, and they work fine, which means nothing is wrong with the KVM of the monitor. In order for the lights to work again, I have to unplug and re-plug the USB cable. It does the same thing even when in wireless mode.

I honestly like this keyboard when the RGB lights are working, and right now just keep on checking if there are new firmware for this keyboard everyday hoping that the annoying sleep bug will be fixed. So, 3 stars for now.

reviews.title: Nice keyboard bad software
reviews.text: The armory crate software is the worst I’ve used in my life. The actual keyboard is fine.

reviews.title: best keyboard I’ve ever had
reviews.text: I love this keyboard, had no idea that the type of plastic material the keys are made of makes a huge difference in how it feels and how enjoyable it is to use. The mechanical switches are great too but I sill really like this keyboard for the texture of the keys. I have nothing negative to say hope to have this keyboard for the next 20 years.

reviews.title: x2 Review Update - Great Keyboard
reviews.text:
Works great. Anyone looking at this keyboard already knows what it is and what it can do. I've heard it is a little more expensive than other brands that are doing the same thing. I don't know or care. I wanted this one, this brand. It's been flawless since purchase. - older review

8/26/22 - Update
Original keyboard is still working flawless since purchase. This keyboard has been working so well that I actually ended up buying a second one! I jump between multi-devices daily. Running the USB-C (charging cable) to one device and placing the Bluetooth dongle in another allows you to easily switch between them. You could very well run a USB-C cable to all your devices using color coded cables with some cable management have a USB-C (fountain like) connected to your desk and rotate through the cables to match the desired device.

This keyboard runs flawless on every device I have associated it with. Zero issues in regard to connectivity: brands, operating systems, etc.

Have to keep in mind that the heart of this keyboard is gaming. Very fast and instant with zero noticeable latency & lag. Wired - Bluetooth you will not be able to tell the difference. Large hands might get a little cramped. I've learned to work through it. The pros outweigh the cons. The only cons I can think that others would consider as such, would be the size and price. But you can't really fault it for that and here is why. 1) It's a 60-65% keyboard and you knew this prior of purchase. You can't fault it for what it is and its targeted users. i.e. "Well, it's not as comfortable on the arthritis as a full-size split keyboard" - duh... 2) You get what you pay for. There are more expensive kb's as well as cheaper. Rog Falchion sits nestled in the lower mid-range tier on pricing. Blue Clicky are on sale for $99.99 and the Red Linear are $129.99. That is a very fair price considering what is packaged.

Rog software is not the best but isn't the worst either. I have had a lot more issues with my Logitech software in comparison to what has basically been a stress-free experience with Rog. The software is not technically required to use the kb. If you want to make customizations such as changing the kb color, etc. You will have to download it. There are stock functions (modes) built-in that may suffice enough for some users or turn the RGB completely off to utilize maximum battery life. ** Side note, I'm rarely ever in a need to charge it. I leave RGB on at all times. I've left it on overnight, etc. The physical need to charge in order for me to use it is so far and few in-between that it feels like a chargeless keyboard. If you use a USB-C to connect to another device the Keyboard will charge while doing so.

Mine has been pretty damn resilient too. I have unintentionally knocked/thrown this keyboard via airborne a few times from my working area onto vinyl flooring. Besides a few small scratches on the case, little harm was done each time.

So, what do we have here?

We have a mechanical keyboard with MX Cherries. One has Red Linear switches and the other Blue Clicky.

I prefer the Blue Clicky!!! This keyboard is oh, so satisfying.

Yes, they are loud - oh no! However, no one cares. You don't purchase mechanical keyboards while pretending to be an office ninja. That is why I prefer the Blue Clicky over the Red linear.

The Red linear knows it's loud but tries to be quiet while at a higher cost. It delivers what feels like a finger-press to the depths of the Mariana Trench with an awkward/muffled low-toned like sound to match the embarrassment it is hiding from.

The Blue Clicky fully embraces its true self while doing so at a lower cost. It delivers a more satisfying user experience with touch and sound. Each key press has an instant-mechanical-click. Letting you know, "Hey I am here!" Delivering the sound and feeling of reaching the finish line with each finger press.

Overall - It is a wonderful keyboard. The Falchion will never make you feel like you wish it had more abilities. It will only make you feel like you want more of its capabilities. - Hints me buying two

Regardless of your switch preference you can't go wrong with this purchase.

This is my first board build and I used Kahil Box Navy blues. The board feels amazing and well put together. Great first kit to get started. Can't wait to build my next board and get some more parts to form YMDK. I would choose the faster shipping if you are like me and hate waiting. I did get the board quicker than the projected date.

reviews.title: Fits Royal Kludge 90% and Keychron K10!
reviews.text: I like all the extras. The quality of the PBT is grainy in texture, so if that's the kind of thing you're in to, then these won't disappoint. Not shine through, although the advertisement never claims they are. No light is coming through these from your board. The XVX profile is nice. Many extra key options- this set has fit several boards from several brands- not something you see for the price point! Quality printing and nice font on the caps. The keys feel good to type on when used with a clicky or linear switch. They are a bit heavy, so a lighter switch wouldn't be a bad option. I don't like to use these on tactile switches due to the mushy that these caps add to the keys. O Rings did not help these keys IMO.

reviews.title: Random assortment of loose keys
reviews.text: Expected a full set of keycaps, instead received a box containing three bags of loose keys, missing multiple letters, numbers, function keys, etc. Might be good for a concept art project, but not for a working keyboard.

reviews.title: Some keys misaligned with switch stems.
reviews.text: The keys have a nice touch, sound and printing however some keys, particularly my "O" key are a misaligned with the switch stem causing it to stick up a little higher than the "I" and "P" on either side. I did not mistake a "0" for an "O".

reviews.title: Seem to be good quality, but I hate the XVX profile
reviews.text:
These seems to be good quality keycaps, I have no issues with them at all. I have put them on multiple boards now, and I haven't had any break or scratch. Colors are accurate and legends are clear. No complaints there.

My one gripe is the XVX profile. It takes a lot of getting used to (like any new profile would), but the surface area of the keys is much larger than most other profiles. Therefore, when typing, it feels as if your fingers have to travel significantly further to reach the next key. It also makes it much, much easier to fat finger extra keys. If I had realized how much more surface area there was, I would not have purchased these. However, they do look great, they were cheap, and they sound pretty good too.

reviews.title: Great keycaps, andd even better customer service!
reviews.text: I wanted to find some PBT keycaps that were double-shot and gave some aesthetic flair to my $15 108 full sized mech keyboard with brown switches.  They fit just fine, and give a different, yet, pleasing sounds and feel to the keyboard.  I wanted non-see through keycaps in order to hide most of the LED rainbow glare.  The backlit effect is, again, very pleasing.  The keycap set that I originally ordered was missing the F9 key.  I contacted their customer service through Amazon, and got a reply back right away and arranged for a replacement set to be shipped out.  Got it the new set the day after, and it was complete.  Will purchase from this seller again whenever I need/want new keycaps.  Very confident if something is wrong, will be taken care of in a timely matter.

reviews.title: Where's the documentation?
reviews.text: Very heavy keyboard. Certainly doesn't feel like a mechanical keyboard. The tiny insert offers ZERO CLUES as to how the keyboard is supposed to function, ie there is no documentation. The web site reads more like an ad, no clues there, either. The flashing color LEDs remind me of a 1980s video arcade game. You can reduce the brightness down to zero but that's about it. There's a really ugly and difficult to read quasi-sci-fi typeface used on the key caps. The keyboard itself is quite nice, quite heavy. Little kickstand-type feet if you want it angled. A small plastic ramp is included if  you want to rest  your left hand. What's missing here is a MANUAL of some kind. Even a PDF would be just great. Otherwise it's a mystery how this keyboard is supposed to work, what the features are. Somebody blew it. It's nicely designed with some interesting features, but unless you enjoy hardware sleuthing, how are you supposed to know what works, and how it works? Rather maddening. So I don't see this being used, I'll go back to my older keyboard which actually has mechanical clickity click key responses. It's baffling that with  the attention to detail paid to this keyboard that they wouldn't include or provide some DOCUMENTATION. It's basic.

reviews.title: This is an amazing keyboard! With this and the mouse, I am ecstatic! Don't hesitate on this! Can I give it 6 stars?
reviews.text:
Oh wow! I have waited for several days to review this because my computer was broken and I had to wait for a service tech to drive down and DO something, ANYTHING, with it. When the box came, I was asking myself what it was because the box was HUGE, The inner box was still pretty big, but not huge, It provides a lot of information--including that the keyboard is waterproof, nice since I'm a klutz--and something I'd either not noticed or had forgotten. In side that was a plain black box with a Bloody hand--or is it a hand print? The lights are cool, and the bloody hand lights up on both the keyboard and the Bloody Mouse I got a couple of days before the keyboard arrived. The fast key response is amazing. Even though I'm not a "gamer," I'm not a total computer novice, having gotten my first one with a gig on the hard drive--custom built--and my co-workers said I'd never use all that memory. Right. Now, my phone has 64 times that with room for expansion and does more than that first computer--or the second--and maybe more than the fifth or sixth. I still have to download the software, which will probably wait until tomorrow, but I could not wait to start playing with this. It will take me a little bit to get used to the clicking keys, but I am finding I don't mind it, after just writing this much and, well, it does bring back memories. Also, they help me notice if I don't hit a key quite hard enough. (My high school graduation present was a used Royal portable typewriter in a horrible shade of blue--and I still dislike blue. But, I think I can get past those memories. My parents weren't cheap. They were broke at that point in time.) And now, I have probably spent more on this keyboard, even though I was amazingly fortunate to be able to get this at a discount in exchange for my honest, unbiased review, than my family spent on that typewriter.

I didn't know what to expect of this, but read what one of the other reviewers said about not needing to be a gamer to appreciate this and I can see, already, how true it is. My typing is faster and I'm just using this for the first time. And now with this and the matching mouse, I can dare to try some of the things I hear about. No, even with this pair, I won't have the fast response time of someone a few decades (well, quite a few) younger, but it will sure help even the playing field for me. I am so eager to put this through its paces and I am SO happy with it, even this soon, that I have no problem recommending anything with the Bloody name on it. And I did live in New Zealand for a while, so know that Bloody is not quite considered a polite word. Too Bloody bad. I love the keyboard and mouse!

Addendum: Two days along and I'm even happier! Wow! This thing is great!

reviews.title: Keyed Up
reviews.text: I don't do a lot of gaming but this is nicer than the old Dell keyboard I was using.  It's kind of loud but otherwise I haven't had any problems typing.  The keys light up when the computer is on and during idle times it puts on a little light show.  I use the old home row technique and haven't seen any increase in errors.  Hunt and peck types might feel differently. I already have a wrist rest so I haven't used the one that attaches to the keyboard.

reviews.title: Nice keyboard even if it's not mechanical
reviews.text:
Nice keys that feel similar to mechanical. Spacebar is set up so you can press it on the edges and it will respond just as well as hitting the middle. Larger keys such as Backspace, Return, Ctrl, and the Windows all work fine.

QWER and ASDF keys are colored orange and have a unique, bumpy texture you don't feel on the smooth black keys. I would have preferred orange keys on ASDF and JKL; since that is "Home Row" for typists. The bumpy texture would make it easier to find Home Row without looking.

Arrow keys are the common one on top and three below configuration. The keys I don't often see are a FN key and a weird key with no text label instead of a second Windows key on the right of the spacebar. The "weird" key seems to work as if you right-clicked the mouse. Finally, you will see the Print Screen (PS), Scroll Lock (SL), and Page/Break (PB) keys placed above the numeric keypad.

Aside from the extra keys, the slightly increased resistance, lit keys, and the increased weight of the keyboard itself, there isn't much else that separates this from a standard keyboard. All keys stay lit when you type and switch to rotating patterns after a minute or two of inactivity. Hit any key and you are back to fully lit.

reviews.title: Solid and positive
reviews.text:
There is a lot to like about the Bloody Gaming LED B720 Light Strike Mechanical Gaming Keyboard. Fit and feel, construction, lighting scheme, and most importantly “mechanical keys” are all first rate.

Right out of the box, you can feel the weight of this keyboard. No lightweight here. Plugging it in, there are no issues with Windows 7 to 10 – drivers are automatically detected and the keyboard is immediately available. The keys light up with a rainbow of color, with each row presenting a different color. On this B720 model, there is no way to change the color scheme, but most people will find it pleasant. In idle mode, it presents a couple of animations, upon which any key touch will immediately bring back full lighting. Lighting is dimmable to totally “off”.

Of course, you do not purchase a keyboard like this without awareness that a variety of mechanical key types exist. My other keyboard is a Tt esport MEKA Cherry Brown with Cherry MX Brown switches. Cherry MX brown switches have a moderate travel distance, with some tactile feedback for keystroke and a definite bottom and light clicking noise. For me, Brown switches provide a nice blend for gaming and touch typing. The Bloody B720 has an Infrared Optic Switch exclusively developed by Bloody, and indicated to be closest to a Cherry MX Black switch. For me, comparing the Optic Switch to Cherry Brown switches, the throw distance seems shorter for the Bloody keys, with less resistance and the bottom just slightly softer. Click wise, it is mechanically positive, but noise wise less than the brown switch. Personally, I find both very desirable for the way I type and game, and struggle with finding a preference between “Optic black” and Cherry Brown.

On other aspects of the keyboard, the Bloody B720 comes with textured and differently colored gaming silicone keys, along with a nice little left hand support for same. The quick guide provides limited documentation and the Bloody website for software download. While I did not spend a lot of time with the software, it allows macros and some customization—although no changes to lighting for the B720.

If there is anything someone might not like about the Bloody B720 it would probably be the font selection for the keys (a bit sci-fi) along with an inability to control the lighting a bit more fully. For me, it is fine, I like the way it behaves during use and in its more animated modes.

Bloody Gaming may or may not be right about their own proprietary keys becoming popular, since gamers have definite preferences and a multitude of experiences with a variety of keyboards. I can say, that for the type of work and play I do on a daily basis, I would recommend this keyboard to anyone thinking about a mechanical keyboard. The Bloody B720 is an attractive solid keyboard providing a great mechanical key typing and gaming experience.

title: GTSP 9009 XDA Retro PBT Keycaps Set for Gaming Keyboard Dye-Sub for Cherry Mx Gateron Kailh Switch GK61/GK68 60% Mechanical Keyboard (9009-XDA)
features: ✅【What You Get】-1x133 thick PBT Keycap set. It’s only keycaps, no keyboard included

reviews.title: Space bar was too big:( still cute tho
reviews.text: The keys are so cute! I love it! The only downside was that the space bar was too big for my keyboard!! It was also too big on my brothers keyboard, so that’s a little weird. So sad about it too since that was the main reason why I got it:(

reviews.title: Really cheap look and feel
reviews.text:
These are really cheap. I know you might be thinking, you get what you pay for and these are cheaply priced. However, at the end of the day, keycaps are just plastic and the good ones are just waaay over priced.

First thing first, the actual color differs from the picture. The picture has a nice looking matcha green, the actual product is a little darker green and no where as vibrant. Also, some of the legends on the keycaps are kind of blurry. I am noticing the blurriness on all the non-alpha caps. You can tell these are really cheap and they look pretty bad.

title: Akko Keycaps Top Printed Shine-Through with ASA Profile, White Keycaps PBT Double-Shot Keycaps for Mechanical Keyboards
features: SHINE-THROUGH KEYCAPS – Deliver premium and shining RGB experiences with Akko ASA Shine-through keycap sets! Come with extremely durable and resistant double-shot Shine-through keycaps, the legend shine through keycaps brings unique and great RGB effects.

ULTIMATE CUSTOMIZATION FLEXIBILITY – Comes with Akko ASA profile, the keycap set is suitable for a variety of layouts including 61-key(60%), 64-key, 68-key (65%), 84-key (75%), 87-key (TKL), 98-Key (Classic 1800), 100-Key (96%), Alice and full 108-key size, and thus offers strong flexibility for keyboard personalization.

ASA PROFILE – Akko’s proprietary ASA profile is tailored to offer a more familiar and comfortable typing experience by matching the height for OEM profile while maintaining the aesthetics and spheric top of the classic SA profile.
PBT DOUBLE-SHOT – Double-shot keycaps are extremely durable and resistant to wear even for decades, and the legends are particularly vibrant, sharp with high contrast.

FOR MX STRUCTURE SWITCHES – Compatible with MX structure mechanical switches and mainstream keyboards including but not limited to Cherry, Gateron, Akko and Kailh. Large keys of non-standard layout & stabilizers may not be compatible.

reviews.title: Not the brightest shine-through, but for the material and price it's worth it.
reviews.text:
Akko's ASA profile is a taller profile kind of like SA. Feels great to type on and is fine for gaming if you don't mind the extra travel time on each keystroke. The finish on these has a great texture and it's PBT so it shouldn't wear out quickly. "Shouldn't" being relative since I tend to shred keycaps as though my fingers were first dipped in acid before typing.

30.00 for keycaps of this quality and for the number of keys is great especially in a hobby where everything is over priced, over hyped, and overly bogged down in group buys and pre-orders that take literal years to fulfill.

reviews.title: Shine-Through keycaps, look amazing
reviews.text: These shine-through keycaps look awesome.  They are super easy to install, like most keycaps.  It is just a bit time consuming.  I love being able to change out keys and switches and seem to collect keycaps.  These are great and sound and feel amazing.

reviews.title: That's not what I expected
reviews.text: The cable does not have the diameter of the expected coils and the aviator connector is not of good quality. I don't think it will last long.

reviews.title: Nice looking and a great add for keyboard enthusiasts!
reviews.text:
Do you need a cable with an aviator connection? No, but do you want one? Yes! I like the mesh sleave on the cable, that gives a premium look and a perceived ruggedness. I chose the grey so whatever keyboard I hook up (or any USB-c peripheral) it looks nice.

Only ding I would give it is that if the keyboard needs to be to the left the cable off the coils is on top and does not look as nice. If the cable is oriented to the right, it looks better. I don't have any major issues here, but it is something that shoudl be in the product description maybe.

Overall, really nice and glad I bought it!

reviews.title: Very nice coiled keyboard cable.
reviews.text:
The cable came nicely coiled with no flaws. Plugs are high quality and the screw connection type is pretty heavy duty I don't see this breaking. Only wished the straight part of the cable was longer.

I highly recommend this cable for anyone looking for a custom looking cable that wont break the bank.

reviews.title: Works as advertised!
reviews.text: This cable worked exactly as advertised. My keyboard has a USB c connector, and it fit together perfectly. I love the look of this cable as it neatly tucks under my desk and doesn't leave any unnecessary excess hanging around. Overall very happy with this product!

reviews.title: Decent aviator cable for my keyboard setup.
reviews.text: These cables are an aesthetically great match for my “rebel scum” keyboard build.  The connections are tight and the materials used seems like they are great quality.  I don’t really have any complaints about the quality of this product.  I think it’s important to note these are not braided cables, and have a soft rubber feel, much like you would get on any standard USB type cable.

reviews.title: Great for the look, 10 key A plus, Functional enough for device swap
reviews.text:
I really wanted this keyboard for the typewriter look, device swap, and 10-key.

The only setback is that even when plugged in via USB to the main device when waking up there is a few seconds of buffering time before being able to type at times. At first, it drove me crazy but now I notice that the green light signals when this is happening and goes solid when ready which alleviates the "let's go" anxiety because I know what's happening. I love that it pairs to 3 devices. 2 via Bluetooth and one via usb.

Another weird thing is maybe at least 1 time a week I have to unplug and plug the keyboard back in when I cannot type on my device and I know that the correct device is selected and the solid green light is on. If there were a better typewriter-style keyboard in all black and chrome with 10-key and pairs to at least 3 devices that don't have the buffering when swapping device or intermittent typing issue, I would have picked it but it doesn't exist.

Overall 4 stars.

Update:

Key caps are already falling apart after 3 months use! My heart is so heavy it’s so noticeable and I cannot find a replacement key hundreds of dollars down the drain.

reviews.title: Keys are dim
reviews.text: I sent mine back because I couldnt see the keys when I was 2 feet away. The backlight shines more between the keys than through them. It was ok in a very dark room but a dim indoor setting they were impossible to see unless you were right over the keyboard, even with the light turned all the way up. They were also kind of wobbly, cant see anyone typing fast on this. I bought a querty writer and the quality difference is huge.

reviews.title: Love the retro feel and "noise"
reviews.text: Love the retro feel and clacking noise.  Typing accuracy has improved!  The ability to switch between 3 devices is extremely convenient!

reviews.title: Good Keycap Set! Beat Expectations
reviews.text:
I had initially bought this keycap set as a placeholder for my GMK Samurai Keycap set that I was set to receive. However, I had learned that Drop would ship them in late July, and since I was unsure if I was getting a refund, I bought this keycap set as a placeholder.

This keycap set broke all expectations that I held for cheap keycaps. They feel to be of good quality, with a high-ish thock sound that is what I wanted. Overall, it is a good keycap set that I would recommend to people if they are looking for good quality and good-sounding keycaps.

Also, I did get a refund for the GMK keycaps so I will be sticking with these keycaps, although they don't match as they were not meant to pair together and were rather a last-minute decision.

reviews.title: OMG great keycap set!
reviews.text:
I have been looking for these sets for the longest time, outside of GB and these guys have made a solid replica. i am so impressed with the quality and feel of these Botanical keycap sets that the premium sets can remain on the shelf. They look so nice and very very close and clean to the originals.

the only way you can tell that they are not GMK is by looking at the bottom. The dye-sub is a little weak in the finish but you never look under the hood.

If you like the greenery landscape or the color great fanatic this is the best set. It's super clean, subtle, and sounds great! I have this set on my KBD67 Lite and it sounds so much better than my ABS keycaps i paid $80 for. The texture is also very nice and I seem to be keen on this rough like texture than the ABS smoother feel. It kind of is matte if that makes sense. The legends on all the alphas are uniform, no thickness issues. The ,.? and other modifiers might have a thinner font but negligible.

I can't say enough what a great first impression these sets have given me and if they produce an "Oblivian" replica i'm jumping on it as well. Pictures to come, after I pickup my desk from all the loose keycaps.

reviews.title: Won't pair with M1 Macbook Air, works well with Dell XPS 9370 and Acer Triton Predator
reviews.text:
For windows users this keyboard is great. The brown switches feel somewhat similar to higher end cherry brown switches and I had no complaints with the build quality. There are various lighting modes (my favorite is the single keystroke light trail).

I was slightly disappointed with the Bluetooth not working on my M1 Macbook Air but I had no other issues with various windows laptops. There is some latency noticeable when waking from sleep but it's not too big of a deal. For gamers it might be though so you'll want to use it wired.

Overall it's a good deal for a mechanical 60% bt keyboard as long as you're not expecting premium switches or bt 5.0 connectivity.

reviews.title: Compact But Has Good Weight, Keys Are Perfect
reviews.text:
I opted for the "brown" keys and I must say that they feel and respond perfectly. Just the right amount of "clack" and just the right amount of resistance. The keys are normal width but the footprint is compact so you don't have to sacrifice any typing comfort for the portability or the ability to work in small spaces. The keyboard itself is very weighty and between its heft and rubber feet it's pleasingly very stable - won't slide around on the desk. The ability to use either USB or Bluetooth makes this thing incredibly versatile. Thankfully it's USB-C so you don't have to worry about plug alignment, and the included USB cable is very good quality (braided nylon, strain relief) and length. The backlighting is decent, though not terribly even so some of the lettering doesn't look right in the dark.

One big downside is the lack of dedicated Function keys (F1-F12). This keyboard takes a cue from laptop keyboard design and introduces an "Fn" key which you have to hold in to change the function of normal keys to specialty operations, but instead of controlling volume or screen brightness, the "Fn" key is required to activate bluetooth pairing, an feature that acts sort of like Caps Lock but for function keys and of course the "F" keys. The problem I ran into with this configuration is that the F1-F12 keys weren't being recognized with some devices. I actually bought this specifically to use with a MiSTer FPGA device which supports standard USB keyboards and requires the F keys for certain basic functions.

According to the instructions, the combination "Fn + 1" should look like an "F1" key press but it did not. After poking at it for some time I discovered an undocumented (as in it's not in the instructions anywhere) feature which subtly changes the keyboard's operation. The "A" and "S" keys have an additional label "Os1" and "Os2" respectively. Holding "Fn + A" or "Fn + S" makes the keyboard backlight flash (which it does whenever you've changed some function of the keyboard itself). With the keyboard set to "Os2" (Fn + S) the "Fn + 1" combination DOES send "F1" but, this arrangement also confusingly swaps the "Window" key and the left "Alt" key.

Bottom Line ---
Pros:
- Heavy
- Quality keys, great feel
- Bluetooth & USB
- USB is USB-C and comes with a good cord
- Easy to plug in and use

Neutral Observations:
- Backlight is uneven

Cons:
- Instructions are incomplete
- Not having dedicated F1-F12 keys is problematic for gaming

reviews.title: Good with some room for improvement
reviews.text:
So I got these keycaps today and installed. They installed just fine on Cherry style switches. They have a satisfying *thock* sound to them when depressing. I mostly got them for arrow and WASD. The main thing I'm noticing is that the top edges of the keycap, while aren't sharp in the sense that you may cut yourself, could really use just a TOUCH of softening.

Also, the letters and arrows are actual cutouts. it's possible for skin and debris to pass through them, so handle with care? I haven't had them long enough to know if it makes more of a mess than standard pudding keycaps. Also don't know if the heavier metal keycaps have any effect on longevity. Definitely need less force to depress the keys.

To get 5 stars, I think just softening the edges of the tops of the keycaps and maybe finding a way to have epoxy resin fill to seal the holes without affecting weigh or backlight visibility would be the only things I ask for. Keep the dead skin cells and snack food dust from slipping through the top of the keycap.

reviews.text: I kept breaking the plastic keycaps on my Corsair K95 RGB keyboard while playing Doom Eternal. These keycaps are made of aluminum and are holding much better. They fit a little tighter than the plastic keycaps, but they do fit.

reviews.title: Nice mechanical keyboard for the money
reviews.text: I have a number of mechanical keyboards that are mostly used for business purposes. My primary motivator for buying this keyboard was to try out the GamaKay Phoenix switches, but I also like the look and size of the keyboard. The price is also really good, in my opinion. Right now this keyboard is the one I reach for the most. I really like the quiet thump of the switches and they feel nice to use, but to be clear - they aren't actually silent. I've had a few annoyances with this keyboard occasionally not "waking up". The lights will respond, but typing doesn't show up. It's an easy fix. I just switch the input type over to BT and then back to USB since I've been using it wired. It immediately starts responding again. This isn't a consistent issue, but is a small thing that I wish didn't happen.

reviews.title: Support is impressive
reviews.text: Great keyboard back up by great service.

reviews.title: Easy to pair; good customizability
reviews.text:
[[VIDEOID:4822e6b7aa201be2a20c1d13ef6c2077]] Pros:

- Compact. Good mechanical alternative to Magic keyboard if size is an important factor for you.
- Customizable. Hotswappable switches and caps give you a good platform for changes later.

Cons:

- Stock caps are very plasticky and not the best I've used. Print quality and shape are good, but the material makes them feel hollow and gives an odd echo to each keypress. Will be replacing.
- No risers. The flat angle of the keyboard is not comfortable. Needs some sort of elevation in the back.

Meh:

-Stock switches are not the best I've used, not the worst. The yellow gateron's are among my favorite switches. They have a great overall feel. Some keys, particularly spacebar, have some "springy" sound to them and need lubrication or cushioning. Fortunately, the switches are swappable, and this can be adjusted if you're down for further investment and/or a project.
- Bluetooth connects well, but is sometimes laggy on input. Not a huge deal for regular typing, but I wouldn't game on it.
- LED's are always "moving." There's no way to set it to one color and leave it, which is my preferred color set.

Bottom line:

This keyboard is a decent platform for customization and you can MAKE this keyboard into exactly what you want, but I think it's overpriced if that's what you're getting it for.

reviews.title: My favorite keyboard!
reviews.text: I own quite a few of these multi-mode mechanical keyboards, and this is my favorite one by far. The build quality is phenomenal. PBT plastic keycaps with an XDA profile, dual flip out feet, the small layout WITH dedicated arrow keys, and even RGB backlighting. The keyboard uses a USB-C connection for wired mode. You also get a 2.4ghz dongle for wireless connectivity if you don't have Bluetooth. If you do, then you can connect and swap between 3 different Bluetooth devices. The ON/OFF switch and the connection mode switch are on the left side of the keyboard as opposed to the bottom. The RGB backlighting shines around the keycaps but not through them as PBT does not play well with allowing backlighting through a key as it is firmer and heavier than ABS. Still, with the white case cover the lighting looks great. You can also turn off backlighting to extend the battery life of the built-in battery. If you download the driver software, you can easily change the backlighting options without having to worry about remembering too many key combinations. This keyboard looks good and feels better. I got the option with the silver speed switches, and it is a dream with this keyboard. The speed of the actuation plus the feel of the solid PBT makes this keyboard the most comfortable that I own. This keyboard is now my daily driver, even above my HHKB. I highly recommend you try this keyboard. If you want a reduced layout with solid construction and fast response, you cannot get better than this anywhere.

reviews.title: Exceptionally perfect feel EXCEPT no way to find your position!
reviews.text:
I wanted to love these key caps. They look great! They feel superb and their smooth texture is exactly what I wanted.

However, two major flaws: I didn't even know this was a thing to consider, but they don't have bumps on the positioning keys "F" and "J". So if you type a lot and remove your hands from the keys, you need to look down every time to find your position. This interrupts my workflow as a transcriptionist quite a bit. The other disadvantage is that the smooth feel of the material also makes it impossible to keep skin oil, snack residues, etc. from being left behind on these caps, making them somewhat difficult to grip after the first half hour.

reviews.title: Really nice visual upgrade
reviews.text:
I wanted to upgrade my keyboard’s appearance, and after much Googling I settled on this product. I have a full size 104 key keyboard, and looking at keycaps on various websites makes it seem kinda complicated to know which set I’d need for my specific keyboard (Das Keyboard 4). Some Ctrl keys are wider than others, Spacebars shorter than others, etc. and what I liked about this set is that it includes different length keys and you just use the one that fits your keyboard and ignore the rest.

This is my first set of keycaps so I can’t really speak with any knowledge to the quality of the keys, but I’m really happy with how they look. They feel similar to the ones that came with my keyboard but look muuuuch better.

reviews.title: Fantastic keycap set
reviews.text:
They finally arrived! I plan on putting these keycaps on a 75% keyboard that won't arrive for another couple of months so in the pictures, I only put it on part of my keyboard to test them out. I want to "preserve" that new keycap feeling later. :)

These keycaps are fairly thick and have the standard PBT texture. The doubleshot legends are quite clear and none of the spacebars are warped! This is a new profile I've never typed on and I can't find much information on the web about it so I included a lot of pictures. I compared them in the pictures to my Ducky keyboard with doubleshot ABS. They actually aren't too different from OEM keycap profile (from the Ducky) height but some of the rows are higher. They're much more shapely and the F and J keys have a deeper dish. Compared to DSA keycaps, they don't seem to be quite as deep dishey overall which I actually prefer.
The keycaps fit snug on cherry mx brown stems, more so than my Ducky keycaps. They aren't hard to put on though. Some of the stems have a small part of plastic missing from the MX cross area but it's only a handful of the keycaps and it didn't effect the fit. I've included photos of this as well.
Overall they're great keycaps that I won't be using yet until my keyboard for them arrives.

reviews.title: Spacebars do not fit well
reviews.text:
[[VIDEOID:14b0c07be1bf5b90e20f388d925ce8c8]] The keycap set is great in terms of design, modifier key size options, and key legend for quality for price. Fitting for all keys is great, excepts for the large spacebars.
The space bars (both 6.25u and 7u) in my set don’t work smoothly and somehow get the stabs stuck (two different kinds of stabs as well). I tried them on two keyboards (one with 7u and other with 6.25u) and only these spacebars showed problems and the other spacebars I have do not show this problem. I am not sure really whats causing the space bar issue, maybe those pbt space keycaps are slightly bent (as I have read about) but visually they look okay.

reviews.title: Good Quality for the $ - Fits Cherry MX Switches
reviews.text:
This fit my Ducky mechanical keyboard without issue. They seem to be well made and fit tightly in my cherry MX switches. A couple observations, not sure it’s a positive or a negative but a point of observation:

1) They do not come with media key replacements. The blue ones you see in my image are from my original key caps

2) The height of the keys are slightly shorter than my Ducky OEMs. While initially this was a possible concern for me, having typed with the new keys for a couple weeks, seems to not impact typing at all.

3) The blue caps that came with the replacements are not the ones you see in my photo (Enter key). They have a slightly yellow / blue hue to them vs. the Ducky’s I’m using. Wanted my enter key to match the rest of the blue media keys so I mixed and matched. Some may like the blue that comes with the set, I just preferred my original blue keys color.

For the price, they fit the bill, can’t complain. We’ll see long term how the printing of the keys holds up / how quickly they wear down.

Wish list:

- Caps lock key had the word ‘Caps’ on it
- Windows button keys had something besides “Super”.

Overall good purchase.

reviews.title: Not for Certain Noise
reviews.text:
Unfortunately these o-rings didn't help with the noise from my mechanical keyboard and switches. The noise from my keyboard comes from the sound the springs make when the button pops back up, and these o-rings work to muffle sound when the keys are pressed down. For keyboards with raised keys that don't bottom out, like mine, and for switches that make more noise when they come back up instead of when they go down, the o-rings are not effective for reducing noise.

Otherwise, the product is good, and I'm keeping the o-rings for when I eventually change out the switches on my keyboard entirely.

reviews.text:
I was setting up two keyboards with lighter switches, and think that o-rings are important when you drop the force. This kit was a good value, and I like the brushes to clean the keyboards.

I would recommend a decent set of tweezers to push the rings down onto the key posts. I had a plastic set that was perfect for it ( they came with a pair of Moondrop IEMs ).

title: Akko Keycaps Set, Black&Bronze Theme 158-Key ASA Profile PBT Double-Shot Keycap Set with Black Keycaps for Mechanical Keyboards with Collection Box
features: BLACK&BRONZE THEME – The combination with classic black, gray and dark bronze,　the Black&Bronze keycaps brings heavy sense of history. The bronze charactors shine on the dark keycaps let us fantasy the bronze gleams in the dark night through thick fog.

ULTIMATE CUSTOMIZATION FLEXIBILITY – Comes with Akko ASA profile, the 158-key keycap set is suitable for a variety of layouts including but not limited to 61-key(60%), 68-key (65%), 84-key (75%), 87-key (TKL), 98-Key (Classic 1800), 100-Key (96%) and full 108-key size, and thus offers strong flexibility for keyboard personalization.
PBT DOUBLE-SHOT – Double-shot keycaps are extremely durable and resistant to wear even for decades, and the legends are particularly vibrant, sharp with high contrast.

ASA PROFILE – Akko’s proprietary ASA profile is tailored to offer a more familiar and comfortable typing experience by matching the height for OEM profile while maintaining the aesthetics and spheric top of the classic SA profile.

FOR MX STRUCTURE SWITCHES – Compatible with MX structure switches including but not limited to Cherry, Gateron, Akko and Kailh etc. Large keys of non-standard layout & stabilizers may not be compatible.

reviews.title: Some of the best keycaps under $100
reviews.text:
These keycaps are fantastic. The quality of material is noticeable right when you open the package, and the layout compatibility is uncomparable. For about $60 you get keycaps that work with the following layouts:

Full Size
1800
96%
75%
65%
60%
40% (non ortholinear)

The only layouts that aren't supported are ortholinear (though you might be able to make something work) and split (no split spacebar here). 60% with arrows (the 64-key) also is not supported as there is no 2u shift.

The colors are fantastic, the material feels very nice, and the cap profile is just incredibly comfortable to type on. In fact, it's so comfortable the only caps that I think are nicer are Drop's MT3 which cost double and don't come with as much layout variation without buying extra kits.

This specific set, Dracula's Castle, also comes with custom novelites and two different colors worth of compatibility (crimson and black) for a lot of the keys to make your board look exactly the way you want.

I'd highly recommend anything in ASA profile. The Cherry profile is good too, but not s comfortable for me to type on personally.

reviews.title: So amazing for the price
reviews.text: They looks so good for the price, Akko does it again!

reviews.title: Great quality double shot pbt keycaps.
Pretty Great Set with an Interesting Profile
reviews.text: This set is pretty nice, unlike most of Akko's keycap sets this set doesn't directly rip off color ways from existing GMK or EBPT sets, it comes close to something like SA Bliss but it adds black mods so it's not exactly the same.  The keycaps themselves are fairly nice and the font of the legends are a lot more consistent than their cherry profile sets. The packing is nice albeit a little frustrating as you pretty much need to use a keycap puller to remove the keycaps. The ASA profile is what I found the most interesting, if I had to compare it to anything I would actually compare it to OEM profile but slightly taller with rounded edges than something SA profile, The sculpting is a lot more derivative of OEM than SA in my opinion. The typing feel is pretty great it is very reminiscent of OEM profile so if you are used to OEM profile you will be right at home. The sound is more clacky than thocky at least in my NK65 with Gateron Cap Gold Switches. Overall the keycaps are nice and the ASA profile is a pleasant surprise coming from someone that uses both SA and OEM profile fairly regularly.

reviews.title: Good quality, Vivid colors, Nice sounding, Great value
reviews.text:
Akko Los Angeles 158-Key ASA Profile PBT Double-Shot Full Keycap Set for Mechanical Keyboards with Collection Box

I really love the profile of these keycaps. I have a hard time with whether to call this company a knock off company or not. They do have their own color combos and make combos that other companies do for a lot cheaper. Are color combos and fonts really proprietary? I'm not sure and eventually there will be no more combination of colors that one company will be able to claim as only their colors. I do think that Akko make really good keycaps and you get a lot for your money. So that's my two cents.

reviews.title: Hey, this is nifty
reviews.text:
JUST GOT THIS LAST NIGHT -- CHECK MY PURCHASE DATE -- AND IT WORKS! FEW MINUTES TO UNDERSTAND THE APP AND CONFIGURATION BUT NOW I'M UP AND FLYING.
USING BUTTONS FOR TRANSCRIBING SHORTCUTS; HIGHLIGHTING TEXT, BOLD, UNDERLINE, LARGER, DELETE, PLAY/PAUSE, FORWARD AND REWIND AUDIO/VIDEO TRACKS.
9-KEY *DOES* WORK THE GLOBAL APPLE MEDIA KEYS -- PLAY/PAUSE, REV, FFW AND IT WILL SCRUB AUDIO/VIDEO AS NORMAL AKA HOLDING DOWN THE REWIND KEY IN QUICKTIME, FOR EXAMPLE.
THE DEPRESSING OF KEYS ARE OLD SCHOOL -- LONG THROW AND LOUD -- BUT WILL GET USED TO.
CONTOUR SHUTTLE PRO V2 WILL ALSO GET AN AUDITION.
SUPER HAPPY WITH THIS LITTLE CONTROLLER, IT'S A TIDY SQUARE ON THE TABLE, AS WELL. LONG CABLE LEAD.

reviews.title: Awesome keypad for Day Trading Hotkeys
reviews.text: This keypad is good quality. Keys are tactile and clicky. Board is solid and no flex. Cable is braided and good quality. Very happy with this device. The programming can be flashed to the hardware so you do NOT need to have the software running for this to work.

reviews.title: I live the macro board
reviews.text: I am a software developer and use this everyday. It was easy to program and I love the onscreen UI that tells me what I have mapped to each button.  I also like the ability to store multiple button sets in other “presets” on the board. Overall it works great and I am glad I picked this up.

reviews.title: very good for the price
reviews.text:
I got this for a few different use such as photoshop, gaming, and other work software.
At first, looking at the photo I thought it was a metal case, but it's just a thin metal on the top and everything is plastic. Therefore, it's really light, and when you tap the keys it sounds so hallow, so I end up opening up taping the board, and filling it with some foam. This made a bit better but not much different. As for the software it is easy to use and there are a few layers (profile) settings that you can set it up for different software if needed. Also, the software is very easy to use.

Overall for the price, it is a good macro keypad for many different uses.

reviews.title: Nice Additional Keys
reviews.text: The software couldn’t be any easier to program. Keys have a nice feel to them. You can program up to 6 layers with this software. I use it with my CNC CAD/CAM software for repetitive functions that I use most. I would buy it again.

Double stage spring: 63.5g

Factory lubed

reviews.title: Can be used stock!
reviews.text:
[[VIDEOID:528307786b36a4c2c9833ddd389101cb]] They come with a small amount of lube pre applied. Usually, prelubed switches are inconsistent in my experience but these ones are really good. I decided to not lube them at all. EDIT: got a few more batches, they're not as consistent. But seller was nice enough to get them replaced.

The stems are long pole. As a result, it has a nice bottom out sound.

It was noticeably heavier coming from a 50g switch to these that are 63g, but overtime I got adjusted and had no problems typing with them.

Overall a great buy, though I wish it was priced more competitively.

Using on Drop Preonic with MT3 Camillo, plateless, tape mod

reviews.title: Nice linears
reviews.text:
Starting off not sure who's at fault for this as it's only fulfilled by Amazon but one of my bags was missing a few switches (one bag was open and all the switches were rattling around inside the amazon pouch it arrived in) I counted 5 missing and there wasn't a silica gel packet either, the other bags were fine.
complaint aside they feel really nice and the factory lube seems to be well done as wish they had a "3 pin" option and different switch amounts 35 2 is too few and 3 is too many (unless some get lost in transit like mine lol) 90 would be a good option for the TKL/75% gang

reviews.title: Will be Using Right Away
reviews.text: In building & repairing computers these key switches are used very often. Mainly for high-end (over $100) keyboards that the serious gamers use. What they do is tough on the keyboards and often switches break or become less responsive which may lead to a gamer losing a match. These snap right in to the sockets and can instantly rebuild the whole keyboard like new. I realize they would not be used by your everyday person or casual gamer but when it gets serious they are  the switches to be used.

reviews.title: Nice Linear
reviews.text: These are nice and smooth and sound wonderful.  I'm not a linear fan usually, but I do like them in my modifier keys (shift, backspace, enter, and space) because I don't like the return sound a tactile makes while in a larger key.  These are perfect for that as they don't have a high pitch and there's no spring ping to even think of!  I would highly recommend them to anyone looking for a lighter-weight linear switch with some style.

reviews.title: Great Stock!
reviews.text: The switches sounds great and feels good to use. The lube in this is not bad at all and you don't hear any ping or scratchiness. The bottom out is much more than I am used to, but I do enjoy it otherwise.

title: VELOCIFIRE Tenkeyless Mechanical Keyboard Mini, 78-Key Compact Ergonomic, Outemu Brown Switches Backlit and Double-Shot ABS Keycaps for Copywriter, Typist and Programmer
features: MUST HAVE- Velocifire mechanical keyboard is designed for copywriter, programmer, editors who spend many hours typing every day. You will get better at typing speed and accuracy through Velocifire mechanical keyboards.

Durable Brown Switch- Low-noise switches have a tactile bump for feedback with every key-press. It is much QUIETER than Blue Switch but LOUDER than a regular Membrane keyboard. If you never used a mechanical keyboard before, please think about whether you can accept its sound first.

Compact Design- The compact mechanical keyboard helps save desktop space.Tiny size of compact keyboard makes it possible to share room with a mouse. Users like to have to mouse close to keyboard, since that will be easier to reach.It also serves as a accessory of laptop.

ANTI-GHOSTING - This is sometime used in place of Key Rollover, but the terminology is incorrect since ghosting is a different (and rare) issue. You will need to do more research to see what key rollover technology is being used. Ghosting is when two or more keys are pressed and a key that was not pressed registers instead.
Money Back -- Velocifire offers a 30 days money back. We always serve you after the sale!

It makes a loud and high pitched ringing noise that is far from pleasant. The small form factor would make it great for gaming however the sound when hitting the keys are is not good. Ultimately it could have been a nice keyboard but it fell short.

reviews.title: Perfect starter Artisan keycap!
reviews.text:
Edit: purchased the black AND the white one. 10/10

I purchased this keycap as I wanted an artisan but did not want to have to pay resale on ebay or Mechmarket. After a quick search, I was glad to find this combo as it covers the escape key AND the tab key in a matching set. I tried both keycaps on multiple boards and I am thoroughly impressed.

I can easily say that this keycap set will fit both regular MX stems and box stems, as they fit on my box inks and NK creams without issue. I swapped them on 6 different boards just to see how they looked with different sets and did not find there to be any loosening.

Being able to change the "screen" is a fun touch but I am leaving it on the apple logo for nostalgia. The keyboard on the tab key is magnetic and I have found myself playing with it while working today.

Overall this is an easy 10/10 for both price and quality. I highly recommend it for both enthusiasts who want a fun budget set but also for anyone with a keyboard in general!

title: ASCENY Coiled & Double-Sleeved Mechanical Keyboard Cable, for Type-C Mechanical Keyboards (Purple)
description: As MK enthusiasts who are obsessed with building keyboards, we understood the needs of the mechanical keyboards community. This cable is our latest take on designed mechanical keyboard cables. Our goal was to create a mass production product that will allow more people to get into the hobby without having to spend a huge amount of money. After many failed attempts to make a great coil in mass production, we finally believe that we have created a great product that stands in one with the standards of mechanical keyboard enthusiasts.
features: Stiff plastic injected Asceny connectors. No more amateurish heatshrinks.
PET double sleeve that gives a beautiful texture, and extra durability.
4.9ft long (excluding the coil length) & Super flexible 6" tight coil that lasts.
Comes in a beautiful package that holds the coil tight. Can be saved and re-used whenever you want to store your cable.

reviews.title: Great cable for a small investment.
reviews.text:
Being new to to the Mechanical Keyboard market, I recently purchased a prebuilt "budget" board that came with a long plain usb-c cable, which would be fine but I wanted a cleaner look for my desk. Aviator cables are great but I did not want to invest $50+ for a single use cable. In comes Asceny with a cable that costs half as much and looks just as good in my opinion. The packaging was nicely made, and does not feel cheap in any way, this company really put a lot of love into the product.

My only complaint is that with the direction of the coil, I can not have the Asceny logo facing up with a left side charge port on my keyboard, otherwise the cable does not sit correctly on the desk. This would not dissuade me from recommending it though, and may even encourage some buyers.

reviews.title: Keychron K4 Compatible
reviews.text:
Read reviews about the plug not fitting on some Keychrons but was prepared to modify. Turns out, it fits just fine, and I haven’t had any issues so far.
Cable itself feels solid and durable, a bit stiff, but maneuverable.
Overall, for the price, I’d say go with it if you are debating.

reviews.title: Nice
reviews.text: Good value, sturdy, nice style

reviews.title: Good starter coil cable for keyboard build
reviews.text: This is my first coil keyboard cable for my first mechanical keyboard build. I can’t compare it to one of the more popular brands like Glorious for example, but for what it is, it’s a nice, sturdy, well made cable. It looks good and is a nice accessory for my keyboard. The coils are actually smaller than I thought they would be, but still nice. I wish the cable was longer though, that’s my only complaint.

reviews.title: good wire to save space and for the *aesthetic*
reviews.text: i love how the coiled-wire pairs with the mechanical keyboard. it makes my desk look less messy and looks fab LOL

Characters on the ASA Clear keycaps are processed through UV printing with wear-resistant and scratch-resistant tests, and are not easily wiped off.

ULTIMATE CUSTOMIZATION FLEXIBILITY – Comes with Akko ASA profile, the 155-key keycap set is suitable for a variety of layouts including 61-key(60%), 64-key, 68-key (65%), 84-key (75%), 87-key (TKL), 98-Key (Classic 1800), 100-Key (96%), Alice and full 108-key size, and thus offers strong flexibility for keyboard personalization.

MAC KEYCAPS & NOVELTY KEYS – The keycap set is designed for both Windows and Mac users, where Mac modifiers CMD/OPT are offered in different sizes. The transparent keycap set also features extra cute animal themed novelty keys for decoration.

ASA PROFILE – Akko’s proprietary ASA profile is tailored to offer a more familiar and comfortable typing experience by matching the height for OEM profile while maintaining the aesthetics and spheric top of the classic SA profile.

FOR MX STRUCTURE SWITCHES – Compatible with MX structure mechanical switches and mainstream keyboards including but not limited to Cherry, Gateron, Akko and Kailh. Large keys of non-standard layout & stabilizers may not be compatible.

reviews.title: Unique keys look cool with RGB. Some drawbacks.
reviews.text:
Pros:
- Beautifully and conveniently packaged and organized. Caps come on three trays with plastic film on them so that nothing will have shifted in transit. It's very easy to replace your caps and keep your old set save and organized in the trays, too. Simple to find any specialized keys that you may need in the trays.
- Print is easy to see and seems durable/high contrast. No funky fonts that are hard to read.
- Looks awesome with RGB.

Cons:

- There are no tactile nubs on the F and J keys to indicate homerow. As a touch typist, this was almost a dealbreaker.
- Color is way off from the images in the description. The images in the description show a clear white color to the keycaps. Along with the "clear/translucent" descriptors, I believed I was going to get more of a white/iced translucent look. Nope. The caps are basically colorless clear. They are smooth and glossy with no texture. I left some of the OG white keys on my keyboard to show the color clearly side by side. Not the look I was expecting from the images and description.

Good to know:

- I've never used ASA profile before, and generally prefer XDA, so these are a little taller than I'm used to on XDA, but more rounded (and, I think, more comfortable, than OEM. I had some lousy stock OEM caps on my old keyboard, and I do feel these caps are an improvement. They are sufficiently dense, and give me a slightly deeper, more muted sound from my keypresses with my brown switches, which I like, compared to the more plasticky/hollow caps that were original to my board.
- Despite having a glossy finish, I don't find these keys to be slippery--the slight curvature leads your fingertips toward the center of the keys easily and they're comfortable to use.
- I really hate that there are no homerow nubs. Who skips that? Come on.

reviews.title: No tactile bumps on F and J, amazing for backlighting
reviews.text:
I have the “White” color option in this set of keycaps from Akko. White is a bit misleading, the color is actually glossy and nearly translucent. This is actually what I wanted, I was looking all over for nearly clear keycaps, but I did want to point that out.

If you like maximum backlighting, this might be the set for you. I was using white pudding caps before, and I thought they let a lot of light shine through. The difference is night and day. These Akko caps show backlighting on all sides and the top of the cap. I’ve included a picture of a white pudding cap surrounded by the clear Akkos to show the difference.

I’m using the keycaps with Akko Vintage White (MX) switches. The keycaps fit well, but they took a bit of force to fit on the switches.

I am disappointed the F and J keys do not have ridges or bumps. I’m a touch typist and using an ergo board with 56 keys, I rely on those ridges to help me orient my hands. This set has so much variety that I wish Akko had included doubles of F and J or even blanks with the ridges.

Speaking of keycap variety: the set has some great 1u options! My current keyboard is an Iris Rev 6, all keys are 1u size. But most keycap sets don’t have 1u keycaps for Shift, Control, Command/Windows, and so on. This set does, which is a big help. I also like the cute animal keycaps, they add some fun to my board.

I believe the ASA height is original to Akko. They have a helpful height chart on their site, comparing ASA to OEM, JDA, OSA, and Cherry. I was using OEM before, and switching to ASA and the glossy feel of the keycaps took about two days of adjustment.

reviews.title: Clicky clack who’s at the rack with the jackets? Me!
reviews.text:
I had been eyeing a mechanical keyboard for years, hesitant to buy one because A) I already had a perfectly fine working keyboard and B) Reviews I had read made it sound like they were so noisy you needed to wear ear protection while using one. During a recent move I left my previously mentioned perfectly fine working keyboard outside for an extended period of time, uncovered in the rain and sun and any other elements that rolled though Southern California for those few months. When I finally returned to the keyboard, I found that it had become yet another casualty of the pandemic. Finally I had good cause for a new keyboard, and my research led me to try this one. And like the famous tattoo says, I have no ragrets!

I plugged it in and immediately it lit up and off my little fingies went, zipping around the keyboard with the grace and elegance of a gold medal winning gymnast at the 2021 Tokyo Olympics. Every click and clack was like music to my ears, each sentence I typed sounding like a symphony composed by Mozart himself! I now look forward to typing my weekly emails to mother, catching her up with her favorite son’s (sorry Richard, but you know it’s true!) comings and goings!
I’ve only had this keyboard for about a week, so time will tell if it will hold up to the rigorous poundings that accompany each email I compose, but as of now I would not hesitate to recommend this keyboard to all my many (ok, zero) friends! Now I can’t wait to get off from my day job as a clerk typist and go home and get some typing in!

reviews.text: I wanted to get a substitute USB-C cable for my keyboard and found this listing. Was intrigued by the interchangeable inputs as well as the mechanical design. The price seemed steep, but the uses, ergonomics and possible durability of the cable seemed like a good investment. Mine came functional with an included "Kraken Keybaord" sticker, thank you! The only problem I found was that the USB-C male input was a tad long for my ANNE PRO Clone, a Dierya x Kemove DK61 60% Keyboard.
