title: Hexgears Impulse - Hot-swap Mechanical Keyboard (Box Brown Switches, Pudding Keycaps)
description:
The Hexgears Impulse is available in many amazing configurations.
— Durable PBT Keycaps
PBT is an engineering plastic that resists shine and finger grease. This is far better than the cheap plastic used by major brands. All Impulses use PBT in their doubleshot injection molded keycaps — the main letters won’t ever wear off.
— Awesome RGB Backlighting and RGB Ring Lighting
The Impulse lighting system is on-board, ensuring compatibility with various operating systems. Translucent pudding keycaps showcase its smooth RGB lighting in a way that other keyboards can only dream of. RGB customization options allow you to select an experience that matches your battlestation.
— Survives Your Worst Impulses
Do you have a coffee habit? A cat that spills things on the regular? The Impulse handles liquids like a champ. IP56 water resistance means that the keyboard functions while blasted with water jets. Its curved metal frame is also quite rigid.
— Kailh Box Switches
Kailh Box switches are rated for 80 million presses — way above industry standard. They have drainage ports and self-cleaning housings. Box switches also feel excellent, as they’re less wobbly and noticeably smoother than standard models. Tactile Box switches result in relatively quiet mechanical keyboards, but the clicky versions go all out with a new and improved mechanism.
— Other Features
The Impulse is designed as a plug and play device. Its feature set offers exactly what you need to get up and running fast. 2-stage angle adjustment feet and basic onboard functions like Windows key locking enhance your experience.
Impulse keyboards have a 1-year limited warranty.
features: RGB, Per-key customizable lighting modes, RGB Light Ring
Two-shot extra durable PBT keycaps (Pudding & 2-tone)
Curved metal mounting plate with 2 stage adjustable height feet
IP56 water resistant design, N-key Rollover (NKRO), integrated USB-A cable
Available in Kailh BOX Brown (Tactile), BOX White (Clicky), and Hako Clear (Heavy Tactile) Mechanical Switches
Updated Impulse V2 design with Hot-swap switch sockets (MX-compatible, LED compatible, plate mount)

reviews.title: Good Keyboard, clicky, and positive return
reviews.text:
Hi, I am a bit of a keyboard junky. I have bought probably 10 mechanical keyboards over the last 3 years. I still have an original IBM PC keyboard - that is really stiff and loud. But about this keyboard, I read an online review and said, why not - and I have been using it for several days. First, it sets up easy. Just plug in to get started. Configuring all the lights is more work and not completely intuitive - especially if you lose the little manual 3x4" or so. Personally, I don't care that much for the lighting features on any keyboard - I want to know if I can type quickly without any errors from the keyboard as opposed from me. In general, this keyboard is one of the best. The key depression effort is light to medium - if you rest your fingers on the keys, they will not trigger -which is good. The space bar works well - and I usually find this a problem because I hit it a bit off center - but this one works well. The noise is medium. The clacky sound is the sound of me pressing the keys to the maximum and not the click of the membrane.

I generally like this keyboard and I have tried many from $79 mechanical keys to $200 keyboards. I think this is up there with the best - maybe not all the bells and whistles like volume control, but I never use that. Buy this. Works well. Feels good under the fingers. Type fast!

reviews.title: Recommended for Gaming
reviews.text: Nice keyboard. Has NKRO, macro support, and lots of lighting patterns for the keyboard and ring lighting. Looks very nice in the Pudding keycaps version with full RGB. I ordered it with the Kailh Box Brown switches, which work smoothly, and have a somewhat subtle tactile feedback. I tested it fully, and there was no key chatter detected. Well worth the reasonable asking price and one of the very few current options offering these switches in a commercial build.

reviews.title: Great for typing
reviews.text:
I have the version with white keycaps and "box white" clicky switches. I don't play computer games, so I can't comment on that aspect of the keyboard. But I can say that this is a very good typist's keyboard. The key switches sound like Cherry Blues, but I think these feel smoother, and have less lateral wiggle room.

The keyboard comes with a tiny "user guide" that is no more than a list of keystrokes that control the lighting and macros. I don't care for lighting on a keyboard, so the first thing I tried to do was dim the lights. The "user guide" wasn't very clear on that, so here's how:

While holding down the "Fn" key...
... press the Down arrow to dim the white lights.
... press the "2" key on the numeric keypad to dim the colored perimeter lights.

Keep pressing those keys to dim the lights further. I've now got them completely dimmed, and I hope they stay that way.

One thing to know about this keyboard is that the keycaps aren't recessed. On most keyboards, you can't see or grasp the bottoms of the keycaps, because they fit into cavities formed by the molded plastic deck. This keyboard's top deck is flat metal, without cavities. So there's about a quarter-inch gap between the keycap bottoms and the top of the deck. As a result, it's easy to pull the keycaps. You can even remove the Escape key with your bare fingers. I don't think this is a bad thing; it's just worth knowing about.

Speaking of keycaps, these use a stylized font that sacrifices legibility for fashion. The designer apparently dislikes closed shapes, and created little vertical gaps in the Q, O, zero, 8, etc. Not even the ampersand, pound sign, or the little orbs of the percent sign are spared this annoying treatment. It looks like the dye is flaking away. As a sometimes hunt-and-peck typist, I find this very distracting, as it keeps me from instantly recognizing many of the keys.

I would rate this keyboard with five stars, if not for the inadequate "user guide" and the poorly thought-out keycap font.

reviews.title: Very well built
reviews.text: Solid keys, good feel.  I don't need all of the LEDS, and had to play around with the controls to get just the minimum lighting.  Much better than my old "mushy" wireless keyboard.

reviews.title: Best keycaps I have ever used.
reviews.text:
Bought these for my GMMK pro.

I have owned several mechanical keyboards, but never bought a high-end set of keycaps. Unlike every other set I've ever used, these just seem to ignore dirt and grease. I can stuff my face with a big Mac and go straight to typing, and the caps stay completely clean. I don't know how that works but I won't question it.

Other keyboards require weekly wipe downs, I have never had to do it with these caps.

They're also noticeably built well. These are going to outlast my fingers by a hundred years, likely.

reviews.title: Legend doesn’t glow like other pics
reviews.text: For my Tofu65, I do like these pudding key caps, but I’m not sure why the legends on my key caps aren’t transparent. Everyone who posted reviews with pics show their legends glowing, so I’m not sure why mine are different. My other issue is I got several duplicative keys, and I’m missing a few. For example, I only have one home key and about 4 page down keys. So that’s slightly annoying. I’ve seen some others complain about this similar thing as well. But the feel and look of these key caps are quality. Slightly disappointed.

reviews.text:
I just got my white set in the mail today and they would be good keycaps if there had been better quality control. It's like they took a bunch of flawed pieces and sold them to us as a set. Like another user said, I expected the shift, caps lock and tab keys to have the words spelled out and not just arrows.

There are rough bumps and weirdly broken pieces of plastic at the top of every keycap, as you can see on my picture. It is very hard to read the keys with backlight on since the font is so thin. The keyboard photographs well but it's very hard to see what key you are pressing. I feel deceived by the company and wish I had bought the HyperX ones instead, even though I didn't like the font.

reviews.title: Almost perfect, if not for the competition
reviews.text:
TLDR: If you don't want to deal with pre-ordering the Wooting60HE or just really like Steelseries products, this is a really good 60% option.

Pros:
-Omnipoint switches feel very good
-Adjustable actuation point
-Finally adopted PBT keycaps for longevity
-Good RGB brightness and accuracy
-Pretty good stabs out of the box made better with some lube

Cons:
-The Wooting60HE exists...

Thoughts:
Rant time. Right out of the gate, this would be the perfect 60% keyboard currently, if the Wooting60HE didn't exist. It has hotswap switches, acoustic foam, analog functionality, adjustable actuation point, RAPID TRIGGER (huge for high actuation point users), pre-lubed switches and stabs, and doesn't require its software to be active to function fully. This board isn't bad by any means, it's just that the wooting is just better in my opinion. I saw steelseries' video today comparing their "response time" with some weird rigged comparison test where they claim a 10ms advantage over the wooting. Even if that were true, which I don't think is accurate, 10ms isn't enough to justify choosing this over the wooting, unless you just really like Steelseries products, which is fine. But the rapid trigger functionality alone is HUGE for switches with a high actuation. If you don't know what that is, basically at any point during the upward travel (after you've pressed a key), you can press down again, to register another keypress. It basically makes the actuation dynamic letting you keep that high actuation, but not require you to fully release the key to press it again. Anyway, rant/PSA over, back to the Apex.

Despite everything I just said, this is still a really good keyboard. If you liked the Apex Pro/TKL, you'll like this. I've found that magnetic switches are easily the smoothest ones on the market, even without lubing. They just glide, absolutely fantastic.

I would comment on the responsiveness, but honestly, I really can't imagine milliseconds making a huge difference for movement inputs in a shooter. Osu probably if that's your thing, but starting to move in one direction or another a milisecond faster isn't going to change your game in the slightest. A mouse, absolutely, but there's really no keyboard input that needs that level of precision. So try not to get hung up on responsiveness in regards to keyboard claims.

Something definitely worth noting is how magnetic switches and optical switches are basically immune to double presses that eventually happen to regular mechanical switches. You can rest assure that all of your key presses will be very accurate.

Conclusion:
Before you commit to this, I highly recommend looking into the Wooting60HE. If you don't want to deal with pre-ordering, or just really like Steelseries products, this is still a really good keyboard. I love the switches, and am so happy they decided to finally start using PBT keycaps.

reviews.text: This mini keyboard was a major change from my previous keyboard. The first major shock I had when I needed the grave/tilde key for programming, thankfully with the SteelSeries GG program I was able to program the grave/tilde key into the escape key with a modifier. In Minecraft as well some of the F3 functions needed to be mapped because there is no function row. After some getting used to I am just as fast on this keyboard as my previous one. There was a quirk I could not figure out without some googling however, if you hold the SteelSeries logo and the windows button it locks the windows button and changes it's color to white. Doing it again will re-enable the windows button.

reviews.title: Good quality and adorable!
reviews.text:
Key caps are textured, but do not feel rough. The textured PBT will keep them from getting shiny as fast (compared to smooth ABS). No print errors. Fit the Cherry switches perfectly. They feel weighty and durable. The plastic is cut cleanly, no rough edges. Nice big font, centered on each key. I am very happy with these.

The only thing I am a bit disappointed about is that the special (non-standard) Capslock key does not fit my keyboard; the slot where you are supposed to insert the switch is not centered correctly. But, it isn't enough of a disappointment for me to knock down my rating.

reviews.title: Perfect!
reviews.text: These keycaps are made of PBT, which is about the highest grade of plastic that you can get for your keycaps. I love the flatter profile of the XDA keycaps. The print on the keys is very classic, large, and easy to read. This keycap set contains both peach and sea green keycaps for the function keys, space bar, escape, and enter keys. You can mix and match them until your hearts delight. You even get some extra keys for media keys if your keyboard has them, plus menu and function keys. You get a wide variety of keys that will fit most Cherry MX style keyboards easily. The plastic is nice and textured so your fingers won't slip off the keycaps when you are typing on the keyboard. I would highly recommend these keycaps as an upgrade to ABS keycaps, and for customizing your keyboard in a cute vintage style.

reviews.title: In Love!
reviews.text: I purchased the "Life is a Journey" ASA profile pudding keycaps because of the awesome theme and color scheme. They are gorgeous, sophisticated, and they FEEL better than any other pudding keycaps I've ever had. No wobble, no cheap plastic sound. They add to the sound of the board and typing experience. Superior to HyperX. I have them paired with my Kailh Box Whites and I couldn't be happier.

title: 4-Port HDMI KVM Switch – 4K 60Hz – QHD 144Hz - Audio Output and USB Sharing – Mechanical & Gaming Keyboards Supported – HKS0401A2U
description:
This 4x1 HDMI KVM Switch allows you to share one set of “keyboard, video monitor, and mouse” (“KVM”) with up to four PC’s or video devices (Xbox, PS4, Firestick, etc). The switcher does not require software and works with Windows, MacOS, Unix/Linux, Raspberri Pi, etc. HDMI 2.0 protocol supports 4K@60hz and blazing 144hz@1440P, making this device a perfect fit for work-from-home professionals and high-end video gaming.
Key Features
- Supports DisplayPort, DVI, & VGA with approved adapters.  - Keyboard passthrough mode allows for better compatibility plus multimedia key functions  - Hotkey triggers assignable to either Scroll Lock or Right-CTRL  - USB sharing works with printers, jump drives, USB headsets and webcams for teleconferencing.  - Auto-scanning with adjustable time interval from 1 to 250 seconds.  - 1-year US-based warranty when purchased from BuyTESmart
FAQ
- Audio is transmitted via HDMI connection. HDMI or DisplayPort monitor required for audio  - Use powered USB hub to expand the USB2.0 port if multiple connections are needed  - Use USB extender to reduce distance to receiver if wireless mouse/keyboard is “jumpy”  - Please install CR2025 battery before use (battery not included)
Mouse / Keyboard Compatibility
Dedicated mouse & keyboard ports have emulation programming. Second gen chipsets have “Passthrough Mode” to send special characters such as multimedia keys (play, pause, volume up/down), which improves keyboard compatibility. Keyboard software such as Logitech Options, Corsair iCUE, etc conflicts with the emulation and limits the ability to use macro keys. We recommend using the KVM’s USB2.0 port as a workaround if this software if needed. USB2.0 port does not have emulation programming and KVM will not recognize hotkey commands. Please use a powered USB hub to expand USB connectivity.
features: Share 4 computers with 1 monitor, keyboard, mouse. Switch between PC’s with push button, keyboard hotkeys, mouse gestures, or remote control. Can also use as HDMI switch for gaming consoles and streaming devices.
HDMI 2.0 supports UHD 4K60hz (3840x2160), QHD 144hz (2560x1440), 1080P 144hz (1920x1080). Plus Ultrawide 60hz (21:9 & 32:9). HDCP 2.2, HDR10, Dolby Vision. EDID Emulation.
Plug & Play. No software or drivers needed. Supported by IT departments for work-from-home professionals. Separate your work from your personal life without the hassle & clutter!
Transmit audio to monitor via HDMI and/or external speakers via stereo output. Share USB device such as webcam and headset with dedicated USB2.0 port. Great for Zoom and Twitch users.
Supports wired, wireless, mechanical, multimedia, and gaming keyboards. No delay, zero latency keyboard switching and pass-through mode for multimedia keys. READ FAQ & PICS.
U.S. Based TECHNICAL SUPPORT from BuyTESmart available to help resolve all issues.

title: DROP + Matt3o MT3 Susuwatari Custom Keycap Set, ABS Hi-Profile Keycaps, Doubleshot Legends, Cherry MX Compatible Set for Ortholinear Mechanical Keyboards (Ortholinear)
features: A GROUNDBREAKING PROFILE, BACK FOR MORE: Sculpted in Hi-Profile, Matt3o’s groundbreaking MT3 /dev/tty custom keycap set changed the way we type.

FROM THE IBM TERMINAL TO THE DESKTOP: Based on the profile form the iconic IBM beamspring terminals of the 1970s, this custom set is fully sculpted in Hi-Profile. From its heavily slanted design to the scooped, contoured tops of each cap, the set recreates the feel of vintage keyboards.

DOUBLESHOT LEGENDS: As opposed to a dye-sublimiation process, these doubleshot legends are permanently molded inside the keycap, thus becoming an integral part of it. This ensures reliable legends and continuity throughout the set.
ORTHOLINEAR: For ortho keyboards like the Drop Planck, Preonic, and other boards with similar layouts.
SPECS: Produced by Drop and designed by Matt3o, ABS Hi-Profile MT3 keycaps, Doubleshot legends, MX compatible, and Fully sculpted based on IBM beamspring keycaps.

reviews.title: Absolute necessity on ortholinear boards
reviews.text:
These keycaps are thick, double shot so they will never fade, and sculpted. With ortholinear keyboards, these keycaps really help adjusting to smaller modifer key size and different key layout.

Pros:
1. Thick: This helps lower the pitch of the sound, which makes it sound quieter.
2. Doubleshot ABS: No wearing out the legends. The font is also fairly thick, making it much more legible than some other keycaps.
3. MT3 profile: The sculpted profile really makes it very comfortable to use and helps reduce hitting the wrong keys. No sharp edges due to the spherical shape. Very enjoyable for typing. The profile is much higher though so that could be an issue for some people.
4. Multiple profile options for certain keys: For example, the Ctrl and Esc keycs come in profiles that would allow it to be the top row or 3rd row. Space bar comes as two 1u, two 1.5u, and one 2u.
5. Storage tray and box: This seems silly to put as a pro but the tray and box it comes with make it easy to store unused or keycaps it replaced. Other Keycaps come in a zip lock bag that will just be a jumbled mess.

Cons:
1. Price. This is really expensive for a set of keycaps but this is the normal price for any specialty keycaps. It is what it is.
2. Limitation of scultped profile: Putting key profiles meant for row 1 in row 3 feels awkward so you might end you designing your keymap partially based on keycap profiles. Also might end up rotating some keycaps like row 5 Raise or Lower layer keycaps to make it more comfortable.
3. ABS option only. The PBT version is in white only. So if you prefer the color with the material that it isn't made it, then you're out of luck.
4. Limited to buying sets if you need extra keys: If you need more keys, you have to order a set. I would like to have more 1.5u blank keycaps but don't want to buy multiple sets just for the few pieces I want.

reviews.title: I like them
reviews.text:
These are my daily drivers, I use them on a Drop CTRL with Glorious Panda switches. Initially I thought the MT3 profile was disorienting, but after using them for a while, I am quite fond of it. I acknowledge that not everyone will like this profile though, and that should be considered if you are buying this product (or any like it). If you can find an MT3 set to try first before dumping about two hundred dollars on keycaps, it would be a **very good** idea. Other things go without saying, the thickness is very good the weight on my switches feels good and not like its making keys too easy to press or anything. I really like the theme, but all of that considered, I bought this specifically for the VI keys (hjkl with arrows) because I thought they looked super cool.

The price for these keycaps is a good deterrent for most people, for good reason. However this high of a price is pretty standard for high quality keycaps, as well as the Drop.com-exclusive MT3 profile.

This leads me to the value for money, its expensive and definitely should only be bought if you have a hankering to spend money on some expensive keycaps or you really really like having a specific row of keycaps.
Brightness is a 1 star because they're not shine-through keycaps, as they should be.
Gaming is a 4 star because, like, Sure? nothing about these keycaps keep you from gaming.

reviews.title: Best 3rd party caps I've ever owned.
reviews.text:
I really liked the esthetics of these key caps because I was looking for something which resembled "Old Nasa" feel, and these were the best I could find. The ergonomics were also great and everything has a very nice and snug fit, unlike the original keycaps that came with my CTRL keyboard.

I only wish that the "additional" buttons came with the normal key caps for the money I spent on the original "package". $30 for about 10 extra keys I can use on my ten keyless is VERY steep.

reviews.title: Best keycap set
reviews.text: I love this set. Worth every penny.

reviews.title: Absolutely gorgeous
reviews.text: Wonderful keycaps , goes great on my Nyquist Keyboard, looks professional yet custom, I highly recommend.

title: KINESIS USB-A Freestyle Pro Quiet Ergonomic Split Mechanical Keyboard (Cherry MX Silent Red Switches)
features: AWARD-WINNING SPLIT DESIGN: Advanced ergonomics for all body types and preferences via adjustable split, splay, and tent (tenting accessories sold separately). New cable storage compartment supports up to 20" of separation when you need it.

GENUINE CHERRY MECHANICAL SWITCHES FOR PREMIUM TYPING FEEL AND PERFORMANCE WITH LESS NOISE: Cherry MX "Silent" red mechanical switches feature a low activation force, linear feel and are rated for 50M key presses for unmatched durability.

FULL ONBOARD PROGRAMMABILITY WITH THE DRIVERLESS SMARTSET ENGINE: 9 custom layouts, 8 office hotkeys, on-the-fly macro recording, one-touch key remapping, pre-configured Mac and Dvorak layouts, settings saved to keyboards 4MB flash memory, and the SmartSet App GUI for Windows & Mac.
PLUG-AND-PLAY WITH ALL MAJOR OPERATING SYSTEMS: Windows 7-10, Mac OS X, Linux, Chrome.
2 YEAR MANUFACTURER'S WARRANTY: Buy with confidence knowing that Kinesis engineers all our products in the USA to the highest standards and stands behind them 100 percent since 1992.

reviews.title: Good, but could be better
reviews.text:
I use this with my MacBook Pro. I have brutal pain in my hands, wrists and forearms from osteoarthritis, tendon-patchy and tendonitis; caused from 19 years of being at my computer and holding my phone up for blogging.

This keyboard has made things so much better, however... I needed the keyboard to have the lift without the wrist pads which are agony for my hands. Only, the tent system is made to include all pieces; the lift and the wrist pads. So, I have to use the lift pieces without the wrist pads which leaves a chunk of awkward plastic sticking straight out from the keyboard; something I am constantly catching. It's frustrating to no end.

I am now looking for something I can simply glue to the inner, underside of the keyboard that will add the lift but leave the front open.

I'm also disappointed with the price. Come on now. It's sooooo overpriced. It's only a matter of time before another brand comes out with a more reasonable one- but in the meantime, I feel like they are taking advantage.

In the end, this is far better than nothing. It definitely places your hands in a more ergonomic position, and is better than a flat keyboard or laptop touchpad setup.

reviews.title: Great keyboard for ergonomics
reviews.text: The split keyboard layout has been great for my shoulders and arms.  It took a couple of weeks for me to get used to the layout but the extra functions offered on the edges of the keyboard are very helpful.  Being able to replace the key caps is huge.  I really love this keyboard.

reviews.title: Quality material, but as wide as TKL keyboards
reviews.text:
I wish the length of the cable was longer, and that a longer cable can be purchased separately.
For the price, the tenting should be standard, but it is a separate purchase. And, without them, this keyboard isn't as great.

I purchased the tenting separately, and it really helps with ergonomics when typing. But, when gaming it tends to push my hands side and down, so it's better to use a separate palm support.

I was surprised that when the keyboard is laid out, it is as wide as a ten keyless keyboard. I was hoping that it would be shorter, so that the mouse has more room. It's fine for work or just typing. For gaming, I'll put the right section farther up. Or, I'll put it above the keyboard tray, so I still have access to the keys when needed. That frees up a lot of room for the mouse.

The quality of the keyboard is great. Everything feels solid. The keys feel wonderful. And, the ergonomics is great for typing.
The tech support was friendly and helpful. I had a bit of a problem early on with customizing the keys, and their tech support promptly helped me.

reviews.title: Great keyboard
reviews.text: Nice quiet keyboard with a great feel.  I got the tenting and wrist rest kit.  It took a little bit to get used to the angle but I'm really enjoying it and have already programmed some of the keys to do routine things for me.

reviews.title: Perfect balance of ergonomics and key comfort.
reviews.text:
I have tried all the Kinesis keyboards with the exception of the 400$ console setup. I have chosen this one as the best overall experience, specifically paired with the VIP3Pro tent and wrist accessory. The keys on this keyboard have a much more consistent and pleasant feeling as compared to their membrane offerings as well as their silent switch option. Those keyboards are fantastic if you are not already addicted to the feeling of mechanical keys. However if you are searching for the ultimate in keyboard experiences for daily use, I heavily and without reservation recommend this keyboard set. The keyboard may initially seem expensive when compared to other ergonomic keyboards that do not split or offer the tenting/wrist rests, however having tried many different curved and non split ergonomic options from Microsoft, Logitech, and many others, I can say without a doubt that the optimal configuration requires the keyboard to be split. If you need to have a number pad like I do, I suggest any simple number key option, they'll fit nicely between the two halves and do not interfere at all. I plan to purchase a second keyboard for my WFH setup to compliment my work setup. I don't want to go back to a standard keyboard and you won't either after using it.

This review was not endorsed, sponsored, or influenced by any 3rd party, I am simply that overjoyed with the product.

title: nuphy Air60 Portable Wireless Keyboard, 60% Low Profile Mechanical Keyboard, Supports Bluetooth 5.0, 2.4G and Wired Connection, Compatible with Windows and Mac OS Systems-Gateron Brown Switch
features: ✨【The new upgrade】：NuType F1 is highly praised by many users. On this basis, we have upgraded NuType F1 in all aspects and got the latest Air60 low-shaft mechanical keyboard. It adopts 60% layout (64 keys), bright color scheme, and the design of low shaft will not hurt your wrist after using the keyboard for a long time. The wide keycap design can help reduce the number of keystroke errors.

💻【Three-mode design】：Each user's usage is different. Based on user needs, we try to adapt the Air60 to as many users as possible, so the Air60 keyboard supports 2.4G, Bluetooth wireless connection and type C wired connection, and can connect up to 4 equipments at the same time to meet more complex user needs.

💪【Alternative laptop keyboard】：The four foot pads on the back of the Air60 can be perfectly embedded between the keys of the notebook keyboard. Typing on the Air60 will not touch the notebook keyboard at the bottom, giving notebook users a better typing experience. It is compatible with most laptops on the market, including the latest Macbooks.

💡【60% Portable Keyboard】：Compared with Air75, Air60 has no F area and will be smaller in size. If you don’t use F area often, Air60 is undoubtedly a better choice for use on the go; if you often use a laptop, Air60 can be perfectly placed. On the keyboard of the notebook computer, it is currently suitable for the vast majority of computers on the market, especially the Mac series, and it is more convenient to carry.

🔋【2500mAh battery】：The battery size of the Air60 wireless keyboard is 2500 mAh. The laboratory test time is more than 48 hours, which can meet the needs of a week of office work. When the backlight mode is turned off, the use time can be greatly increased.

reviews.title: Works great. Battery life is pathetic
reviews.text: Keyboard works great. Compact. Keys are responsible with good travel. The battery, however, lasts just about a day, which is unacceptable.

reviews.title: Didn't think low profile could feel this good...
reviews.text:
I was hesitant to try out this keyboard because I have always avoided low profile mechanical keyboards.

Maybe because I did actually type very well and fast with the chic-lit style keyboards that this keyboard reminds me of and I am too deep into the mechanical keyboard hobby to really want to move to low profile.

I am glad I took the leap!

I really like the way the browns feel on this keyboard. It is a pleasure to type on and the space bars and other stabilized keys feel great. Out of the box I don't think there is anything you need to do to this keyboard except use it!

Some things will take getting use to like the smaller shift button. I actually wouldn't mind if this board was spread out a bit more to allow for more traditional length buttons, but I'm sure it is something I could pick up quickly.

The build quality feels excellent and the polished steel plate on the bottom is a great touch. It really looks classy and I love the look of this keyboard. Nuphy's color-ways have always been super slick to me and this is no different.

The board has awesome RGB effects that you can change easily from the board itself. It connects wired, through bluetooth, or through a 2.4ghz adapter. Bluetooth connected instantly and works super well.

It comes with a ton of accessories, from magnetic feet to tilt the board a bit to extra keycaps, pullers, switches, stickers, and the instructions are also a poster of an anime chick which would probably look good in a gamer style room.

I am really tempted to try and use this board as a daily driver but right now I'm using it with it sitting on my M1 Macbook Airs keyboard and it is working great for that use case. It is thin enough that it doesn't block the screen or anything like that.

I have another compact 60% board that has the same goals as this Nuphy board and it misses the mark. Nuphy really hit the nail on the head with this board.

reviews.text:
Since you always gotta replace PCB manufacturer stabs, you might as well buy these. Great quality. Highly recommend full Holee mod for the best feel. Always lube your stabs folks.
highly recommend.

reviews.title: Improvement on V1
reviews.text: I have used the first version of these and they work good, but have had issues with the stabilizer wires popping out when removing keycaps.  These updated V2 have extra hook to keep the wire in place and work nicely.  These are some of the best stabilizers you can get right now.

reviews.title: I should have gotten these a while ago...
reviews.text:
I have an NK87 and the stabilizer ticking was terrible. I did all the tricks for it, but it persisted from some keys. NK sells their stabilizers for about the same price as these, so I thought I would just have to live with it. Then I just decided to get these, and am so glad I did. Ticking is gone.

Key points
1. They look extremely similar to the NKs, but there is obviously some difference.
2. Straight and flat wires - no tuning needed
3. Manufactured right - i.e. no need to clip, stems are flat
4. Came with the soulmate tuning kit. I think this helped a lot too.

Highly recommended.

title: DROP + Invyr Holy Panda Mechanical Keyboard Switches - Plate Mounted Tactile Switches, Cherry MX Style, 67g Spring, by Kailh (70 PCS)
features: THE MOST TACTILE SWITCHES IN THE WORLD: With a name like Holy Panda, these switches had to be epic. Made with stems from Halo switches, housing found on Invyr Panda switches, Holy Panda switches combine the best of both worlds.
THE BEST OF BOTH WORLDS: The result is a snappy, tactile switch that is satisfying to type on.

COMPATIBILITY: Holy Panda switches are compatible with plate-mounted Cherry-style PCB's and are perfect for hot-swap compatible barebones kits such as the Drop ALT, CTRL, SHIFT, ENTR, Carina, Planck, and Preonic.
SPECS: Halo Switch Stems, Polycarbonate top housing, Nylon bottom housing, 67g spring, Plate Mount, and MX-compatible.

reviews.title: Excellent tactile
reviews.text:
I have purchased these, lubed Glorious Panda, and Tecsee Purple panda.

This is the best with the other 2 being very close to as good as this. The tactile-ness is a little better than the other both. With the other 2, the tactile is right at the beginning, while this one starts at the beginning and seems to feel the same until bottoming out. All have the nice bump back.

I didn't lube these and they sound and feel great. I think this is my favorite tactile now. But if you're on budget, I would recommend one of the others.

reviews.title: Not a bad one in the bunch
reviews.text: Got the 90 pack and not a broken or bent pin in the entire bunch. Professionally packed and working 100 percent. All switches tested and working fine. A little expensive but worth it for the fast Amazon delivery.

reviews.title: Usable keyboard. Mouse is a little problematic.
reviews.text: The keyboard is good and more ergonomic than others but lack of function keys makes less than desirable. The mouse just kept, intermittently disconnecting so was unusable.

reviews.title: Comfortable to use
reviews.text: I didn't have any expectations for this wireless keyboard and mouse set. I just wanted it to sync up easily to the PC and it did. More than that, it is a surprisingly comfortable keyboard to work with. The keys are responsive and accurate. I can put it at an angle that I like. It is easy to store away. I just really like it more than I had expected. I may not have had particular expectations. I just wanted to try out a keyboard/mouse set on a PC that wasn't getting much use, but I may end up putting this set with my main PC set up. I like it that much.

reviews.title: Plug n Play
reviews.text: This is a nice keyboard mouse combo. Set up was simple. There is one dongle for both the keyboard and the mouse. The keyboard is quiet, comfortable and a good size. The mouse is responsive. Time will tell how long it lasts but for now I am pleased with its performance.

reviews.title: Cool looking but not the best mouse
reviews.text:
I wanted a cool looking mouse to replace a Microsoft mouse that was starting to act funny, after 5 + years. After using it for an hour now I really wish I would have spent more for functionality rather than aesthetic value.

First of all I had to pull out a sheet of paper to use as a mouse pad because my old Microsoft mouse functioned with any surface that I used it on, performed flawlessly. This new mouse can't even be used on a standard wooden desk without skipping and jumping all over the screen.

I prepared myself mentally for a cheap feeling mouse because in the end you get what you pay for but holy cow this mouse feels like something I would buy at the local dollar store it screams lack of quality.

I am sure I will be buying another mouse to replace this one shortly either from frustration or because it was built at such a low quality standard.

reviews.title: Excellent travel size and 6 month long battery life!
reviews.text:
Updated 1 year later(May 3, 2020)

Down grading from 5 stars to 3 stars because it turns out there might be a bug in the mouse that once you pair it with 2 different computers over bluetooth, you cannot reset the mouse to use the wireless dongle. There is also no support on the Logitech website - try searching their website for the manual for this mouse, it's absolutely missing. You'll see an FAQ section and some various sections on tech spec, but no setup guide or manual!

*********

If you're tried of replacing batteries, this mouse is for you! I'm impressed by how long a single AA battery lasts in this mouse. I haven't had to replace the battery since getting it 6 months ago even with daily use. The two modes is nice since it lets me connect this mouse to two computers! The bluetooth is strong and connects well to my MacBook Pro, while the included radio frequency receiver is plugged into a iMac and I can switch between computers with a. simple button click.

reviews.title: Great travel mouse!
reviews.text: Love the feel of it. Easy to connect. Small enough to use for travel yet big enough to where it doesn’t hurt to use ergonomically.

reviews.title: WOW! Seamless movement from one computer to the other!
reviews.text:
This device synched to both computers quickly. Download the 'Logi Options' software on both, then enable 'Flow'
Move the mouse off the bottom of one screen & it appears at the top of the other laptop.
Copy a file on computer one, switch to the computer two, right-click->paste. You have copied the file took computer one to computer two.
The mouse itself is legit comfortable, precise asks smooth.
Add 'Flow' and it is also revolutionary.
Highly recommend.

reviews.title: Nice mouse for Mac Pro using Big Sur OS
reviews.text: I was looking for a mouse for my MacPro computer.  It's got 2 buttons on the mouse that I wanted to setup as volume up, and volume down.  But there is no instructions on how to do this, and I can't find any.  I'm using the mouse as a standard mouse with scroll for web pages.  Works perfect for that.

reviews.title: Nice and quiet
reviews.text:
Nice, quiet mouse at a great price. It's on the smaller size, just what I needed for carrying in the computer bag. I have long fingers, but not necessarily large hands, and this fits perfectly for me. The scroll wheel is nice and smooth (and also quiet). You can feel some tactile "knurling" when you scroll, so it's not baby's-butt-smooth, but it's not like scrolling over a circular-saw blade either.

Using the USB dongle, the mouse is very responsive. The Bluetooth connection seemed a little laggy to me. No stars off unless it does the same when I test it on another PC.

I do not intend to install the Logitech Options software so I cannot speak to the usefulness of Flow or reassigning buttons.

Pros
- USB and Bluetooth connectivity
- Can use with up to two devices.
- 7 buttons: L, R, Center, Center-Left, Center-Right, Back, Forward. Eight if you include the PC selector button.
- Very quiet left/right click buttons
- Nearly quiet center click and back/forward buttons
- Uses one AA battery (preferred over non-replaceable battery)
- Battery life advertised at 2 years.
- Has an on/off switch on the bottom

Cons
- Possible laggy response using Bluetooth. I need to test on another PC to be sure.

Other consideration:
- The USB dongle storage is behind the battery door. If you frequently remove the dongle from the PC, this might be a concern for you (it's not a problem for me).

reviews.text: This little mouse is nice and responsive. I really enjoy using it. It's comfortable, too. Highly recommend.

reviews.title: Not what I expected.
reviews.text:
It’s super super lightweight and feels very cheap. It comes with no instructions what so ever. It comes with a little usb input and so I plug it into my Chromebook and put in one AA battery. I flip the switch to on and it starts glowing red. I don’t know what the red light means, again, no instructions. Are the batteries dead? Is it not connected? No idea.
I open up the Bluetooth menu and it’s scanning and nothing is coming up and then I realize the cursor is moving with the mouse. I start rolling it around and it has horrible traction. It’s not a smooth motion as you’d expect from a mouse. Again, maybe my batteries were low, maybe the connection was low, I can’t say, although I switched out the batteries about 3 times and I doubt all 3 batteries were close to dead. I bought this for my sons online homework that he has to do, it consist of a lot of dragging items to designated locations on the screen and he’s been having difficulty using the mouse pad on the Chromebook . But it’s so flimsy, my daughter picked it up and lost it amongst the mess of toys and I don’t even feel at a loss.

reviews.title: Sleek and Elegant

It's attractive and fits your hand comfortably.

reviews.title: Responsiveness is abysmal
reviews.text:
I have a Fellowes mouse pad (vinyl material) and this mouse moves the pointer on it like it is stuck in mud - very slow. Yes, i removed the coated ovals on the bottom. I tried on my desktop protective cover (a softer plastic) and it was even worse. Putting the mouse on paper made it move the mouse pointer faster and smoother but occasionally had hiccups. This is unacceptable for gaming, let alone basic office work. This wasn't even the worse part of this mouse.

The mouse buttons require you to click on the very edge of the button to recognize the click. Because my finger tips reach about 75% of the length I would have to click 3+ times to get Windows 11 to recognize I clicked the button. I made sure to charge the battery to 100% and tried numerous USB ports on my computer and on my docking station to no avail. Would not recommend.

reviews.title: Helped my forearm pain and works as described
reviews.text: Works as described, more natural wrist position and seems to be helping my forearm pain

reviews.title: Very nice mouse!
reviews.text:
I've seen a few of these mice around and this one was inexpensive enough to give the design a try. I normally use only Bluetooth mice because I don't like losing a USB port to a dongle, but made an exception.

I have to say I'm impressed with this device. The performance is rock-solid and it feels great to use. I also like the slightly rubberized finish; feels good in the hand. What I'm doing is alternating between this and a conventional mouse every few days to give my wrist a break. The reduction in wrist discomfort is noticeable.

It's worth losing a USB port to a dongle

reviews.title: Ergonomics
reviews.text: The concept of this mouse is that your hand is in a more natural position when you use it. That part works fine. There is a hesitation that occurs from time to time that will cause you some angst. The mouse button has to wake it from sleep mode, which also takes some getting used to. Overall it is a decent mouse and surprisingly easy to adapt to.

Q&A
Where is the USB receiver?
The USB receiver is in the mouse, you can find it when you open the mouse's battery cover. When you don't use it, you can plug the nano receiver into the USB storage slot again, so you don't lose the USB.
Connectivity and USB troubleshooting
Restart your computer and make sure the mouse is turned on and not too far away from the USB Receiver.

reviews.title: These are great sounding computer speakers
reviews.text:
I have the Klipsch Pro Media Thx 2.1. These are great sounding computer speakers. They best the Bose Companion II which sound terrible in comparison. the Bose sound shallow and weak. These speakers have 3 1/2 inch long throw woofers for the midrange, and a real subwoofer for the lows. They are great sounding for what they are and the best computer speakers to my knowledge in the $200 or below genre.

However, they need to be tweaked. The subwoofer is slightly heavy (although an adjustment is on your speakers) and the highs are slightly bright like other Klipsch speakers, and the midrange is slightly recessed. Simply set your computer system from Windows at 70% output roughly, then pull up iTunes (if you use it) or another equalizer, and set the low bass from about 65K down about 3db below average, put the midrange from about 125K on up to about three 3DB higher than normal, then set the 1K at zero, and above that from 2K on up about 3db below zero. You can adjust that a little to make a curve

These speakers are great. I went with refurbished myself at a little over half price. Enjoy! They are great.

P.S. I am an audiophile who has a good ear and an extremely good stereo system. These do not equal that, but sound great for what they are and better than all others for $200 or less and close to the $400 plus systems.

reviews.title: Not natural sounding but that's how I like my computer speakers to sound
reviews.text: I'm not clear what the differences are between this model and the other identically labelled model from other sellers that sell for less money. You shouldn't pay more than $120-$135 for these from what I can tell after shopping around. I bought mine in "like-new" condition for $99 with Prime free shipping and I'm ecstatic about the sound quality. Subwoofer is boomy and the sat speakers are bright. Typical Klipsch sound. Not natural sounding but that's how I like my computer speakers to sound. I compared these to the Logitech at $105-$120. I own a pair of those too. I'm a fan of Logitech. Make that, I used to be a fan. Going to go with Klipsch if I ever have need for more speakers. These sound great. You won't be disappointed if you like the "Klipsch sound."

reviews.title: The satellite speakers are clear with a good amount of range and depth whether playing games or ...
reviews.text: First experience with Klipsch speakers and I am thoroughly impressed! Wasn't expecting the amount of impact from the subwoofer (my previous pc came with a factory 5.1 setup and fall flat compared to these). The satellite speakers are clear with a good amount of range and depth whether playing games or listening to music/watching videos. I was worried that a 2.1 setup would leave something to be desired vs a 5.1 setup, but I'm glad I made the jump!

reviews.text: Perfect just as described

reviews.title: No better computer speaker out there
reviews.text:
There is simply no better set of computer speakers out there. The subwoofer rivals those home theater setups as well. I have this in my office connected to a Mac Mini which I often use for iTunes and watching movies, and recording to Garageband.

I have never cranked the volume 100%, it's incredibly loud at 65%. Bass is very smooth and powerful.

I actually needed speakers for an outdoor wedding and actually brought these to the event, no one complained about not being able to hear the ceremony even 20 rows back.

If you can't afford a home theatre system, consider this 2.1 for your living room as well. This will surprise you.

reviews.title: Good but wanted more features
reviews.text:
I bought this in a time crunch. My wired mouse was getting hard to use because the scroll wheel had shifted out of place. I had several wireless mice around, but none of them still had their wireless receiver. And they were before the days of Bluetooth. So, I had was in the market for a new one.

This one is nice. It fits the hand well and all. But, I realized that it did not have the features that I was used to. First, it is not a quiet mouse. I did not notice at first, but when it penetrated my fog of concentration, I could not unhear it. Click. Click. Click! And, this was not great for conference calls either.

The other issue was that it tracked slower than I would like. I was still using my wired mouse at this point, so I did not want to change mouse settings via software. I really missed having a dpi button on my mouse. This is important to me as I use a laptop on an extended display to a 2nd monitor. So, I need to be able to zip from one end of the screen the other - quick enough to unmute and answer a question during a conference call.

Have to click to wake up the mouse kept catching my attention - which means it was on it's way to annoying me... I have worked with computers for so long, it's like an extension of me. It needs to be intuitive to use and not interrupt my flow.

And, at this point, I figured out that I would need to use two different computers at once. And, while I could pair this wireless mouse with a wired one, the USB ports required were a challenge. My newer computer has no USB C ports at all. So, this limited my set-up options. Secondly, I now had 2 mice crowding limited desk space.

So, I learned that there was such a thing as multi-device mice. And, I found one that can switch between two computers and a iPad - with a simple LED indicator so that you know which device you are controlling. I bought the also designed to be silent and to switch between different dpi. All these features and it was only $3 more.

This is what I bought to replace this one - Arteck Multi-Device Wireless Bluetooth Mouse with Nano USB Receiver Ergonomic Right Hand Silent Clicking for Computer Desktop PC Laptop Mac iPad and Windows 10/8 iPad OS Build in Rechargeable Battery

So, to sum it up, I would say that I need the speed and responsiveness of a gamer's mouse with the silent clicks and 3 device connects like an office worker. So, this mouse is ok. But, if you are an advance or intense user, you may find that it does meet your needs.

As I began typing, I liked the smooth, quite feel BUT quickly discovered that this keyboard does NOT have a 'Print Screen' key, which is vital when working. DO NOT Buy this if you need it for work. As you can see in the picture provided, the 'F11' key is NOT labeled.
F11 toggles from Full Screen back to regular screen. The first 4 keys at the top of the number key pad are TOTALLY UNNECESSARY.
1st key) Same function as Ctrl+C (Copy)
2nd key) Does Absolutely Nothing!
3rd key) Same function as Ctrl+V, (Paste)
4th key) Same function as Ctrl+X (Cut)
Had this keyboard followed the SAME FORMAT
The keyboard is overpriced to be missing a vital function as Print Screen Key.

reviews.title: One of the best everyday mice I've used
reviews.text:
I have input devices for drawing on my tablet, and I have a gaming mouse, but the Logitech M305 is an excellent mouse for every day use, so it's the one I use the most.

The mouse itself has very basic features,
* scroll wheel (mild clicking feedback)with side-click options
* battery status light (green when fully charged, red when almost out)
* two buttons
* an off switch
* a nano USB transmitter than stores inside the mouse
* uses a single AA battery

It does come in jazzy designs, and I liked the yellow/gold one the best. The one thing I might have wanted to change on this mouse is the on/off switch. The best nano-USB mouse I've ever had would automatically turn off when you stored the transmitter inside. With this one, be sure to flip the switch to off as well before you put it in your bag, or it will be down there draining the battery as it moves around.

reviews.title: Amazing addition to the Logitech G Pro Wireless!
reviews.text: Great quality, precision cut pieces that fit EXACTLY in the shape of the mouse. Whoever designed the CAD for this did a great job on the measurements. Using the grip itself, also crazy how something so small makes a big difference. No more worrying about it slipping off my right thumb which I mentally couldn't handle. It's shame that Logitech didn't design the grip but this will do nicely until they do.

reviews.title: They're ok.
reviews.text:
I'm only using the side grips. (No issue with the texture of the buttons, so imo, its best to just not use them and keep the mouse as light as possible)

Its definitely an improvement over the stock plastic feel, which is too smooth for me. These add some grip, and even a bit of cushion.

Guess I was expecting a more grippy feeling. Maybe a more pronounced texture. There is definitely room for improvement for those of us with sweaty gaming hands.

I also wish the edges were tapered off at its edges rather than a hard cut, but that's a minor nitpick and not too important.

I will say with these grips, I am having trouble deciding between which mouse to use primarily... G Pro Wireless or Viper Ultimate. This is definitely something that was missing from the G Pro Wireless's design for me.

reviews.title: It works great! But not for long!
reviews.text:
Came a day early, put two AAA batteries in, put the USB in the laptop, and away we go.

It works great.

Update: It didn't work for long. It starts out with the mouse going to sleep all on it's own, and then it gets worst (you wouldn't think it possible, would you). I left the laptop and mouse on while I ran to the store, when I came back it was working VERY intermittent (very jerky) so I opened it thinking maybe my batteries weren't all that good.

What did I find? One of the batteries was so hot I couldn't touch it. I'm surprised it didn't catch on fire.

I should have known better than to buy some Chinese garbage. Into the trash it went.

Don't buy this, it's a waste of good money.

reviews.title: GREAT BUY!
reviews.text:
I had purchased an ergonomic mouse prior to this one. It was rechargeable as well and died less than an hour after lite use. It was not very comfortable and felt cheap. When i received this one I was skeptical because it did feel lite weight and I worried it would be cheap quality. It is comfortable & light weight, rechargeable long lasting charge. I use it for work it lasts all day and since I work from home I used it at night as well without needing a recharge until bed time. I have switched to regular mouse a couple times when i forgot to charge mine and there is a huge difference in comfort. I have a hand injury and when i use a regular mouse my hand hurts, after using this one I see a big difference when I have had to switch back. Highly recommend.

** update: i’ve now had this for several months and I have actually ordered another one which I haven’t had to take out of the box. I honestly ordered it because I lost the charging cord to my first one which I rarely use. I think I charge this mouse maybe once a week if that and I use it up to 15 hours a day with work and it never dies.

reviews.title: Love this mouse!

title: SHARKOON Drakonia Gaming Mouse - Black
description: The Drakonia Black is the follow-up model to our popular Green Drakonia. Like before, the Drakonia Black has eleven buttons and a 4-way scroll wheel, with each being freely programmable through the included configuration software to perform various different functions. An ADNS-9800 laser sensor from Avago operates under the gray dragon scales casing, with the current DPI setting in use indicated by a constantly illuminating LED. The SoftSkin surface of the Drakonia Black offers a soft grip and prevents perspiration build-up, ensuring the mouse fits perfectly in the hand even during heated battles. Likewise, the ergonomic shape of the Drakonia Black is designed for stability and control: its outwardly curved underside offers more grip during very small and precise movements as well as a high-level of comfort during long gaming sessions. Therefore the Drakonia Black is aimed especially at FPS Snipers and RTS/RPG gamers - the type of players who typically launch themselves into long battles and epic adventures. In the underside of the Drakonia Black you will find six metal weights comprising the Weight Tuning System, allowing the fighting weight of the mouse to be adjusted at any time. Unleash your inner Dragon – with the Drakonia Black!

title: Logitech POP Mouse, Wireless Mouse with Customizable Emojis, SilentTouch Technology, Precision/Speed Scroll, Compact Design, Bluetooth, Multi-Device, OS Compatible - Mist
description: Logitech POP Mouse - Silent Wireless Mouse Let personality POP on your deskspace and beyond with POP Mouse, your whisper-quiet, wireless mouse with fresh customization features. Take your self-expression further and download Logitech Software to customize the top button. Give it your own twist by assigning it to send your favorite emoji or another shortcut - such as Snip Screen, Mic Mute or Voice-to-Text. POP Mouse fits comfortably in your hand and slips easily into your pocket, handbag or computer case. SilentTouch technology makes every click whisper-quiet. The portable mouse's SmartWheel stays in sync with you, easily shifting from high-precision to speed scroll mode. Pair POP Mouse with up to 3 different devices at once, and use the Easy-Switch button to toggle between them. Alternatively, activate FLOW and glide between screens as you work, transferring text, files and images with a simple copy and paste. Connect the cordless mouse to your desktop, tablet or phone* using Bluetooth or a Logi Bolt USB receiver which you can purchase separately. With a classic Logitech promise of durability, POP Mouse is your companion for the long haul, with up to 24-month battery life** and auto-sleep power-saving technology that helps it last. reviews.title: Horrible Connection

reviews.title: Quiet and super fast Bluetooth setup - no Emoji function with iPadOS
reviews.text: Within a minute of taking this out of the box, I had it paired with my iPad. It was seriously so easy to just pair and go, and I love how it can be paired with three different things (just push a little button on the bottom of the mouse to switch between computers/iPads). It feels okay in my hand - not the highest quality I’ve seen (plastic is very basic and it is pretty lightweight as well), but it doesn’t feel cheap. The color is so fun, which is the main reason I got it. Also it is very quiet and doesn’t have any loud clicking. The one thing to mention is that the circle button under the scrolling wheel doesn’t have any functionality with an iPad. Nothing was happening when I kept clicking it to try and use the emoji shortcut, so after heading over to Logitech’s website i saw “*Emojis and software are currently supported on Windows® and macOS only.” So maybe iPadOS will eventually support this capability, but as of now it is useless. Overall I still like the mouse a lot for it’s ease of use, quietness, and color.

reviews.title: Beautiful little mouse with a pink color that truly POPS!
reviews.text:
THE GOOD:
---------------
* The pink color of this mouse really POPS!
* Operation is smooth, just like any mouse.
* Multi device with a click of button underneath the mouse. You can save up to 3 devices.
* Battery is included and is rated for 2 yrs. Wow, we'll see.
* Emoji dedicated center button for chats.
* Weighs 2.9 ounces.

THE BAD:
------------
* No information in box whatsoever about the emoji software. You'll need to go to Logitech's website and do some digging. I didn't bother since my little girl won't be chatting.
* Bluetooth only. No mentioning in the manual whether or not it works with their unifying receiver.

I got this mouse because my little girl loves pink, and the red coral color here truly pops! She does basic homework stuff on the pc. She's not at that chatting age yet, so I don't really care or tested the emoji feature. Logitech didn't make it easy for you to test it out anyway, so I didn't bother. I'll go 4-Stars overall.

Not being a Y gen - lol, it took me a while to figure how to work the emoji button.  again, not a key aspect for us.  Curious to test that the battery will last for 1 year as claimed, but easy to take off the 'color' plate and replace the AA battery.  very happy with the color.  fun and ergonomically comfortable.

reviews.title: I found the buttons too easy to click
reviews.text: Meh...I found the buttons too easy to click, sometimes just the weight of my hand would make the mouse click. Also, the mouse cursor would wander when the mouse itself wasn't moving. It has some features that surprised me like being able to take weights in and out of the mouse for customized weight, but the easy clicks and the wandering cursor were deal breakers. Overall it feels a bit cheap. I got a logitech 510 instead and really like that mouse. Just a casual gamer here, wasn't looking for anything fancy.

reviews.title: Great Mouse!
reviews.text:
I really like this mouse and for the money, it is by far the best value in a gaming mouse I have purchased to date. I have spent over $100 for other gaming mice just to have them wear out after a year of use. I paid about $20 for this mouse and I am not disappointed in the quality at all. It uses the same switches as more expensive mice, feels great in my hand and is just as responsive as those more expensive models I purchased in the past. You may not get all the RGB lighting effects or programming features, but for the cost it cannot be beat.

The only thing that is a slight disappointment is the scroll wheel. One click is too strong and there are no settings in the software to adjust it. For the price I paid, it is something I can easily overlook and still give this mouse a 5 star review.

reviews.title: Defective Mouse
reviews.text:
This mouse would rate five stars if it didn't go bad after the return date.

It feels nice in the hand, it does all the mouse things it is supposed to, and it slides around smoothly. That is, when it decides to connect to my computer. I have a macbook pro with a bootcamp partition and primarily plug in through a USB hub. At first, I thought the hub had issues, but my keyboard is also connected to the hub and it has zero problems connecting with either OS. The mouse, on the other hand, likes to go on strike, even when plugged directly into the laptop's USB port. I have yet to determine the conditions cause the mouse to stop working, but I have yet to find a pattern. The mouse is just as likely to stop working on El Capitan as it is on Windows 10.

I tried to contact Velocifire since my mouse started being lazy after the return window, but I never heard back. I will not be buying from this company again.

reviews.text:
I like the mouse. Excellent value for money, except for one very annoying flaw. It is constantly disconnecting the bluetooth connection from my new Macbook Pro. It's pretty annoying.

After what feels like only a few minutes of idle time, the mouse bluetoothe disconnects. Then when I move it nothing happens for a couple seconds. The finally, it connects and my laptop tells me the mouse is back, and it works perfectly... until the next time it is idle.

I have use other low cost brands as well as my Apple Magic Mouse (which I don't use as I prefer a track wheel). I have not had any issues with the Bluetooth on those, only this one...

If it were not for the disconnect issue I would rate the mouse a 5 star. Otherwise, I give it a 3. I am still using it for now, but will find a better one...

UPDATE: Okay, I find that I am CONSTANTLY drustrated that this mouse loses connection with my laptop. PITA. Not worth using at any price.

reviews.title: Very good price-point for Laptop portability and Features
reviews.text:
Rating this PINKCAT wireless mouse is difficult in terms of "stars". The price-point and your intended use are big factors.

I'll get one thing out of the way to save you some time - if you're a gamer, I would say that this is not going to have the stable accuracy you need. In fact, I think it will frustrate gamers, so if you're a gamer then you need to move on/up to something more expensive. Just my opinion.

My usage is for work. Lots and lots of work - like 12-15 hours a day of non-stop "click click click" work, so I'm basing my review on that and in comparison, to my main "workhorse" mouse.

My main mouse is a Logitech Anywhere MX, which is an incredible mouse but is also about $50 more than this PINKCAT mouse. I wanted to find something similar in both size and features as my more expensive mouse but with silent click and more as a backup, and for basic uses this fits the bill pretty well.

As you can see in the photos, this mouse is only slightly larger than a Logitech Anywhere MX, so it's still plenty small enough for laptop / portable / small space use. Now that you know what I'm comparing it to, I'll get right to the pros & cons.

PROS:

- Very light-weight, significantly lighter than my MX, yet still similar in size & shape.

- The "silent" buttons are truly that! Something I wish was a feature with my noisy MX buttons.

- Only requires one AA battery (my MX requires two) and excellent battery life.

- Scroll-wheel is smooth, quiet, and comfortable.

- The dull mat style surface is very comfy and doesn't get sticky like the shiny slick surface of my MX.

- The "back" and "forward" thumb-buttons work as expected for quick switching back & forth on web pages and tabs / locations in file explorer folders.

CONS:

- Even with the "3 Grade Adjustable DPI" function, I wouldn't recommend this mouse for gaming or fine digital artwork in apps like Photoshop.

- The signal and receiver seem to be a little easily susceptible to signal issues and occasional jitter, but that could be due to the number of various devices I have in the room. When I first tested it out there seemed to be a lot of jitter and the cursor jumped around a bit, but after switching it to a different system than the one I used my MX on, and adjusting the mouse settings a bit in Windows, it has been pretty smooth.

- No side-to-side push with the scroll wheel, unlike my MX. (But again, we're talking $8 compared to $58).

- Battery compartment door is flimsy. It's OK, but handle with care when popping it open.

Overall, this mouse is fine for basic use, and for its price-point it's excellent.

This was really hard to rate in terms of "stars" , especially coming from the perspective of someone who owns a more finely tuned & designed expensive mouse. So... for the price and for basic use I'd give it 5 stars, but for smooth accuracy it's not going to measure-up to something like a high-end Logitech and would be more like 3 stars in that aspect. But for 8 bucks It's a great mouse - gets the job done for standard computer uses, and it's definitely light, silent buttons! So over all I have to give it 4 stars.

reviews.title: Keyboard is very loud when typing!
reviews.text: The mouse is pretty standard, nothing great, but nothing bad. I brought my cute little set to work in my laptop bag so I figured it was secure. When I took the keyboard out 1 letter had popped off. No biggie, it snapped back on easily. The keyboard buttons are bit higher than I'm used to so I was typing slower and it was a bit uncomfortable after a while. I planned on switching back to my regular keyboard shortly but what escalated that switch was how loud the keyboard was while I was typing. My office is usually rather quiet plus I'm in a cubicle and a coworker asked what are you doing over there!?! He said it sounded like I was hammering the letters with a small hammer. I knew it was loud but after realizing it was bothering my coworkers I immediately put it in my bag to bring home. Haven't used it since!

reviews.title: Plug and Play Wireless Keyboard; Not sure about the mouse
reviews.text: I run Windows 10 on my laptop, and this wireless keyboard was up and running in few minutes after unpackaging.  You will need to provide your own batteries (2 AA – one for the mouse and one for the keyboard).  The keys are not tactile like other “typewriter” keyboard I have, but the keys have enough tension in the loaded spring to give a slight “satisfactory” feel to the keystrokes.  The wireless connection between the receiver and the keyboard/mouse was responsive and experienced no noticeable delay.  I am not 100% sold on the “milk tea” colored keyboard, but it slowly grew on me after a few days of use, although my 8-year young daughter thought it was like a puke color… an interesting observation.  The mouse was not for me.  It was too flat and too small for my hand, and after a few hours of cumbersome use, I switched back to my existing mouse pad.  For less than $49 USD, I think this keyboard brings a fun look to the otherwise a boring office environment.

reviews.title: Flawless Bluetooth connectivity with Mac
reviews.text: My Logitech M310 (been using them for 10-15 years) could not connect properly with my USB-C/Thunderbolt MacBookPro, using their USB dongle, thru a USB adapter. Scroll wheel would NOT work, and Logitech tech support said they would not update drivers. 'Don't use an adapter.' But they aren't aware that new Macs don't have old-school USB ports? Anyone else have this problem?! Anyway... this Seenda connects directly with Bluetooth, and connects instantly. If it sleeps (after a few hours?) it wakes and re-connects with one click, in less than a second. I charged the battery when I bought it a few weeks ago, and forgot that I might need to charge it again one day. Still going. Downsides: it is much smaller and lighter than I am used to (the M310 is easily twice as thick/tall) so I am getting used to that. Took awhile to find the right DPI/resolution/speed (and the button to change that is in a precarious, easy-to-hit-by-mistake position. Overall a great recommend.

reviews.title: you get what you pay for
reviews.text: these work but feel like crap.  Left and right click are terrible.  Sometimes when I left click, as the piece of plastic is coming back up, it goes under the right side.  Its like someone took a solid sheet of plastic and cut a line down the middle to allow you to press down on the left or right side, its terrible.  Scroll wheel feels fine.  DPI button just cycles through, no way to go up or down, just cycles through 3 modes.  Very uncomfortable.  For the price, you get two and both are exactly like this so I doubt its defective.  I only got these to control my streaming PC so its not a HUGE deal, but if youre getting these for daily use - DONT DO IT.  I can hardly put up with these and I use them for maybe 10 mins a day.  Pay 15$ for one mouse.  I honestly feel like I could crush these with my hand - thats how crappy they feel.  They also go to sleep mode after like 5 mins so I have to constantly click it to wake it up, and it ends up opening apps.  Not worth the 15$

reviews.title: It's a mouse, it works.
reviews.text:
When purchasing a bluetooth mouse, or any bluetooth device, an important factor is how well it connects and how well it STAYS connected. After all this time, the industry still can’t make up its mind about how bluetooth works:
- Microsoft with their mouse and Sony with their controller that pair without the need of a code (which Android’s bluetooth stack doesn’t support).
- Mice and keyboards that will not reconnect after it wakes from sleep mode.
- To this day, bluetooth devices still can’t wake a computer from suspend state.
So when I get a simple bluetooth mouse for a good price, and it actually works as expected, I was happy.

For my review, I’m comparing the Bornd mouse to the [[ASIN:B006428K7I Motorola 89519N Bluetooth Mouse]] which I got in a set that included the [[ASIN:B004L9MBH6 Motorola Wireless Keyboard for Motorola ATRIX and XOOM (Motorola Retail Packaging)]].

With the Motorola mouse, its frequency somehow conflicts with the Motorola keyboard, resulting in sticky keys, as in “I’m having a good daaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaay”. Conversely, the keyboard interferes with the mouse where the computer would actually lose connection with the mouse for a few seconds after typing, or lose connection completely.

What I liked about the Bornd:
- Pairing was simple using the button at the bottom of the mouse.
- Operating distance is about 5 feet, but this may be because of my computer’s bluetooth antenna
- Takes a single AA battery which lasts over a month of moderate use (2 hours per day)
- Mouse movement is good. No need to adjust mouse speed in the control panel.
- Accuracy is good. Editing images using Pixlr.com, I’m able to select precisely the parts of the image I need.

What gave me trouble with the Bornd:
- When you first put your hand on this mouse, you will not feel that it is very well built. The plastic is completely smooth and the mouse wheel seems to rattle when you shake it. I got used to it after a few minutes, though.
- The mouse reconnects with the computer most of the time, but sometimes it was necessary to turn the mouse off and on again after the computer reboots or if the computer was out of range for an extended period of time.
- Lately, I’ve been experiencing double-clicks when I click on the left mouse button once. I’m usually able to fix this by getting angry and slamming the mouse down a couple of times. This may indicate a build quality issue with this mouse.

In my specific case, the Bournd did not interfere with my Motorola keyboard at all and it seems the sticky key occurs only when the batteries on the keyboard runs low.

reviews.title: Move along. Don't waste your time and money here.
reviews.text:
UPDATE: Two months! Two months this mouse lasted, and that was with very light use. Fully charged, I was just scrolling with it when I felt the wheel break. It just stopped making the little clicky sound/feeling. No trauma, no misuse, just very very very cheaply made. I surrender. It's time to cough up the money and buy the Apple brand mouse for my MacBook. My sanity is at least worth the $60.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:
After three previous tries, I finally got a Bluetooth mouse for my MacBook. I'm hoping this one is sturdier than the last I purchased that barely lasted six months. That remains to be seen, but given the product materials, I'm not hopeful. Making the connection after power-up or sleep mode is a little finicky. Also, a solid flat dark surface/mouse pad seems to be a prerequisite. Without it, the cursor is slow to respond or just does its own thing. I've never seen a mouse with the jitters before, but this one will cause the cursor to jiggle and twitch, even though the mouse itself it perfectly still, untouched. I've watched the cursor jitter clear off the screen. However, using a solid black mouse pad seems to have dealt with the problem. I would send it back and try a different product, but I've sent so many cheaply made and/or mislabeled mice back to Amazon in the past month, I've got return fatigue. We'll give this one a chance with the mousepad solution.

reviews.title: Definitely returning and buying a different brand

I would even go as far as to say that it dies faster than that. Purchased this for my sister for her birthday but will definitely return and go with a different laptop.

reviews.title: RAPIQUE Bluetooth Wireless Mouse
reviews.text:
RAPIQUE Bluetooth Wireless Mouse
Great mouse. USB C re-chargeable. Can run in bluetooth or RF mode. Lights up so can see when lights are off. Feels great. Compact but not to compact, is still comfortable and ergonomical.
Affordable.
I used to buy the well known name brand mouse that can cost 2 to 4 times the price. With the competitor mouse after about 6 to 12 months it would start to double click. I now feel maybe that is "planned obsolence", so I will no longer buy that mouse.
The main shortcuts I use are forward and back which are already on two side buttons. I then also use Start + D for Desktop, so I can do that with this mouse.
Liked it so much bought 2 more for my other laptops / backups.
Great mouse.

reviews.title: Super fun RGB lighting and great for Hell Let Loose
reviews.text: I wanted something with more buttons for Hell Let Loose than the Basilik V3. This mouse is ideal for those that need extra buttons for gaming as that is the primary reason you should consider it. The thumbrest is great as I think all gaming mice should have thumbrests since it’s so much better for your hand ergonomics. I have large hands and the mouse feels very good to hold and gives no fatigue. At first I though my thumb would hit the easy shift button but it didn’t so that’s another plus. I would say the left and right click buttons could be a bit wider and more ergonomic to say something like Basilik v3 which is where that mouse is a bit better but overall negligible. Of course the RGB is where the mouse really looks great, I love seeing so many fun colors move around and it looks really pretty to look at. So if you have a game you really like to play and are annoyed using your keyboard for some critical commands like in Hell Let Loose (map, team chat, squad chat, leadership chat) this is a very pretty, well designed convenient button placement mouse, I would recommend it.

reviews.title: Very nice gaming mouse
reviews.text:
This mouse is very ergonomic, has many buttons, and the software is good. I play many different games and need button profiles for them. The software is easy to use, and it is easy to associate a game/program with a profile for auto-switching when it is run.

I seem to use the buttons/profiles of gaming mice much more than some people. When I read mouse reviews, they mostly talk about the weight of it and other silly things that only first person shooter people care about. I care much more about the number/placement of extra buttons and the software used to configure the mouse.

I have several nice mice from other brands, brought down by HORRIBLE software. Logitech and Corsair make nice mice, but their software is a deal breaker. Roccat's mouse software is WONDERFUL.

I also like that the mouse has optical switches, which will last longer.

Only downsides: Not AS MANY buttons as my Roccat LEADR (started registering the dreaded double-click fault) and the software only supports 5 profiles at once. If you play more than 5 games that need a profile, you have to do the export/import dance. But this is a trivial fault.

The LEDs are a little loud, but I'm not a big LED/RGB lighting person anyway, so you can't fault the mouse. And you can turn them off (though I tend to set the colors to identify the game, so I can make sure I'm in the correct profile.)

Wonderful gaming mice that can be used for many different genres: MMO, FPS, etc.

reviews.title: upgrade from the KONE AIMO
reviews.text: I had to upgrade my previous mouse the KONE AIMO. It has a known issue with the left click which was repaired for a period of time then started acting up. I play World of Warcraft and use sooo many key binds, so having a mouse like this is very helpful to my gameplay. The Kone XP is awesome. Lighter than the AIMO, similar button style but just feels smoother. Highly recommend it.
